Mr. Stanley is returning to China in a new role as chief executive of operations there, after stepping down as country officer in June. Ms. Weir, who was named country corporate officer for Hong Kong and China at that time, succeeds Mr. Stanley as head of global corporate investment banking in Southeast Asia, according to a memo; the contents of the memo were confirmed by a company spokesman, Richard Tesvich. Citigroup is lagging HSBC Holdings as overseas banks expand in China, the world's fastest-growing major economy, to prepare for greater market access at the end of 2006.

The company forecast fourth-quarter profit, excluding some costs, of 1 cent to 3 cents a share, in contrast to an earlier estimate of a loss of 2 cents to 5 cents. description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority this week officially took over the six Bronx routes of Liberty Lines Express Inc., one of seven bus lines often criticized for poor service. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg greeted commuters on Riverdale Avenue in the Bronx yesterday, as riders on the BXM1 route boarded a brand-new bus, one of 10 new ones replacing older buses. The city has twice pushed back deadlines to convert all seven of the bus lines -- subsidized by the city -- to the authority's control. City officials have continued to haggle with the owners and unions of the remaining lines over terms of the takeover. City officials say they now hope to complete the conversion by the end of April. description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has signed a bill to temporarily extend the franchise of the company that operates bus shelters. The city continues to work on a more comprehensive plan that would include newsstands and street toilets. The new law extends through Dec. 31 the franchise held by New York Subways Advertising Company, a subsidiary of Viacom Outdoor Inc. The company is guaranteed $13.5 million in compensation this year, and the city will receive 60 percent of gross advertising revenues above $35 million. Last March, the city's Department of Transportation requested proposals for a comprehensive project that will include bus shelters, self-cleaning public toilets, newsstands and other structures on which the city can sell advertising. Five companies submitted proposals in September. A technical committee is reviewing the proposals and is scheduled to select one of the companies this spring. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOFFMAN, ROBERT F.
description: HOFFMAN--Robert F., 79, of Madison, New Jersey, on January 1. Born South Orange, NJ, son of GF Hoffman, Founder of Hoffman Beverage Co. Lovingly known as "Sport." Survived by wife of 54 years, Marion, of Madison, and five sons: Larry of Ridgewood, NJ, Greg of Washington, CT, Johannes of Annapolis, MD, Rob of Pennington, NJ and Tom of Weston, CT. Graduated in '43 from Columbia High and MIT in '46. Majored in Mechanical Design, rowed Varsity Crew, President of OX Fraternity, Tau Beta Pi honors. 23 years with Worthington Pump, helped found Leisuredyn Inc. in '69, manufactured world's first personal watercraft: the Aquadart. Owned RF Hoffman & Sons, engineering consultancy, concluded career with Hartz Mountain in '83. Early mainstay of Madison Y Indian Guides, 50+ year member and President of Maplewood Glee Club. Chairman of Columbia High and MIT 50th Reunions. Tutored underprivileged Newark youth in math. Avid sailor, skippered a Comet on Candlewood Lake, and later a Lightning at Lavallette Yacht Club. Visitation January 5, 2-4 and 7-9, at Bradley Memorial Home, Chatham, NJ. Celebration of Life January 6 at 11 AM, First Presbyterian Church, New Vernon. Contributions to the Maplewood Glee Club Scholarship Fund, Box 54, Maplewood, New Jersey 07040 or NJ Audubon Society/ Schermann-Hoffman Sanctuary, Hardscrabble Road, Bernardsville, NJ 07924.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHULMAN, ANN WEINFELD
description: SCHULMAN--Ann Weinfeld. Died peacefully at home on January 4, 2005, at the tooyoung age of 73, after a brief battle with lung cancer. The elder daughter of Judge Edward and Lillian Weinfeld, Ann grew up on the Lower East Side, was educated in New York's public schools and then Vassar College, married (and later divorced) Alvin Schulman, with whom she had their daughters Amy and Nina, and then at the age of 49 was graduated from the NYU Law School, going on to become a passionate and effective advocate for labor unions and their members. A marvelous cook, avid theater goer, delightful conversationalist, intrepid traveler and committed devotee of tennis and baseball, Ann befriended countless people from all walks of life. Her exceptional emotional generosity and warmth of spirit were special gifts that will be long treasured by those who knew her. Ann leaves behind Amy and her family, David Nachman, Ezra, Gideon and Rafael; Nina and her family, Hal Ruddick, Lydia and Saul; her sister Fern and her family, Daniel Cohen, Seth, Elizabeth and Josh and their children; and so many others whose love for Ann will endure. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Jewish Fund for Justice, 330 Seventh Ave., NY, NY 10001, or Vassar College, 124 Raymond Avenue, Poughkeepsie, NY 12604. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, January 5, 2005 at 11:45 AM at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. SCHULMAN--Ann W. We mourn the loss of Ann W. Schulman, our former colleague and friend. Her dedication to protecting the rights of working people and joie de vivre will always be cherished. We will miss her deeply. Spivak, Lipton, Watanabe, Spivak & Moss LLP SCHULMAN--Ann. Our beloved friend whose intellect, warmth and graciousness enriched our lives. Ann was truly an extraordinary woman whose memory will live in our hearts and minds forever. Our thoughts and love are with her family. Barbara, David and Robin

title: PROXY ADVISER ENDORSES MERGER OF MOLSON AND COORS
description: The Adolph Coors Company and Molson said yesterday that Institutional Shareholder Services, the world's biggest adviser on proxy voting, recommended that investors approve their planned $3.4 billion merger. To proceed, Molson, Canada's biggest brewer, needs two-thirds of its widely held Class A shares to be voted in favor of the deal. Molson, based in Montreal, and Coors, based in Golden, Colo., announced merger plans in July. Burgundy Asset Management, a fund manager in Toronto with more than 600,000 Class B shares of Molson, said that it would not support the transaction because it undervalues the brewer.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Economy Expands
description: Vietnam's economy expanded in 2004 at its fastest pace since 1997, the government said, bolstered by accelerated growth in service industries. Gross domestic product grew 7.7 percent in 2004, according to preliminary figures from the General Statistics Office, up from 7.3 percent growth in 2003 and the highest figure since an 8.2 percent expansion in 1997. The economy has averaged 7 percent growth over the last decade, driven by surging exports and an emerging domestic market serving Vietnam's 81 million people. Services, which account for 40 percent of the economy, expanded 7.5 percent last year, up from 6.6 percent growth in 2003.

title: HAPPY KIDS, A CLOTHING DESIGNER, FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: Happy Kids, which designs children's apparel for major brands, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday after missing payments on a $48 million loan. The company, which is based in New York, has licenses to design clothing for brands like Izod, Calvin Klein, And1 and Jammies, court documents showed. The clothing designer has an agreement to borrow $53 million from the CIT Group/Commercial Services so it can continue operations, according to court documents. Happy Kids will use the loan for employee pay, licensing fees, manufacturing costs and other operating expenses. Happy Kids owes CIT $33 million from a 1999 loan. In its filing with the United States Bankruptcy Court in New York, the company listed assets of $54.7 million and liabilities of $82.1 million.

title: JUDGE ORDERS TRUMP CASINOS TO OPEN ITS BOOKS

Judge Judith H. Wizmur of United States District Court ordered the casino company and its affiliates to provide updated reports on cash flow and financial forecasts. The judge also ordered the company to make its financial adviser available to answer questions from lawyers for the investors and delayed final approval of a $100 million bank loan that lawyers for the company contend is needed to help keep its Atlantic City casinos operating. The company filed for bankruptcy court protection on Nov. 21. Under the plan, Donald J. Trump would remain chairman and chief executive, but his stake in the company would be cut to 27 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMILTON, RICHARD
description: HAMILTON--Richard. Final Curtain Call at 84, beloved actor of radio, stage, screen and television, died peacefully at home in the Catskills, leaving a long theatrical history. Born in Illinois in 1920, he grew up in California where he attended Pasadena Junior College and the Playhouse, and worked in west coast radio. His memorable roles Off Broadway and On include that of Dodge in the Pulitzer Prize winning production of Sam Shepard's "Buried Child", and of Carl in the 1982 Tony Award winning revival of "Mornings at Seven". Film performances include: The Hospital 1971, Resurrection 1980, Arthur 1981, Protocol 1984, Pale Rider 1985, In Country 1989, Sommersby 1993, On Deadly Ground 1994, Men in Black 1997, Death to Smoochy 2002. On television: Naked City 1963, F.D.R.: The Last Year 1980, Bret Maverick 1981, St. Elsewhere 1983, The Equalizer 1986, 1989, Riviera 1987, Law & Order 1991, 1993, 1996, The Yearling 1994, Picket Fences 1996, Frasier 1996, Oz 1997 and Spin City 1998. Devoted husband and adopted father of two, he imparted to family and friends a rich love of literature and the theatrical arts that was both infectious and inspirational. A man of open and generous nature, easily approachable by all, he made everyone feel like an old friend. He leaves his wife of 50 years, Marilyn Morgan Hamilton, a daughter Hannele Dzubas and a son Morgan Hamilton. A memorial is planned for the spring at the Players Club in New York City where he was an active member for many years. Donations in his memory to the Actors Fund of America.

description: CapitaLand, a Southeast Asian developer, agreed to buy two Beijing shopping malls from a retailer, the Beijing Hualian Group Investment Holding Company, for 345 million Singapore dollars ($211 million), continuing its expansion in China. The two companies are also forming a 50-50 joint venture to provide marketing and retail management services for malls, including one of the shopping centers covered by the purchase agreement, CapitaLand said in a statement filed with the stock exchange. CapitaLand, which is based in Singapore, is pushing into China to tap rising retail demand and to expand beyond Singapore. In December, the company agreed to pay the Shenzhen International Trust and Investment Company 196 million Singapore dollars ($119.6 million) for a controlling stake in six malls in China with Wal-Mart outlets. "With these acquisitions, and with more acquisitions in the pipeline, we will establish and enlarge CapitaLand's retail footprint in China," the chief executive, Liew Mun Leong, above, said in the statement.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Diplomatic Deadlock With Europeans Over
description: A thaw in the frosty relations between Europe and Cuba gathered speed after Cuba reopened official contacts with the embassies of eight European nations on Monday, including France, Britain and Germany, Reuters reported. Relations have been tense since the European Union began pressing Cuba to free dissidents jailed in March 2003. Last year the European embassies began inviting opponents of the government of Fidel Castro to their diplomatic cocktail parties, and Cuba cut off relations with them. Spain, which has extensive investments in Cuba, worked to broker a truce between Mr. Castro and European leaders. President Castro released 14 of the 75 jailed dissidents, and a European Union panel recommended this month that the practice of inviting dissidents to parties be dropped in favor of more discreet contacts. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

Arts, Briefly; Relativity in Dance
description: Roll over, Niels Bohr. A leading British contemporary dance company has been commissioned to create an interpretive dance based on theories of space and time by Einstein, below. "Constant Speed," by the Rambert Dance Company will set E = mc2 and Einstein's investigations into Brownian motion -- the constant, random movements of tiny particles -- to the movement of dancers. Commissioned by the Institute of Physics, an international professional body of scientists, the work is to have its premiere in May at Sadler's Wells in London, and will mark 100 years since Einstein, at age 26, began to publish his seminal research papers. The piece will be the first work that Mark Baldwin, Ballet Rambert's director since 2002, has created for his company. The work is to be accompanied with music by Franz Lehar ("The Merry Widow"). title: COOPER COMPANIES GETS CLEARANCE TO BUY OCULAR SCIENCES
description: The Cooper Companies won antitrust clearance to complete its $1.2 billion purchase of Ocular Sciences. The acquisition would make Cooper the world's third-biggest maker of contact lenses and enable it to compete with Johnson & Johnson, the world's largest maker, and Ciba Vision, a Novartis unit that is the second-largest maker. Shareholders of Cooper and Ocular approved the takeover on Nov. 16.

title: ATHEROGENICS SAYS COMPANY IS UNDER INVESTIGATION
description: AtheroGenics says it is the subject of informal inquiries by regulators into reports of a study of the company's heart drug and of trading in the company's shares. The Securities and Exchange Commission and NASD are investigating disclosures about the results of a trial of the medicine's effect on plaque in diseased arteries, AtheroGenics said in a filing. The company reported "positive interim" results on Sept. 27, but final test results released on Nov. 22 showed that the drug was less effective at reducing plaque than the September analysis suggested. The shares rose 64 percent on the first announcement. AtheroGenics, which is based in Alpharetta, Ga., is cooperating with the requests for documents and other information, the filing with the commission said.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Three-Hour Gunbattle
description: As many as 400 Maoist rebels fought a fierce three-hour battle with government forces in western Nepal, officials at the Nepal Army's western division headquarters said. The officials contended that more than 150 rebels were killed in the clash and 100 others wounded. The gunfight took place near Musrai, west of the capital, Katmandu. There was no comment from the Maoists, and it was not possible to verify the casualty numbers. CNN, Reuters and other news agencies said that the bodies of 30 rebels had been recovered. Both the government and the rebels often overstate enemy casualties while underreporting their own losses. P.J. Anthony (NYT)

NBC came in second among the also-rans on the strength of a special episode of "Dateline" at 10 p.m., which featured an interview with Amber Frey, an ex-girlfriend of Scott Peterson, who was convicted of murdering his wife and her fetus. Its audience of 15.9 million made that "Dateline" the most-watched episode of the newsmagazine in nearly two years. And the series premiere of NBC's sitcom "Committed," which was in the slot usually occupied by "Scrubs," performed much better than that hospital comedy has this season. But the second half of CBS's hourlong "Amazing Race" bumped "Committed" to third place. description: Occidental Petroleum said that it had closed its vinyl resins factory in Pottstown, Pa., effective immediately. The closing reduced pretax profit in the fourth quarter by about $53 million. A write-off of production facilities that used mercury cell technology cut pretax profit by an additional $12 million, the company said. The unprofitable vinyl resins business employed 200 people and represented about 2.5 percent of Occidental's sales of chemicals, said Larry Meriage, a company spokesman. The chemicals unit, which accounts for about one-third of Occidental's total sales, more than doubled its profit in the third quarter, to $137 million. Occidental said it also would report pretax costs of about $76 million in the fourth quarter to increase its environmental remediation reserves, provide for litigation and raise self-insurance reserves.

title: Homeland Security Goes Begging
description: Congress has a critical role in protecting the nation from terrorists by exercising careful scrutiny of homeland security programs. But so far, the House and Senate have been contributing to the problem rather than the solutions, distracting antiterrorism efforts by forcing officials to report to dozens of competing, power-hungry committees. The independent 9/11 commission cried out for an end to this "dysfunctional" system. Its solution was clean and obvious: create a single streamlined homeland security committee in each house, with both budget power and responsibility for oversight. Yet no national priority has been more shamefully subject to evasion by a truculent Congress ensconced in the traditions of turf battles.

Arts, Briefly; MTV's 'Real World' Goes On and On
description: Take heed, camera-ready young people who like heart-to-heart conversations and binge drinking: MTV has renewed "The Real World" for five more seasons. MTV and the show's creators, Bunim/Murray Productions, said yesterday that the groundbreaking reality show -- in which seven young strangers are filmed living together, flirting and fighting -- would be broadcast through 2008, for a total of 20 seasons over 16 years. The current season of "The Real World," its 15th, takes place in Philadelphia, and is ad-supported cable's No. 1 show in its time period (Tuesday nights at 10) in the 12-to-34 demographic that MTV covets. "Every four or five years, we have a brand-new audience that grows into the show," said Jon Murray, a creator of the show and its executive producer. As for what new ground "The Real World" can cover, Mr. Murray said: "I'm confident in the format of the show. It's almost like a ship that can't sink." MTV also picked up two more seasons of "The Real World/Road Rules Challenge," a spinoff of "The Real World" and its sister show, "Road Rules." KATE AURTHUR

description: A federal judge dismissed a $120 million suit against the F.B.I. by two former owners of a South Boston liquor store who said a gangster and informer, James Bulger, had extorted the business with the knowledge of his handler at the bureau. The plaintiffs, Stephen Rakes and his former wife, Julie Dammers, said they were forced to sell the store at gunpoint in 1984 to Mr. Bulger, who turned it into his gang's headquarters. The owners said a former agent in the bureau, John J. Connolly Jr., had been aware of the extortion but was more concerned with protecting Mr. Bulger. Chief Judge William G. Young of Federal District Court in Boston said he dismissed the suit because the claim was not made until 2001, two years after the bureau's troubled relationship with Mr. Bulger became public. Mr. Bulger has been a fugitive since 1995. Fox Butterfield (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Rehnquist Returning To Limited Work
description: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, under treatment for thyroid cancer, has returned to limited work at the Supreme Court. The court's public information officer, Kathleen Arberg, said the chief justice had been working from home and at the court since the week of Dec. 20. There was no explanation why Chief Justice Rehnquist's return to his chambers, from which he had been absent since surgery in late October, was not reported earlier. The court, in recess since Dec. 13, will resume hearing arguments on Monday. Ms. Arberg said she did not know whether the chief justice would be on the bench then or whether he would attend the regular closed-door conference on Friday morning. Last month, both the court and the White House announced that Chief Justice Rehnquist planned to administer the oath of office to President Bush at the inauguration on Jan. 20. Linda Greenhouse (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Yanukovich's Resignation Accepted
description: President Leonid D. Kuchma accepted the resignation of Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich, his former protg and the evident loser of the presidential election last month. Mr. Yanukovich, who trails by more than 2.2 million votes in the completed but uncertified tally of the Dec. 26 election, announced his intention to resign on Friday. He has said he will continue to dispute the legitimacy of his opponent and the presumptive president-elect, Viktor A. Yushchenko, in Supreme Court complaints. The court said it had received a portion of his complaint, and could begin hearing it this week, according to news agency reports. Mr. Yanukovich was the nominal winner of a Nov. 21 presidential election, which was overturned by the court because of widespread fraud. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

description: Malcolm Gladwell, whose best seller "The Tipping Point" (2000) analyzed the means by which fads and ideas propagate, has written a similarly anecdotal account of how split-second decisions are made. In "Blink," he finds scientists who break down the ostensibly simple processes of perception into quantifiable elements. He finds 90 different attributes ascribed to the Oreo cookie, and an extra $789 a year in salary for every extra inch of a tall person's height. He determines that people exposed to the words "wrinkle," "bingo" and "Florida" can be made to feel old in a hurry.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Rambus Shares Rise After Judge's Ruling
description: Shares of Rambus, a designer of high-speed memory chips, rose as much as 6.1 percent yesterday after a federal judge said the company could pursue patent-infringement claims against Hynix Semiconductor. Late Monday, Judge Ronald M. Whyte in San Jose, Calif., rejected Hynix's request for pretrial rulings saying the company did not infringe patents owned by Rambus. Rambus, whose designs increase the speed and efficiency of memory devices in computers, claims its patents cover aspects of all memory chips made in the $16.7 billion industry. Hynix is among the memory-chip makers contesting the patents. Rambus shares rose 58 cents to $22.06, and earlier rose to $22.78.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLER, PETER
description: KELLER--Peter. Age 87, of New Rochelle, New York. Devoted husband of Norma for 59 years, beloved father of Lisa and Nina, father-in-law of Saky Yakas and Richard Adago, grandfather of Benjamin Yakas and Perry and Naomi Adago. Pete, as everyone called him, spent 56 years at the Wall Street Journal, where he started in 1945 in the composing room and rose to national news editor during an illustrious career. For more than 25 years he served as night news editor, creating one of the highest editing standards in the nation. He trained several generations of reporters and editors, who called him the "living legend" of the Journal. After a formal retirement he returned to The Journal as a consultant and editor. During WWII he served as a warrant officer in the Fifth Army in North Africa and Italy, and received a Bronze Star for meritorious service. A voracious reader of history and literature, he imbued his two daughters with his love of learning, as he dedicated his life to them. His humor, intelligence, patience, and moral compass are irreplaceable. Funeral Service will be held Friday, January 7 at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 12 Noon, interment at Sharon Gardens to follow. The family will receive visitors at home afterwards. Contributions can be made to the Peter Keller Journalism Scholarship Fund at Purchase College, 735 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase, NY 10577. For information George T. Davis Funeral Home, 914-632-0324

Inside TV is to begin sales in the second quarter, and Mr. LeGrice said that a circulation of one million within a year or so "would be nice." TV Guide, with sales of about nine million a week, has been losing subscribers, advertisers and sales amid competition with celebrity magazines such as People, US Weekly and In Touch. Gemstar, based in Hollywood, has not reported an annual profit in five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAPOLARELLO, GRACE AUDITORE
description: CAPOLARELLO--Grace Auditore, passed away on Monday evening, January 3, 2005. at the age of 84. The wake will be held on Friday, January 7, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at the corner of E. 81st St. from 4-7:30pm. She'll be laid to rest beside her husband Carmelo, and her son Dominick at 1:30pm on Saturday, January 8th at Pinelawn Memorial Park. Grace was born on December 11, 1920 in the Cobble Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn, NY. She graduated from P.S. 27 Elementary School in 1936 and Brooklyn High School of Women's Garment Trades in 1940. Her parents, Santo (1873-1942) and Josephine (Interdanato 1887-1957) Auditore came to America from the Province of Messina, Italy in 1909 on the ship Santa Anna-Frabe via Ellis Island. Grace married Carmelo Capolarello (1917-1993), also from the Province of Messina, on July 15, 1950 in Girdini, Italy. Together they had three children, Dominick (1952-2004), Rita and Joe, all who were born in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Grace is survived by her sisters, Annette Torres and Angelina Arena, and her son and daughter, Joe R. and Rita J. Capolarello. They will remember her as a loving mother who showed courage throughout her life until her last moments. In memory of their mother, a memorial has been created for Grace Auditore Capolarello with the Southern Poverty Law Center, www.splcenter.org www.tolerance.org and Bank Street Law Office, Legal Services for Older New Yorkers in Need BankStreetLaw@aol.com both not-for-profit. You may send contributions to Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Ave., Montgomery, AL 36104, and Bank Street Law Office, 59 Bank St., 5th Flr, NY NY 10014

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Blogging Start-Ups Join Forces
description: Six Apart, the maker of Movable Type, software for publishing Web logs, said last night that it had acquired Danga Interactive, which operates the popular blogging site LiveJournal.com. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Six Apart said the deal would make it the largest independent company in the business of providing services and software to bloggers, with a combined base of more than 6.5 million users. It said LiveJournal, whose users are largely in their teens and 20's, would continue to operate as a separate division. Six Apart's software and its TypePad blog hosting service have attracted an older crowd, including many of the Web's most popular bloggers. Six Apart's main competitor is Google, which bought a service called Blogger two years ago. Last month Microsoft introduced its own blogging service, MSN Spaces. David F. Gallagher (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Kodak Introduces Wireless Camera
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, which is shifting to digital photography as film sales decline, introduced yesterday what it said was the first digital camera able to send high-resolution images without connecting to a computer. The EasyShare-One camera, which allows users to share pictures online or by e-mail, will be featured at the Consumer Electronics Show, opening today in Las Vegas, said Kodak, based in Rochester. The camera will go on sale in June for $599. It has a 4-megapixel sensor and a 3x optical zoom lens -- the most popular configuration among consumers, according to Kodak. It also has 256 megabytes of internal memory, compared with 16 to 32 megabytes in current EasyShare models. Users can transmit images through a proprietary wireless card that connects through a hub, wireless router or cellphone.

title: Arts, Briefly; British Book Honors
description: The list of five category winners has been announced for the 2004 Whitbread Book Awards, one of the top literary prizes in Britain. Of the five, one will be chosen for the Whitbread Book of the Year on Jan. 25, to be decided by a panel that includes writers, journalists, broadcasters and politicians, as well as the actor Hugh Grant. Andrea Levy won the novel award for "Small Island"; Susan Fletcher won the first-novel award for "Eve Green"; the biography prize went to John Guy for "My Heart Is My Own: The Life of Mary Queen of Scots"; Michael Symmons Roberts won the poetry award for "Corpus"; and "Not the End of the World" by Geraldine McCaughrean won the children's book prize. Each winner will receive 5,000 (about $9,400), and the Book of the Year prize is worth an additional 25,000 (about $47,000). The winners were chosen from 450 books by British and Irish writers. The public may vote for a winner and view the poll at www.whitbreadbookawards.co.uk, though that race will not affect the judges' decision. PAM KENT

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Gambling Concern Cuts Forecast
description: The British casino operator Stanley Leisure cut its annual profit forecast because of unfavorable sports results and unpaid gaming debts. Pretax profit, excluding one-time items and good will for the year through May 1, would be "broadly in line" with the previous period's 41.8 million ($78 million), said Noemie de Andia, a company spokeswoman. Analysts had expected a profit of 52 million. Results of horse races and European soccer games in the six weeks starting Nov. 1 crimped earnings, Stanley Leisure said. The company was also uncertain if it could collect unpaid debts from losing casino players by the end of the fiscal year, Ms. de Andia said.

title: Arts, Briefly; Zeffirelli Criticizes La Scala
description: Less than a month after the renovated La Scala opera house in Milan opened to rave reviews, the director Franco Zeffirelli has denounced its inaugural season as uninspired mediocrity. "After all the fuss and exultation, La Scala has come up with a program that is truly beneath expectations," Mr. Zeffirelli wrote to the newspaper Corriere della Sera, which published his letter on Wednesday. Mr. Zeffirelli, below, said that instead of competing for the world's top talent, La Scala had settled on minor conductors. He conceded that some famous names, like Zubin Mehta, would lead orchestras during the concert season, but insisted that La Scala was primarily an opera house and that the absence of his preferred conductors "risks becoming utterly absurd and developing into a scandal of truly international proportions because La Scala belongs to the whole world." JASON HOROWITZ

Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLER, DEANE G.
description: KELLER--Deane G. (64), of Marlborough, CT died suddenly on January 4, 2005. He was the son of Deane and Katherine Hall Keller. He earned a B.A. from Yale University, his M.A. from St. Joseph College in West Hartford, CT and studied in Florence, Italy. Deane was a professor at the Lyme Academy College of Fine Arts in Old Lyme, CT for 25 years. He was awarded the Charlotte Colby Danly Jackson Endowment for the Deane G. Keller Chair in Classical Drawing and Figurative Art at Lyme Academy College. Deane also taught at the New York Academy of Art, Graduate School of Figurative Art in New York City, and the Art Students League of New York. Deane's work is housed in several permanent collections and was widely exhibited in the northeast and Italy. Deane authored two books, "Figure Drawing in the Academy Tradition 1890-1998" and the "Draftsman's Handbook: A Resource and Study Guide for Drawing from Life" which he also illustrated. Deane is survived by his wife of 36 years, Dorothy Bosch Keller, and a brother, William. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Deane G. Keller Scholarship Fund at Lyme Academy College of Fine Art, 84 Lyme St., Old Lyme, CT 06371 or the Deane G. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCARTY, MACLYN
description: McCARTY -- Maclyn. The Rockefeller University community mourns with deep sadness the loss of our beloved colleague and friend, Maclyn McCarty, an eminent physician - scientist who served the university with enormous distinction for sixtythree years. A member of the U.S. National Academy of Sciences and the Institute of Medicine, and recipient of the 1994 Albert Lasker Award for Special Achievement in Medical Science, Dr. McCarty was a microbiologist best known for his seminal contributions to DNA research. In the 1940's, in association with Oswald Avery and Colin MacLeod, Dr. McCarty determined that genes are made of DNA, a landmark discovery that opened the gateway to the modern era of molecular biology and molecular medicine. From 1946 to 1981, as head of the Laboratory of Bacteriology and Immunology, he pioneered investigations of streptococcal infections and their complications including rheumatic fever. In 1960, he accepted appointment as physician-in-chief of The Rockefeller Hospital and for fourteen years fostered clinical research and clinical care on our campus. From 1965 to 1978, he also served the university as vice president. Dr. McCarty held one of the university's John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Professorships. Throughout his distinguished career, he was a forceful and articulate spokesperson for the importance of patient-based research and the need for medically trained investigators in biomedical inquiry. With uncommon insight and dedication, he was an exemplary model for many generations of investigators. His greatness as a scientist was matched by a wonderful humanity. A warm, wise and caring friend to many, he will be profoundly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved Marj, a cherished member of our community, and to his sons and daughter. Paul Nurse President David Rockefeller Honorary Chairman Russell Carson Vice Chairman Joshua Lederberg, Frederick Seitz, and Torsten Wiesel, Presidents Emeriti

title: Arts, Briefly; Cancellations in St. Louis

On Monday its musicians rejected management's contract offer, saying the wages were too low; orchestra officials said that they could not afford to pay more. The orchestra's music director-designate, David Robertson, was to have conducted this weekend's program, titled "Discoveries" and presenting the Dvorak Piano Concerto, with Orli Shaham as soloist, and Bartok's "Wooden Prince." A spokesman said that no new negotiating sessions had been scheduled but that for the moment, next weekend's performances were still on the books. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: CT Scan May Solve Tut Mystery
description: Modern medical technology has been brought to bear in the unsolved mystery of King Tut's death. Was it murder that killed Egypt's young pharaoh 3,000 years ago? At Luxor on Wednesday, researchers removed the king's mummy from its tomb and placed it in a CT scan for the first three-dimensional images of its skull and other bones. When simpler X-rays were taken 36 years ago, bone fragments were detected inside Tut's skull. This prompted speculation that the pharaoh, who died at 17, had been murdered, probably by a blow to the head. Other evidence pointed to death by illness. Dr. Zahi Hawass, Egypt's chief archaeologist, said that results of the CT scan would be announced later his month in Cairo. John Noble Wilford (NYT)

title: The Dead Talk, and There's Plenty of Static

Have you seen "Sideways" yet? How about "Million Dollar Baby"? Neither title promises transcendence, but both provide an evening of excellent entertainment. Certainly both are far superior to what generally slinks into theaters this unhappy month, including "White Noise," a laugh-laced cheap thrill that has nothing to do with the superb Don DeLillo novel of the same title.

title: The Listings; JAPAN SOCIETY'S ANNUAL JAPANESE CONTEMPORARY DANCE SHOWCASE
description: Now in its eighth year, Japan Society's Annual Japanese Contemporary Dance Showcase is certainly a trip, and not necessarily to that far-off land. The choreography and performers are always surprising and sometimes stir the mind and touch the heart. Most of all, however, they are filled with outrageous humor, more exotic in its way than any ancient Japanese classical dance form. Two of the companies in this year's lineup sound extra-fascinating. One is the all-female, Butoh-inspired SENNICHIMAE Blue Sky Dance Club. Based in Osaka and three years old, the troupe performs at shrines, schools and other alternative spaces. Here, in "Natsu no Utsuwa" ("Container of Summer"), it will portray the living welcoming deceased ancestors for several days before sending them home again. The second is BATIK, above, which will be seen in its American debut. Founded in 2002 by Ikuyo Kuroda, a member of the Kim Otoh + The Glorious Future company, BATIK will perform "Shoku" ("Touch"), a dance that promises a raw portrayal of the frustration and fury unique to Japanese adult women. The programs will also feature performing by Monochrome Circus, Kaiji Moriyama and Noism05. (Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, Turtle Bay, (212) 752-3015. Tickets: $25.) JENNIFER DUNNING

description: ConAgra Foods said yesterday that it was in talks with federal regulators to settle an investigation of fake sales and irregular accounting at its farm-products unit during the 1990's. Settlement payments will be $25 million to $45 million, though the amount may be larger, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. ConAgra set aside $25 million for settlement payments in its fiscal fourth quarter. The company disclosed an S.E.C. inquiry of improper accounting at its United Agri Products unit in 2001, leading to the restatement of results for 1997, 1998, 1999 and 2000. title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: 2 Bird-Flu Deaths Reported
description: The authorities reported two fatal human cases of avian influenza to the World Health Organization, in 6- and 9-year-old boys. They brought the total number of deaths from the disease in Vietnam to 22 in the past year. Seven Vietnamese have survived the infection during that time, including a 16-year-old girl reported ill last month who remains in critical condition. The three new cases were in southern provinces, where the disease has infected thousands of birds. A common risk factor in those cases has not been found, and international health officials have raised concern because they occurred at the start of cooler weather, when the more common human influenza strains usually strike. Epidemiologists have for months expressed fears that avian and human strains could swap genes to create a new influenza virus that could rapidly spread through the world. Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

Paid Notice: Deaths   TILNEY, ROBERT W., JR., M.D.
description: TILNEY--Robert W., Jr., M.D. 89, died peacefully at home in Far Hills, NJ on January 6, 2005. Dr. Tilney practiced general and specialized in head and neck surgery at Morristown Memorial Hospital for 40 years. He was a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons serving as the treasurer and governor of the NJ Chapter. He was a member of the Head and Neck Society and was associate professor of Surgery at Rutgers. Dr. Tilney worked on the SS Hope in Guinea and in Sri Lanka and later taught surgery in a mission hospital in Chiang Mai, Thailand. He served on the Board of Trustees of the Gill School and the Visiting Nurse Association of Somerset Hills. Dr. Tilney was born in Atlanta, GA 1915. He graduated from Groton School, Harvard University (1939) and University of Pennsylvania Medical School (1943). He trained at the Peter Bent Brigham in Boston, and at Roosevelt and Memorial Hospitals in NY. During WWII he served in the US Navy in the Pacific. In 1946 he married the late Anne Cutler Williams who predeceased him in 1977. He is survived by his second wife, Joan Paton Tilney; children Robert W. Tilney, III, David W. Tilney, Susanne G. TilneyPeyton, and Anne Tilney Brune; step-children Bernard Peyton, Linda Peyton Hancock, Pamela Peyton Post, Robert H.P. Olney and Katrina Olney; eight grandchildren, four step-grandchildren, and one great grandchild; and brothers Nicholas L. Tilney, Lewis G. Tilney, and Philip V. R. Tilney. A memorial service will be held later in the year. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Visiting Nurse Association of Somerset Hills, 12 Olcott Ave., Bernardsville, NJ 07924 or St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Main St., Gladstone, NJ 07934.

Six figures inhabit a mysteriously changeable space, awkwardly at ease and not yielding the unfathomable reserves of their secrets. But at the same time, there is a great simplicity to the five men and one woman, all nude without self-consciousness, and to their simple, homemade-looking moves. The straight-up jumps, sometimes up to shoulder sits, are the action of small boys at play.

description: TUCKED high in an amphitheater of volcanic rock in the impossibly picturesque San Juan Mountains of Colorado, Telluride is a skier's Shangri-la. The snow is feather-light, the skies are turquoise, and the closest Wal-Mart is 65 miles away. With a series of elevator-shaft steeps spilling down the front side of the mountain, it has long been known as an expert's playground. In 2002, the resort's image was softened with the 733-acre expansion into Prospect Bowl, which added a dose of intermediate and beginner terrain. But thrill seekers continue to get their adrenaline fix. This season Telluride is offering guided hike-to skiing down Mountain Quail, an 1,100-foot chute below the imposing crags of Palmyra Peak. When you're not turning knee cartilage to Jell-O on the igloo-size bumps of Kant-Mak-M, you can cruise the 19th-century gold-mining town of Telluride. A free gondola links the historic town with the newer Mountain Village at 9,540 feet. Pushing the development of luxury hotels and multimillion-dollar log cabins uphill has enabled the town to remain relatively unchanged since miners came here to drink, gamble and liquidate their $3-a-day paychecks in Popcorn Alley, the red-light district, named for the continuous opening and closing of doors. description: The Supreme Court turned down the first appeal filed by Viktor F. Yanukovich, the presumed loser of the Dec. 26 repeat presidential race, who is seeking to have the results overturned. The roll call of performers is long and winding: Whoopi Goldberg, Ethyl Eicheberger, Eric Bogosian, Peggy Shaw and Lois Weaver, Tim Miller, Karen Finley, Holly Hughes, Carmelita Tropicana, Deb Margolin, Basil Twist, Will Power and Danny Hoch. Mr. Russell, above, resigned last year amid general mourning. This weekend he reappears at the thriving Brooklyn arts center St. Ann's Warehouse, where he is curator of a four-day mini-festival and symposium called "Under the Radar." His focus is theater in the broadest sense, from the solo performances of Marc Bamuthi Joseph and Cynthia Hopkins to the tight ensemble work of the Civilians and the sweep of Big Dance Theater. Audiences can see a tribute to Mexico's comic master Cantiflas (performed by Herbert Siguenza) and a five-hour adaptation of "The Great Gatsby" ("Gatz"), performed by the daring company Elevator Repair Service. Music will be provided by Ethel, a trio of artfully inventive violinists. Happily, international work will not be neglected. The Foundry Theater brings us "K.I. From Crime," a fantasia on scenes from "Crime and Punishment," staged by one of Russia's greatest directors, Kama Ginkas, and starring one of its greatest actors, Oksana Mysina. ("Under the Radar" runs from tonight to Monday at St. Ann's Warehouse, 38 Water Street, DUMBO, Brooklyn; DUMBO Stable, 16 Main Street, at Water Street; the Performing Garage, 33 Wooster Street, SoHo; and the Freight Entrance Theater, 208 West 37th Street, Manhattan. Information: (718) 254-8779.) MARGO JEFFERSON

title: The Listings; 'A COLLECTOR'S CABINET OF CURIOSITIES: OBJECTS FOR A WUNDERKAMMER FROM 16TH TO 19TH CENTURY'
description: If the Metropolitan Museum of Art's "Princely Splendor: The Dresden Court: 1580-1620" made you lust for a wunderkammer -- wonder cabinet -- to call your own, or simply desire a deeper familiarity with the subject, proceed forthwith to the Peter Freeman Gallery in SoHo. There, on the occasion of the Met's lavish survey of natural and man-made booty accumulated by successive electors of Saxony, Georg Laue, a dealer and amber expert from Munich, has mounted a dense display of more than 100 small, exquisite wunderkammer objects dating from the 16th to the 19th century. The show feels like a somewhat oppressive living room, thanks to the intimate size of the gallery and the relative absence of Plexiglas and the use of small exquisitely crafted cabinets for some displays. Nearly everything on view is a kind of marvel, usually one that combines an exotic and beautiful natural material with a triumph of human skill. This applies to several chalices and tankards and one small monument carved from serpentine or rock crystal, a silver-mounted emu egg and a small box made of blocks of amber, as well as a beautiful Asmat ancestor skull, decorated with seeds, feathers and shell; three bronzes of tiny lizards cast from life; and a model boat from the Spice Islands (Indonesia) made entirely of dried cloves. Also arresting are several tiny carved ivories of double-sided heads in which living faces alternate in different ways with vermin-infested skulls. These objects, one of which is a cane handle, above, manifest a theme that haunts the wunderkammer: vanitas, or the fleeting nature of life and the inevitability of death, against which all collecting is an unusually materialistic form of resistance. (Peter Freeman Inc., 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 966-5154, through Jan. 29; free.) ROBERTA SMITH

The Listings; GEORGE CLINTON AND THE P-FUNK ALL-STARS/TV ON THE RADIO
description: Through countless samples and imitations, hip-hop has made George Clinton's riffs familiar again, but great bass lines are only the beginning when he leads his P-Funk All-Stars. It's a big, motley band; through the years, it has been costumed in everything from glitter to denim to diapers. Under Mr. Clinton's watchful direction, the band treats funk as long, molten jams, preaching subversion through pleasure and togetherness without uniformity. In the course of a set, he's likely to get to hits like "Atomic Dog" and "Flash Light," but Mr. Clinton's funk is both manifesto and musical marvel. It keeps up with hip-hop, but Mr. Clinton, above, has been making music since his Parliaments were a doo-wop group in the 1950's, and P-Funk's vamps take in gospel and be-bop, salsa and soul, doo-wop and heavy metal. Tight and loose at the same time, Mr. Clinton and the P-Funk All-Stars insist by example that sweaty, unpredictable humanity is more fun than any machine. TV on the Radio puts its own history of rock -- especially New York rock -- into a pressure cooker of speed-strummed tremolo guitars and implacable mechanical drumbeats. Its songs incorporate noise-guitar squalls, droney Minimalism and something like a cappella doo-wop, while its vocals stay high and gentle, almost wistful. On its album, "Desperate Youth, Blood Thirsty Babes" (Touch and Go) -- one of the best albums released in 2004 -- the lyrics contemplate desolation and fear, collapsed romance and crumbling dreams: in "Ambulance," the band sings, "I will be your one more time if you will be my one last chance." Frenzy and stasis combine in songs that make introspection an adventure. (Tonight at 7:30, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100. Tickets are $20 to $45.) JON PARELES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEGAL, JOHN B.
description: SEGAL--John B., of Larchmont, NY, and Westport, MA, beloved husband for 50 years of Janet Z. Segal, Chief Operating Officer of Four Winds Hospital, Katonah, NY, died on January 6, 2005 of melanoma. He was 76 years old. He was a cherished father, adored uncle, beloved grandfather, and a joyful, quick-witted and dynamic spirit among his friends and business colleagues. An innovator in the cultivation of new hop varieties, he successfully propagated the Cascade hop, among others, which became a mainstay of the brewing industry. He was an active voice for the use of American-grown hops in beer production. He owned a ranch in Grandview, WA, the base of his agricultural operations and brokered the sale of hops, as his father had done since the repeal of Prohibition. He also propagated poplar trees for environmental remediation and at the time of his death, was exploring the medical uses of hops. Born in NY and raised in Great Neck, he attended Westtown School in Westtown, PA and Bard College in Annandale, NY. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his brother, actor, George Segal, and his children and their spouses, John and Robyn Segal of Scarsdale, NY, Jeanne Segal and Tom Trainer of Bethesda, MD, Joanne Fryer (and the late Gary Fryer), also of Larchmont, and special nephew and niece, Nicholas Segal, Polly Segal, and the lights of his life, nine grandchildren, Adam Segal, William Segal, Matthew Fryer, Jenny Fryer, Rebecca Fryer, Eliza Trainer, Ben Trainer, Annie Segal and Teddy Segal. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Melanoma Immuno Fund, c/o Dr. Jed Wolchock, Memorial Sloan Kettering, 1275 York Ave., NY NY 10021, or Westport River Watershed Alliance (WRWA), PO Box 3427, Westport, MA 02790. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, January 9th, at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel", 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC.

Paid Notice: Deaths   DREZNICK, RACHELLE
description: DREZNICK -- Rachelle. On January 6, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Henry Dreznick. Beloved mother of Dr. Jeffrey Dreznick, Dr. Elliott Dreznick and Lisa Dreznick Waller, Esq. Beloved motherin-law of Carol Fisher Dreznick, Esq. and Dr. Scott Waller. Beloved bubbe of Randa, Courtney, Stephen and Benjamin. Beloved sister of Mary Tolmatch, Leah Fixman, and the late Reva Nachfolger Kurtzman. A dedicated, devoted and beloved educator, she enlightened many students' minds and remembered not only all her students but where they even sat. Rachelle attended McGill University on a scholarship despite religious quotas, but had to leave after her freshman year to care for her terminally-ill father. She then graduated from Sir George Williams University in Montreal and obtained her Master's from Brooklyn College. Vibrant, vivacious, and so full of life, she waged a valiant battle against an aggressive, relentless illness. Poet laureate and president of her synagogue's Sisterhood for the past 14 years, Rachelle was also a wonderful friend, aunt and nurturer. Mom, you were a selfless, wonderful and caring individual who, like Dad, lived life for your family. We will miss your effervescence, charm and wit and we'll miss you to no end. We hope you take our love for you with you and we hope you are at peace. There will never be a day when we don't think about you. Our love forever, your family. Services will be held Sunday, January 9, at 1:15PM at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows. For shiva information call 646-831-7807

Paid Notice: Deaths   WALLER, HERBERT
description: WALLER--Herbert, on January 6, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Sandie Waller. Beloved father of Dr. Scott Waller, Keith Waller, and Donna Waller-Maggio. Beloved father-in-law of Lisa DreznickWaller, Esq., Robin WallachWaller, and Jerry Maggio. Beloved Papa to Courtney and Benjamin, and Poppy to Brittany and Brooke. Beloved brother of Seth Waller, Esq. An outstanding athlete, he was in the Brooklyn Dodger's farm system at a time when players played for the love of the game. At his parents' request for him to pursue higher education, he gave up his dream of a career in professional baseball to graduate from CCNY where he was point guard for Nat Holman's powerhouse basketball team. A respected business executive in the cosmetics industry throughout his life, he started his business career at Grey Advertising, subsequently moving on to a vice president position at Estee Lauder, and then to president of the cosmetics division of Sterling Drugs. Ironically, having built his career on his intellectual capabilities, he fell victim to severe Alzheimer's disease at a tragically young age. He will always be remembered for his sharp mind, keen business sense and ongoing love of sports. He will be sorely missed by all those who knew and loved him. title: Arts, Briefly; BBC Battles 'Springer' Backlash
description: The BBC will go ahead with its planned screening tonight of a filmed performance of the hit West End satirical musical "Jerry Springer: The Opera" despite more than 15,000 complaints. Based on the television talk show, the musical, which opened in 2003 at the National Theater before transferring to the West End, stars David Soul, left, and has scenes that Christian groups have criticized as blasphemous, as well as dancing Ku Klux Klansmen. It also has more than 8,000 obscenities, according to The Sun, the London tabloid owned by Rupert Murdoch. The BBC has made a more conservative estimate: 400. Mediawatch-uk, an independent organization devoted to issues of taste and decency in the media, has asked the BBC chairman to reconsider. The BBC responded by saying, "As a public service broadcaster, it is the BBC's role to broadcast a range of programs that will appeal to all audiences -- with very differing tastes and interests -- present in the U.K. today." The National Secular Society has urged the network not to give in to "religious bullies." PAM KENT

title: Arts, Briefly; A Modernist Trove
description: The Georgia O'Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe, N.M., announced this week that it had received a $100,000 grant from the Henry Luce Foundation to catalog the archive it received in 2003 from William I. Homer, a leading scholar of American modern art and photography. The archive includes extensive correspondence pertaining to the research that Professor Homer conducted during his years as a teacher and scholar. It also contains interviews with American artists, including O'Keeffe, who died in 1986. The museum's research center opened in 2001 as part of its mission to help the public understand the modern movement in America, from the 1890's to the present. The grant will make it possible for the museum to house the archive and digitize it so that it will be available to other institutions on CD-ROM and the Internet. CAROL VOGEL

title: Arts, Briefly; Inviting Arts to Brooklyn
description: Nonprofit cultural groups have been invited to submit proposals for the Brooklyn Academy of Music's new cultural district in Downtown Brooklyn. The invitation was inspired by the search for cultural institutions for ground zero. "We thought it was an interesting way to cast an incredibly broad net," said Jeanne Lutfy, president of the BAM Local Development Corporation, which issued the request for expressions of interest. The proposals, due Feb. 7, will be evaluated by the BAM L.D.C., the New York City Economic Development Corporation and the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs. The development corporation is seeking ideas for the north part of the district, a 60,000-square-foot area. The Theater for a New Audience and the Brooklyn Public Library for the Visual and Performing Arts are to be on the south portion. The district's intent is to convert vacant parking lots and other underused property into affordable, desirable space for a variety of arts groups. The district is also to include arts education activities, mixed-income housing, restaurants, stores, underground parking and open public space. An information session on Wednesday drew 30 organizations, the development corporation said. ROBIN POGREBIN

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Indian Interest In Yukos
description: The largest oil and gas exploration company in India confirmed that it was interested in buying assets of the Russian oil company Yukos. The company, the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation, which is owned by the Indian government, said it had been in talks to buy Yukos oil assets like Yuganskneftegas, its largest production unit. Yuganskneftegas was recently auctioned for $9.35 billion to a shell company that was quickly bought by the Russian state oil company, Rosneft. The Indian company is willing to pay up to $2 billion for a 15 percent stake in Yuganskneftegas, its chairman, Subir Raha, said. He did not give details about who the company was talking to or what assets were up for purchase. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEGAL, JOHN B.
description: SEGAL--John B., of Larchmont, NY, and Westport, MA, beloved husband for 50 years of Janet Z. Segal, Chief Operating Officer of Four Winds Hospital, Katonah, NY, died on January 6, 2005 of melanoma. He was 76 years old. He was a cherished father, adored uncle, beloved grandfather, and a joyful, quick-witted and dynamic spirit among his friends and business colleagues. An innovator in the cultivation of new hop varieties, he successfully propagated the Cascade hop, among others, which became a mainstay of the brewing industry. He was an active voice for the use of American-grown hops in beer production. He owned a ranch in Grandview, WA, the base of his agricultural operations and brokered the sale of hops, as his father had done since the repeal of Prohibition. He also propagated poplar trees for environmental remediation and at the time of his death, was exploring the medical uses of hops. Born in NY and raised in Great Neck, he attended Westtown School in Westtown, PA and Bard College in Annandale, NY. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his brother, actor, George Segal, and his children and their spouses, John and Robyn Segal of Scarsdale, NY, Jeanne Segal and Tom Trainer of Bethesda, MD, Joanne Fryer (and the late Gary Fryer), also of Larchmont, and special nephew and niece, Nicholas Segal, Polly Segal, and the lights of his life, nine grandchildren, Adam Segal, William Segal, Matthew Fryer, Jenny Fryer, Rebecca Fryer, Eliza Trainer, Ben Trainer, Annie Segal and Teddy Segal. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Melanoma Immuno Fund, c/o Dr. Jed Wolchock, Memorial Sloan Kettering, 1275 York Ave., NY NY 10021, or Westport River Watershed Alliance (WRWA), PO Box 3427, Westport, MA 02790. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, January 9th, at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel", 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC.

title: ViewPoints: Less is more when business gives
Arts, Briefly; Surviving Sans 'Survivor'
description: CBS easily beat the other networks in Thursday's overnight Nielsen ratings. But the absence of "Survivor" at 8 p.m. produced some atypical results; the premiere of its replacement, "Wickedly Perfect" (the cast is pictured below), performed poorly. This new reality show is a battle in the arena of domestic arts, in which contestants vie for a book contract and a television development deal, essentially competing to be the next Martha Stewart. The show attracted only 9.76 million viewers, less than half of the audience drawn by an average "Survivor." Because of CBS's weakness at 8, NBC won the hour in total viewers, with "Joey" and "Committed," which made its debut on Tuesday. With the exception of the first hour of the finale of "The Apprentice," this was the network's first victory in that time period since the beginning of the season. And Fox's "O.C.," which had been losing steam in recent weeks, also perked up, getting its best numbers since its second episode. Only ABC's teenage show "Life as We Know It," new to 8 p.m., failed to benefit from the "Survivor"-less night: it came in fifth for the hour. KATE AURTHUR

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Auto Production Surges
description: Automobile production in Brazil surged 20.7 percent last year, to a record 2.2 million vehicles, fueled by a strong economic rebound at home and an aggressive campaign to increase sales in foreign markets, the country's automakers' association said. Domestic sales rose 10.5 percent in 2004, to 1.58 million vehicles, benefiting from a drop in interest rates early in the year and a flurry of year-end sales. In December alone, sales in Brazil shot up 28 percent, to 178,000 vehicles, even though automakers scaled back production by 8 percent from November, to 185,200 units. Exports, meanwhile, soared 51.8 percent last year, to $8.3 billion, surpassing forecasts by more than 10 percent. For 2005, the auto industry is forecasting a more modest increase in output, 5.4 percent, to 2.3 million vehicles, as Brazil's economy begins to cool. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Sisterhood for 'Big Brother'
description: Germaine Greer, the feminist, polemicist, academic, writer and broadcaster, has taken on the challenge living with seven other contestants on the third "Celebrity Big Brother," a reality show broadcast daily on Channel 4 in Britain. In "Big Brother," four men and four women share a specially designed house; they have no contact with the outside world until viewers vote them out after fellow housemates nominate them for dismissal. This edition of the show, which began Thursday, consists of highlights from the 24-hour-a-day filming of the group, who are required to perform challenging tasks, like running a physically demanding obstacle course. Ms. Greer, 65, above, is competing against actors, soap opera and pop stars, a model and broadcasters, the youngest being Kenzie, a 19-year-old member of the band Blazin' Squad. Ms. Greer, who admits that she is bossy -- "I'm supposed to be terrifying" -- said, "I've got to strike a blow for the old ladies." The last celebrity housemate standing will receive a prize of about $93,500, to be donated to a charity of his or her choice. Contestants are charged about a dollar for each vote for eviction; a portion of that sum also goes to charity. PAM KENT

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer Lowers Outlook
description: The British retailer Marks & Spencer said that its 2004 profit would fall short of analysts' estimates because of post-Christmas clearance sales. The chief executive, Stuart Rose, who is trying to increase sales to keep the chain from being taken over, said that profit for the year ending in March would be 600 million to 625 million before one-time items, versus estimates of 675 million ($1.27 billion). Mr. Rose joined Marks & Spencer in May to help the company fend off a takeover offer from the British billionaire Philip Green. Mr. Green withdrew his bid in July; under British takeover rules, he could make a new bid as of Jan. 14. Stock in the company, which is based in London, rose 3 percent after initially declining in response to the profit forecast. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Inside the List
description: THE NEOCON NOVEL: The best book-related feature in any of this planet's English-language newspapers is surely "The Digested Read," which appears in The Guardian of London. The premise of "The Digested Read" is pretty straightforward. Each week, The Guardian asks a writer to regurgitate the contents of a newly published book in 500 words or so, preferably in the style of its author. A few weeks ago, Michael Crichton's new novel, "State of Fear," was fed through The Guardian's microcompressor, and the results were predictably hilarious. (One bit of dialogue went like this: " 'Give me Morton's money,' yelled Drake. 'I can't,' replied Peter. 'His estate is in probate.' ") "State of Fear" seeks to debunk climatologists' dire predictions about global warming, and the book includes appendixes, a hefty bibliography and an author's note that bolster the book's arguments. The Guardian had even more fun with this material, capturing Crichton's tone this way: "I'm very, very clever and have read a lot and you're all stupid wishy-washy liberals." Is Crichton's book, as Steve Wasserman has claimed in The Los Angeles Times, "the first neocon novel"? Seems unlikely. Either way, "State of Fear" has certainly not been hurt by the controversy it has generated. The book is No. 3 on this week's hardcover fiction list. On ABC's "20/20," Crichton had to dodge John Stossel's attempts to kick up even more dust. "What's with the four wives?" Stossel asked the frequently divorced writer. To which Crichton replied: "Where I come from, in Hollywood, four wives is sort of like the average. . . . I'm halfway to Mickey Rooney."

Paid Notice: Deaths   SAKS, ALAN
description: SAKS--Alan. Alan Saks, businessman, social activist and advocate of urban Chicago, died January 4, 2005 at age 77. He is survived by his wife of fifty years, Esther Shava; daughters, Ruth, Beth (son-inlaw Scott Fithian), Jane (partner, Lynette Jackson), and Naomi; grandchildren, Sam and Sarah; sisters Sylvia Breeders and Mimi Cooper. Alan was President and CEO of Saxon Paint & Hardware, which was founded by his paternal grandmother in 1914. He developed the company to a 50-store chain across three states and in 1996 he sold off and closed the company. Alan and Saxon became known for pioneering the concept of the "do it yourself trend" in wallpaper, paint and home furnishings. He was a co-founder of the Business Executives Movement Against the War in Vietnam in the 60s. Their activism against the war earned Alan and Esther the distinction of being on Nixon's Enemies list. In the early 1970's he was a founding member of BPI (Business and Professional People for the Public Interest) and a past president and board member up until his death. He spent approximately 20 years on the board of Columbia College of Chicago, and served on the boards of the ACLU and most recently on the board of JCUA (Jewish Council on Urban Affairs). Alan grew up on the near west side of the city and always felt passionately about Chicago. As a child, he shared with his father a love and fascination with the diverse neighborhoods of the city. Consequently, as an astute businessperson and a social activist, he believed in the diversity, ethnicity and vitality of the city. He was committed to the communities beyond being a local retailer and participated in neighborhood-based initiatives, local public schools and chambers of commerce. At a time when there was rapid urban flight, he opened stores in neighborhoods which were being abandoned by the national chains, food stores, and banks. All of these neighborhood stores remained open until 1996. Alan was a lover of nature, jazz and a world traveler with his wife. He spent many weekends and holidays with his family at their beach house in the Indiana Dunes hiking, sailing, biking, swimming, and horseback riding. He was also an avid skier since 1965. His great energy, humor, generosity, enthusiasm for life and tenacity will be remembered and missed by many people. Please call Goldman Funeral Group at 847-478-1600 for information regarding visitation. Per his request, there will be a party to celebrate the life of Alan Saks scheduled in the near future, date and time to be announced. Call Goldman Funeral Group for information after January 10, 2005. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution in Alan's name to one of the three following organizations: 1. The Roger Baldwin Foundation of the ACLU of Illinois, 180 North Michigan Avenue, Suite 2300, Chicago, IL 60601-1287, 312-201-9740, attn: Colleen Connel, www.acluil.org; 2. BPI (Business and Professional People for the Public Interest), 25 East Washington Street, Suite 1515, Chicago, IL 60602, 312641-5570, attn: Hoy McConnell, 3. JCUA (Jewish Council on Urban Affairs), 618 South Michigan Avenue, Chicago, IL 60605. 312-663-0960, attn: Jane Ramsey.

title: No Picture Tells the Truth. The Best Do Better Than That.
description: TWO Mondays ago, the scale of the Indian Ocean catastrophe was just emerging from the incomplete earlier reports (from a Times article the day before: a tidal wave had "killed more than 150 people in Sri Lanka"). By the 4:30 Page 1 meeting, picture editors had examined more than 900 images of devastation to find the one that would stretch across five columns and nearly half the depth of Tuesday's front page. Into a million homes came a grieving mother crouched beside the lifeless bodies of tiny children, and perhaps more horrifying, three pairs of feet extending from beneath a white sheet in an upper corner, suggesting the presence beyond the frame of row upon awful row of the tsunami's pitiless toll.

title: On Mean Streets, Paved With Credit
description: MARTIN SCORSESE'S American Express commercial ("TriBeCa") is an elegy for New York, at once grave and stirring. It opens with Robert De Niro superimposed over -- almost seeming to emerge from -- the Manhattan skyline. The Empire State Building is visible, but this is not the Manhattan of Deco skyscrapers and affluence. It's the Manhattan of tenement buildings, ancient rooftop water towers and ethnic storefronts. It's the Manhattan of immigrants, whose elderly, accented voices murmur in the background: "I come from Ukrainia." . . . "I come from Palermo."

title: Corrections
description: A Residential Real Estate article in The Metro Section on May 24, 2002, about tax write-offs that result from easements -- homeowners' agreements to preserve the appearance of historic buildings -- misstated the size of such a deduction. It is up to 15 percent of the value of the house, not of the owner's income. The article also misstated the eligibility for the deduction. While the house may indeed be in a federal historic district, it may alternatively be listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The article also misstated the founding date of the National Architectural Trust, an organization that promotes the deductions. It was founded in 2001, not 1998. It also misspelled the surname of the general counsel of the National Trust for Historic Preservation. The counsel is Paul Edmondson, not Edmundson. The errors came to light as a result of recent reporting on the same subject for a story in the Real Estate section.

title: The Right to Information at a Condo
description: Q -- I own a condominium unit in Manhattan. I do not live in the apartment but rent it to tenants. The tenants' lease and application were approved by the board according to the building's rules. I recently learned that another unit owner in the building has threatened to sue the board and the condominium unless they agree to release all information and documentation regarding the leasing or sale of any units. Does the unit owner have a right to this information, which includes sensitive personal data, Social Security numbers, financial references and banking information? . . . Lisa Grossman, Manhattan.

Rosen compassionately as well as critically describes the transformation of her thinking to denying death itself.

title: Ban of Brothers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANDELA, MAKGATHO
description: MANDELA--Makgatho. The American Foundation for AIDS Research (amfAR) joins the Mandela family and the people of South Africa in mourning the passing of Makgatho Mandela, 54, who died of AIDS-related illness in Johannesburg on Thursday. Though theirs is an enormous loss, the Mandela family does not grieve in silence and they do not grieve alone. They join millions of South Africans who have lost loved ones to HIV/AIDS, many having suffered needlessly from the prejudice, scorn and misunderstanding that still shrouds HIV in mystery. More than five million women, men and children in South Africa are living with HIV infection. Millions more are affected every day by the stigma and discrimination that defeat the generosity of spirit and courage that have always characterized the tireless advocacy of Nelson Mandela. amfAR stands with him and all of those South Africans who look forward to a life free of fear and hatred. Kenneth Cole Chairman of the Board Mathilde Krim, Ph.D. Founding Chairman American Foundation for AIDS Research (amfAR)

title: The Week Ahead
description: A DEPOSIT ON CREDIBILITY -- The World Jewish Congress, the small but influential nonprofit, has won millions of dollars for victims from banks and companies that profited from the Holocaust. But the organization found itself on the other end of the microscope after it was learned that Attorney General Eliot Spitzer of New York had initiated an informal inquiry into a series of financial transactions made by its executives. This Monday and Tuesday, the organization's general assembly will meet in Brussels to consider changes in financial oversight designed to head off charges that money has gone unaccounted for. The outcome may determine whether the W.J.C. remains a watchdog or becomes one of the watched.

title: What Is War Good For? Art

Painted in 1529 for Duke William IV of Bavaria, it portrays Alexander the Great's defeat of the Persian Army in 333 B.C. Much admired for its gory detail, the painting was stolen by Napoleon to hang in the bathroom of his chateau.

title: WHY WE TRAVEL: BRETTON WOODS, N.H.
description: MOUNT WASHINGTON HOTEL, DEC. 27, 2004 -- Frank Healey, 47, of Hampton, N.H., left, with son Jack, 8, and daughter Charlotte, 10. We go to the Mount Washington Hotel every year. The kids' favorite part, even though they ski for most of the day, is to go outside in the frigid temperatures to the heated pool and then roll in the snow. They just get the biggest kick out of swimming outside in the winter. It was 4 degrees out that day -- but once you get in the pool it's fine. The pool's got to be at least 95 degrees and you get kind of hot in there. Then you roll in the snow, and jump back in the pool. It absolutely takes your breath away, in a great way. You feel like a million dollars when you're done -- if you don't have pneumonia. As told to Seth Kugel

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: SBASTIEN and his father have never been close, but in THE BARBARIAN INVASIONS (2003), which won the best foreign-language-film Oscar last year, he becomes the perfect son. His father, Rmy (Rmy Girard), is dying, and Sbastien (Stphane Rousseau), with the help of the millions he has earned as a financial-risk manager, arranges to have a private hospital room built for him, brings Rmy's friends together at his bedside and arranges for a drug addict to bring the dying man heroin, which Sbastien has been assured is, as a pain killer, "800 percent more effective than morphine." Rmy, his friends and his ex-lovers are the Canadian college professors from Denys Arcand's "Decline of the American Empire" (1986), grown older, mellower and less sexually active. This, Mr. Arcand's sequel, is an intelligent tear-jerker about the acceptance of death and full appreciation of the time we have -- Thursday at 10:45 p.m. on Starz.

When she was lieutenant governor, she offered free mammograms at the Capitol every October and lobbied to create a check-off box on the state income tax form that allowed people to donate money to breast cancer research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUTHBERT, WILLIAM RODGER
description: CUTHBERT--William Rodger, son of Helen Rodger and Lawrence F. Cuthbert, born April 21, 1919 in Ogdensburg, NY, died in his home in Naples, FL at 12:40 AM, December 20, 2004. Bill attended Deerfield Academy ('38) & Kenyon College ('42). Among his best memories were "busting the polo ponies", and classical music in the hanger while learning the mechanics of aircraft & flying. President of the National Intercollegiate Flying Club, his first job was with the Aeronca Aircraft Company. He married Janet Lamberton, affectionately known as "Lamb", on December 20, 1941. Enlisting in the U.S. Army Air Corps, Bill flew with the 30th Fighter Squadron in Panama: he called his P-38 "the Stray Lamb" because "she" always brought him home. From 1946 he was an executive with Newell Manufacturing of which his father, Lawrence was a founder. In 1954 he started and was president of Dover Manufacturing, living for 40 years in Guilford, CT. In 1959 he & Janet packed up the entire family and traveled through Europe settling in Positano, Italy and renting Villa Viola. He taught himself to sculpt and cast in bronze, doing so for ten years. He was a director of the Newell Company (Newell Rubbermaid) from 1962 to 1995, and Chairman of the Board from 1976 to 1992. In 1989 he & Janet began wintering in Naples, FL, moving there in 1994. Bill & "Lamb" helped create and administrate ground - breaking organiza tions among others SARAH & the Philadelphia Piano Quartet. They made social and environmental contributions to The Institute on Man and Science, the Guilford Land Conservation Trust, & the Corkscrew Swamp Sanctuary. He is survived by Janet; his sisters Betty-Jean Wood and Ellen Burt; his children William, Cynthia, Rodger and Elizabeth; ten grandchildren & five great grandchildren. Bill lived a happy and exciting life and he was full of curiosity to the end. Donations may be made to your local hospice or land trust.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: James Ryerson's salute to Sidney Morgenbesser brought back memories of my experience as his student in a contemporary civilization class in the 1950's ("Sidewalk Socrates"). His class was not so much a class as an enlightened and enlightening conversation. In today's bureaucratized universities, with their insistence on substantial publication, Morgenbesser would never receive tenure, let alone become a full professor. He represented a type that used to be common on campuses: the lovable eccentric who doesn't quite get with the program but nevertheless makes an important contribution to campus life.

title: The Henry Jones Art Hotel in Hobart, Tasmania
description: THE BASICS -- Housed in a 140-year-old jam factory tucked among Hobart's waterfront warehouses at 25 Hunter Street, the Henry Jones Art Hotel lives up to its name. More than 250 pieces -- mostly works from artists at the nearby Tasmanian School of Art -- fill the guest rooms, halls and three-story glass-and-timber atrium. But the hotel, which opened in June, is far from being a glorified gallery space. Local students had a hand in designing everything functional, from cabinets and desks to beds (deep headboard boxes double ingeniously as hidden closet space). Luminous prints and installations give a nod to the neighborhood's penal, trading and industrial history.
