title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSE, JOSEPHINE GROHE
description: ROSE--Josephine Grohe. Of Briarcliff Manor, NY, died on January 4, 2005, in Wellesley, MA, at age 94. She was born in The Bronx, NY, on December 6, 1910, the daughter of Josephine and Albert Grohe, and sister of Walter Grohe. She was predeceased by her husband of 50 years, William A. Rose. She was a graduate of Barnard College (1931), where she majored in mathematics. She and her husband Bill were married on July 3, 1937. Josephine leaves three sons, William A. Rose, Jr. and his wife Sandra, of White Plains, NY, Donald W. Rose and his wife Carol, of Mt. Kisco, NY, and Alan D. Rose and his wife Janet, of Wellesley, MA, and a daughter, Nancy Aktas and her husband Gurbuz Aktas of Izmir, Turkey. She also leaves thirteen granchildren, five greatgrandchildren, and two nieces. She was a devoted member of the Scarborough Presbyterian Church, Scarborough, NY. She was also a member of the Ossining Choral Society, the Oratorio Society of NY, Sleepy Hollow Country Club, New York Athletic Club, and was a benefactor of the Metropolitan Opera. She and her family formerly lived in Port Washington, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in her memory to Scarborough Presbyterian Church, Route 9 and Scarborough Rd, Box 35, Scarborough, NY 10510, where a memorial service will be held on Monday, January 17, 2005, at 12 noon.

She grew up in Los Angeles and moved to New York where she married her first husband, Saul Kaplan, a prominent lawyer and state government official. During her 38 years of marriage to Mr. Kaplan, she held leadership positions in a number of civic, philanthropic and cultural organizations both in Cedarhurst, NY and Miami, FL including President of the Peninsula Section of the National Council of Jewish Women, the President of the Five Towns Child Guidance Center and Secretary and Trustee of the Miami Philharmonic. The United States South Seas Exploring Expedition (known as the Ex. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAPOLARELLO, GRACE AUDITORE
description: CAPOLARELLO--Grace Auditore (December 11, 1920January 3, 2005). Mom would often end a phone conversation with us with the words "Do everything right." How appropriate since that is how she tried to live her life by doing the right thing, always. Mom was the most optimistic person we knew. Her cheerful disposition and optimism had a childlike quality, yet she was also the most maternal person we knew. Strangers she met would easily tell her their troubles and she made them feel relieved and comforted. Needless to say she was a source of comfort for her family as well. She was our home base. She was our heart. A big piece of us goes with her and yet so much more of her will remain with us forever. Let us remember her playing in Cobble Hill, going to school, becoming a beautiful young woman, and going to Giardini, Italy, through Naples to marry our father, nervous and bewildered. Let us remember her walking on Court Street on Sundays with her husband and 3 children, going to the Court Street Pastry Shop and then stopping by her sister Annette's home with some fresh biscotti and lemon ice. Let us remember her in the early fall, the cold of winter and when spring then summer came and the light, smells and sounds changed, smiling proud of her life and her family. Mom, we love you & will remember you always. Love, Joe, Rita, & in spirit, Dominick

title: Malpractice Mythology
description: "Tort reform," the Bush administration's answer to the problem of high medical malpractice costs, makes sense from only one aspect: the political. The genius of tort reform, which focuses on putting a cap on the awards from malpractice suits, is that it offends only one big-money lobbying group: trial lawyers, who are important financial supporters of the Democratic Party. Meanwhile, it helps or holds harmless Republican special interests in the insurance, drug and health care industries. The only problem is that it hurts the hapless patients who suffer grievous harm at the hands of incompetent doctors.

She was a cherished sister of Lucien of Dearborn Heights, MI, Joseph of Scottsdale, AZ and the late Eugene Daoust, and aunt to many nieces and nephews. She was an actress on the New York stage, TV and in regional theater. She was the only woman in the 1950s Broadway production of "No Time for Sergeants". Maree was the author of many plays, and of scripts for radio shows like "The Shadow". Marie was a generous financial donor and also donated much of her time to various ministries, such as the Kathryn Kuhlman Foundation. A memorial service is planned on Sunday, January 9, at 10AM at St. John's Jesuit High School Chapel, 5901 Airport Highway, Toledo, OH 43615. title: More Religion, but Not the Old-Time Kind
description: ALMOST anywhere you look around the world, with the glaring exception of Western Europe, religion is now a rising force. Former Communist countries are humming with mosque builders, Christian missionaries and freelance spiritual entrepreneurs of every possible persuasion. In China, underground "house churches" are proliferating so quickly that neither the authorities nor Christian leaders can keep reliable count. In much of South and Central America, exuberant Pentecostal churches, where worshipers catch the Holy Spirit and speak in tongues, continue to spread, challenging the Roman Catholic tradition. And in the United States, religious conservatives, triumphant over their role in the re-election of President Bush, are increasingly asserting their power in politics, the media and culture.

description: GOODFIELD--Alan. December 30th. Beloved husband of Helen. Adoring father of Lisa Heyman (deceased), Suzanne Lynn, Karen Michele, Nancy and Jeff Davis. Loving grandfather of Casey, Elena, Gaylen, Grace and Luka. Devoted brother of Charles and Evelyn Goodfield and the late Sheila Fischer. A graduate of the Horace Mann School, Alan served as a naval officer during World War II. He then graduated from the Wharton School, earned his MBA at NYU, and was a business executive until his retirement to North Carolina. Subsequently, he headed Volunteers for Youth for a year, and enjoyed seasonal tax work, taking a personal interest in each client. A gentleman and a hero, Alan was exceptionally kind and courteous, always supportive and encouraging to those around him. title: How a Vote Could Derail Democracy
description: Stanford, Calif. - IRAQ is about to reach a point of no return. If, as President Bush insists, it goes ahead with elections for the new transitional government on Jan. 30, Iraq may score a huge moral and political victory for democracy over violence and terrorism. More likely, however, these elections will only increase political polarization and violence by entrenching the perceptions of Sunni Arab marginalization that are helping to drive the violence in the first place. This would not be the first instance when badly timed and ill-prepared elections set back the prospects for democracy, stability and ethnic accommodation. Think of Angola in 1992, Bosnia in 1996, Liberia in 1997.

The insurance company is hedging on paying out on the double-indemnity policy, and although Alice has found a job with a real estate firm, she has yet to make her first sale. title: Must Peace Wait for Democracy?
description: On June 24, 2002, President Bush propounded a new foundation for Palestinian statehood. "I call on the Palestinian people to elect new leaders, not compromised by terror," he said. "I call upon them to build a practicing democracy, based on tolerance and liberty. If the Palestinian people actively pursue these goals, America and the world will actively support their efforts." Neither Palestinian nationalism nor Palestinian suffering any longer justified the political enfranchisement of the Palestinians. Instead the Palestinian question was folded tidily into the Bush administration's catechism about democracy, which it has raised into the solution to all of the world's significant problems. Tyranny, terrorism, poverty, disease: the administration's answer to all these evils is elections. About the moral and political superiority of democracy, and about the disqualification of terrorists from politics and diplomacy, the president was correct; but there was something doctrinal, even magical, about his formula. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLER, DEANE G.
description: KELLER--Deane G. (64), of Marlborough, CT died suddenly on January 4, 2005. He was the son of Deane and Katherine Hall Keller. He earned a B.A. from Yale University, his M.A. from St. Joseph College in West Hartford, CT and studied in Florence, Italy. Deane was a professor at the Lyme Academy College of Fine Arts in Old Lyme, CT for 25 years. He was awarded the Charlotte Colby Danly Jackson Endowment for the Deane G. Keller Chair in Classical Drawing and Figurative Art at Lyme Academy College. Deane also taught at the New York Academy of Art, Graduate School of Figurative Art in New York City, and the Art Students League of New York. Deane's work is housed in several permanent collections and was widely exhibited in the northeast and Italy. Deane authored two books, "Figure Drawing in the Academy Tradition 1890-1998" and the "Draftsman's Handbook: A Resource and Study Guide for Drawing from Life" which he also illustrated. Deane is survived by his wife of 36 years, Dorothy Bosch Keller, and a brother, William. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Deane G. Keller Scholarship Fund at Lyme Academy College of Fine Art, 84 Lyme St., Old Lyme, CT 06371 or the Deane G. Keller Art History Scholarship at St. Joseph College, 1678 Asylum Ave., West Hartford, CT 06117.

UP FRONT
description: Longtime readers of the Book Review may remember that Marilynne Robinson's essays used to appear often in these pages. It's a pleasure to welcome her back, reviewing two books about the birth of the antislavery movement in England: Steven M. Wise's "Though the Heavens May Fall" and Adam Hochschild's "Bury the Chains." For Robinson, whose fiction and essays revive the classic 19th-century themes of conscience, duty and moral awakening, abolitionism is a compelling subject. As she recalled in an e-mail message: "About 20 years ago, a minister who knew I was interested in American literature gave me an old book, 'The Lives and Deeds of Our Self-Made Men,' by Harriet Beecher Stowe," which told dramatic stories about early heroes of the antislavery crusade. "Over the years I read what I could find," she explained, "and put together a web of interacting people and settlements. I wanted to look at a reform movement that actually took root." Her research animated her novel "Gilead," one of the Book Review's 10 Best Books of 2004, and informs her belief, stated in her review, that slavery was met with indifference by many "in a world where the appropriation of lives and the extortion of labor were astonishingly commonplace." title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEGAL, JOHN B.
description: SEGAL--John B., of Larchmont, NY, and Westport, MA, beloved husband for 50 years of Janet Z. Segal, Chief Operating Officer of Four Winds Hospital, Katonah, NY, died on January 6, 2005 of melanoma. He was 76 years old. He was a cherished father, adored uncle, beloved grandfather, and a joyful, quick-witted and dynamic spirit among his friends and business colleagues. An innovator in the cultivation of new hop varieties, he successfully propagated the Cascade hop, among others, which became a mainstay of the brewing industry. He was an active voice for the use of American-grown hops in beer production. He owned a ranch in Grandview, WA, the base of his agricultural operations and brokered the sale of hops, as his father had done since the repeal of Prohibition. He also propagated poplar trees for environmental remediation and at the time of his death, was exploring the medical uses of hops. Born in NY and raised in Great Neck, he attended Westtown School in Westtown, PA and Bard College in Annandale, NY. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his brother, actor, George Segal, and his children and their spouses, John and Robyn Segal of Scarsdale, NY, Jeanne Segal and Tom Trainer of Bethesda, MD, Joanne Fryer (and the late Gary Fryer), also of Larchmont, and special nephew and niece, Nicholas Segal, Polly Segal, and the lights of his life, nine grandchildren, Adam Segal, William Segal, Matthew Fryer, Jenny Fryer, Rebecca Fryer, Eliza Trainer, Ben Trainer, Annie Segal and Teddy Segal. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Melanoma Immuno Fund, c/o Dr. Jed Wolchock, Memorial Sloan Kettering, 1275 York Ave., NY NY 10021, or Westport River Watershed Alliance (WRWA), PO Box 3427, Westport, MA 02790. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, January 9th, at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel", 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC.

This fall, she and her husband made the long journey from their home in Minneapolis to Bhutan's sole airport, then spent seven days on a guided tour, trekking into virgin forests, tiptoeing into temples and passing through villages where men and women still go about in traditional dress. "Bhutan has bubbled up in the collective consciousness," said Ms. George. "I just felt like I had to go."

title: Corrections
You Talkin' to Me?
description: I CAME across the following sentence in a term paper recently. The student was about to describe how she had arrived at her conclusions. This is what she wrote: "The following methodology was utilized." I see this kind of thing all the time. Not "the following method was used"; not ever "this is what I did." Like nearly all the students I've taught, this young woman has learned to believe that the English language does not have room for her. That it is a secret code known only to the initiated. That the language she speaks is uneducated, inferior and incorrect. Hence the corseted tone, the vocabulary that strains at sophistication, the way she absents herself from her own writing. This is a student who has been taught to worship the volcano god of Correct English.

description: HERBST--Eugenia Victoria (nee Levin). On January 7, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Frank F. Herbst. Loving mother of Edward and Peter and mother-in-law of Beth Skinner and Ann Colin Herbst. Dear sister of Mimi and Rhoda. Adoring grandmother of Nico, Gabrielle, William and Nicholas. As an administrator for H.I.P., Ombudsman for City Council President Paul O'Dwyer, head of the Quality Improvement Program for the NYC Department of Health, Supervisor in the Office of Municipal Labor Relations and member of the NYS Office of Medical Conduct Ethics Panel, Jean fought tirelessly to make the public health system truly serve the public. Jean was a warm, nurturing and loving mother, motherin-law, and grandmother, but what made her so exceptional was that she extended these qualities to so many other people all over the world. Jean had friends in Indonesia, Thailand, Nepal, England, Ireland and Japan, where she recently spent two weeks on an exhaustive visit. Her openness to new people, new experiences, and new cultures was unique. We, her family, will miss her beyond expressing, as will so many people in distant places. Service Monday, 11:15 am, at "The Riverside," 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to the Bread and Roses Cultural Project of 1199 SEIU, Esther Cohen, Executive Director, 330 W. 42 St., NY, NY 10036.

title: Caribbean Lights
description: Holiday decorations are coming down as New York settles into its gray season. But these Caribbean places add brightness to the restaurant scene.

title: The Gridlock That Stole Albany
description: Greenburgh, N.Y. - ALL across New York, in calm and angry voices, people have concluded that Albany no longer functions in their interest. The keenest criticism has been directed at the Legislature's processes (or lack thereof). The problem, however, is more fundamental: Albany's gridlock -- especially its annual budget-bill gridlock. And now only a constitutional amendment or a constitutional convention can put state government back to work.

A Real Election in a Virtual State

title: Israel Eases Travel Limits on Palestinians Before Election
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Jan. 8 - Israel said Saturday that it was easing travel restrictions as promised in advance of the Palestinian presidential election on Sunday. But Palestinians said they saw only limited evidence that checkpoints and other obstacles were being removed.

title: Mi Ae Geoum, Terence Taylor
description: Mi Ae Geoum and Terence Thomas Taylor were married yesterday at the Merchant's House Museum in Manhattan. Justice Marsha Steinhardt of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn officiated.

title: Assailant Stabs Man in Times Square
description: A man was stabbed in the neck as he pushed a baby stroller through a crowd of pedestrians about 7 p.m. last night in Times Square, the police said. The man, whom the police declined to identify, was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital with a stab wound that did not appear to be life threatening, investigators said. They said the child in the stroller was unhurt.

title: Packers Assured By Favre's Resilience
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Jan. 7 - The Green Bay huddle, once Brett Favre steps in, takes on a businesslike calm. Even if the Packers are trailing in the final minutes, there is no perceptible concern or panic. Favre's teammates sense that something special is about to happen.

description: LIGHTING UP: How I Stopped Smoking, Drinking and Everything Else I Loved in Life Except Sex By Susan Shapiro Delacorte Press ($22, hardcover)

title: For Returning Soldiers, Hellos to Family and Goodbyes to Comrades
description: Standing there yesterday on a Manhattan street, freshly released from active duty in Iraq, Capt. Vincent J. Heintz was telling war stories: How his men had helped train an Iraqi national guard company. How, with the nationwide elections just around the corner, he has confidence in that company to handle anything.

title: The Eli Experiment
description: As a football fan and New Orleans resident, I enjoyed reading Michael Lewis's article about the Manning family (Dec. 19, 2004). However, I was troubled by one minor point. In describing the Wonderlic Personnel Test given to N.F.L. players, Lewis cites two example questions: an "easier question" (verbal) and a "hard one" (math).

title: Whosit's Whatchamacallit

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARRON, JEANNE R.
description: BARRON--Jeanne R. On January 8, 2005. Born December 25, 1904, in Lancaster, PA, she was married to William N. Barron, until his death in 1963. Mrs. Barron was a 1926 graduate of Vassar College and a longtime resident of Great Neck and Manhattan. Surviving are her children, Barbara DiPierre of Littleton, NH, Robert A. (Tony) Barron of Hartsdale, NY, grandchildren, Susan and Wendy Barron, William, Christopher and Nicole DiPierre, great-grandchildren, Jordan, Cameron and Ruby. Service 3 PM, Sunday, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave, Dobbs Ferry, NY. Memorials to Greenburgh Nature Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLYNN, JOHN R.
description: GLYNN--John R. on January 1, 2005 in Redding, CT, after a lengthy struggle with Alzheimer's disease. Longtime resident of Manhasset, NY. Beloved husband of 61 years (Janet), father (John III, Jim), father-in-law (Carol, Elise), grandfather (John, Janet, Cary) and dear friend to all who knew him. Born in West Haven, CT, graduate of Trinity College and Columbia University (MBA). During WW II, served with US Army in Guam, rising to rank of Major. With Sperry Corp. for many years, retiring as a Corporate Vice President of Human Resources. Founding partner and President of The National Mortgage News, a winner of the Peabody Award for journalism.

title: Corrections

title: Suffolk Legislature Ends Its Rules Committee
description: The Suffolk Legislature disbanded its year-old rules committee on Monday.

title: BENEFITS
description: Winter Antiques Opening JAN. 20 -- The opening night of the 51st annual Winter Antiques Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory will aid South Bronx social service programs of the East Side House Settlement. The evening, with cocktails and hors d'oeuvres served throughout, begins at 5 for those with $1,000 tickets, at 6 for those with $500 tickets, and at 7 for those with $300 tickets. All tickets and information from (718)292-7392. Daily admission for the show, which continues through Jan. 30, is $20 and also benefits the East Side House Settlement.

description: AMERICARES and Save the Children, two of the major nonprofit relief organizations based in the state, received almost $25 million in donations and sent thousand of pounds of relief supplies to Southeast Asia in the first week following the deadly tsunamis that struck Christmas weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLIGAN, JAMES M.
description: MILLIGAN--James M. Of Manhattan, NY, passed away suddenly on January 7, 2005. Loving husband of Karen Blank, Dean of Studies at Barnard College, and devoted father of Ned Milligan of whom he was so proud, mentor, model and friend to multitudes. He served as Dean of Admissions at Columbia Law School since 1980, where he enhanced the lives of students and colleagues and brought national credit to his law school as a far-sighted leader in admissions. He was a member of the Klingenstein Advisory Board at Teachers College and because of his sense of professional responsibility, selected to serve as a member of the Disciplinary Committee of the Appellate Division, First Department. He also served as a board member of the Law School Admissions Council. Service Monday, January 10, 1 PM at West End Collegiate Church, 368 West End Ave, at 77 St.

title: At the Bottom of the Steps, Getting a Little Off the Top
description: When Tommy Gangi talks about getting a cut in the subway, he is not referring to an injury he got colliding with an aggressive straphanger. Mr. Gangi is in fact talking about his hair, which he has cut in an unlikely and arguably unglamorous spot: a barbershop in a subway station in Lower Manhattan called the Royal Barber Shop, where the rumblings of the A train can be heard with regularity.

title: Water Views From a Perch Atop the Housing Market
description: EAST HAMPTON - STEWART AND CAROL RAHR didn't set out to buy the priciest residence in New York State. They weren't even in the market for a summer house in the Hamptons; they already had one. But the power couple -- he owns the country's largest pharmaceuticals distributor, she designs high-end diamond jewelry -- needed just one look to decide that $45 million in cash would be a fair exchange for Burnt Point, a palatial 25-acre estate on exclusive Georgica Pond.

title: In Natural Resources Funds, How Long Will the Batteries Last?
description: INVESTORS stampeded into natural resources funds last year, motivated in large part by a sharp increase in oil prices.

title: Correction
description: The Night Out column last Sunday, about Dr. Henry S. Lodge and Chris Crowley, the authors of "Younger Next Year: A Guide to Living Like 50 Until You're 80 and Beyond," misstated the location of the A-frame hut where they vacationed near Aspen, Colo. It is in the Williams Mountains in the Hunter-Fryingpan Wilderness outside Aspen, not in the Elk Mountains.

title: Museum Quality
description: Muji Someday, Andy Warhol once mused in one of his many deadpan ruminations on the future, "all department stores will become museums, and all museums will become department stores." If this has not happened literally, it has practically. In the former art-world stronghold SoHo, gallery-like retail outlets abound; the Prada store is at least as effective at inspiring reverence for its contents as the building's former occupant, the Guggenheim. Meanwhile, as James B. Twitchell showed in his 2004 book "Branded Nation" (the source of that Warhol quote), the chiefs of what he calls Museumworld regularly exhibit consumer products and have become increasingly sophisticated about marketing themselves.

title: Airports Use the Cellphone to Ease Traffic Congestion
description: Los Angeles International has become the latest airport to open a cellphone parking lot, where motorists picking up passengers can wait in their vehicles until they are called. Managers at the airport say they plan to open two more cellphone lots before summer.

title: The Shock of The Old
description: This is not your grandmother's crystal candelabrum. O.K. -- it is, but just as with drippy chandeliers, unctuous florals and flocked wallpaper, hipster homeowners are giving it a modern twist, using it, say, on a minimalist glass-and-steel dining table, with the contrast working to the advantage of both. The Medallion candelabrum, shown here, was designed in the 1860's by Baccarat, the venerable French company that knows a thing or two about the current thirst for all things sparkly. Its Paris headquarters, designed by Philippe Starck in the former home of the 20th-century style-setter Marie-Laure de Noailles, is an ode to tinkling prisms.

title: Rams Survive a Final Push by the Seahawks
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 8 - No matter what happens to them, no matter how much melodrama their coach drags them through, the St. Louis Rams still carry themselves like a championship team. Never mind that their Super Bowl victory is now five years old. Forget that they stumbled to an 8-8 record this season. The Rams believed into the final seconds of Saturday's wild-card game that Seattle had no business beating them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEITZER, JANE SCHAAP
description: LEITZER--Jane Schaap. Died peacefully in Portland, ME on January 6, 2005 at age 86. She is survived by her loving daughters Joan Leitzer, M.D. of Portland and Ellen Leitzer, Esq. of Albuquerque, NM, her son-in-law Kenneth Spirer, and grandchildren Kathryn, William and Laren Spirer and Sara Silverstein. Jane grew up in NYC, was educated at the Ethical Culture School, Fieldston, and Mt. Holyoke College. Her passion was travel and she began her own program placing American teenagers with French families in Aix-en-Provence. She remained a travel agent for many years. Her other passions included cooking, reading and supporting Democratic candidates. She railed against the alleged 2004 election of G.W. Bush. After eight decades in the New York City area, Jane moved to Maine five years ago to be nearer her family. A remembrance will be held in New York in March. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Senior Citizens' Law Office, 4317 Lead Avenue, SE, Albuquerque, NM 87108 (co-founded and co-directed by Ellen Leitzer), or Common Cause, 1250 Connecticut Avenue, NW, Washington, D.C. 20036.

description: ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 8 - The Nets were tired, short-handed, ill and trailing by 17 points with six minutes to play Saturday night.

title: Winner Takes All
description: One of the most mysterious elections in the world is currently being held, without the benefit of international observers or the possibility of court-ordered recounts. Here's a look at the little-understood process of choosing Oscar nominees, and a forecast of which contenders are most likely to benefit from the motion picture academy's system when the nominations are announced on Jan. 25.

title: Its Own Reward
description: What do Anne Bancroft, Anjelica Huston and Meryl Streep have in common besides Oscars? Come April, each will have been a producer of a one-woman show in New York. This she-stoops-to-produce trend started early last year when Ms. Streep helped present Sarah Jones's "Bridge and Tunnel" (she is in discussions to fill the role again when Ms. Jones opens on Broadway this spring); continued in July when Ms. Bancroft brought Ann Randolph's "Squeeze Box" east from Los Angeles; and culminates (for now) in Geraldine Hughes's "Belfast Blues," which begins previews on Tuesday at the Culture Project under Ms. Huston's watchful eye. Here's a look at how these acclaimed actress-producers became involved, how involved they have been, and whether they heeded the advice that Ms. Bancroft's husband, Mel Brooks, gave in "The Producers": Never put your own money into the show! ERIC GRODE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUZMAN, FORBES, ROBERT
description: GUZMAN - FORBES -- Robert. 75. Passed away Friday, December 10, 2004 in Cocoa Beach, FL. Born in New York City and raised in New Rochelle, NY, he moved to Cocoa Beach from Simsbury, CT in 1996. He was a graduate of the Valley Forge Military Academy and after serving four years in the United States Air Force, he attended and graduated from the Columbia Art Instruction Institute, the University of Virginia and the New York City School of Visual Arts. A freelance artist in commercial illustration and design, he became a nationally known animal portraitist with his work being featured on playing cards, greeting cards, porcelain plates and in various publications. His portraits are in many private collections. While owner of a gallery in Avon, CT, he was for several years a master artist, teacher and advisor to special education groups in that state. He appears in The Dictionary of International Biographies, published in Cambridge, England, Who's Who in American Art and Who's Who in the East. He was predeceased by his father, Chilean diplomat Ernesto Guzman-Donoso, his mother Viola and brother Leonard. He is survived by his companion of 44 years, Ken Keating. Cremation will be followed by burial at sea. Memorial donations may be made to the American Parkinson Disease Association.

description: Sherrill, N.Y. - AT the SavOn convenience store in this tiny, tidy upstate city of 3,000 or so, a gallon of regular gas goes for $1.86, a pack of Marlboros goes for $3.75, and the history goes on forever.

title: Back Again: Taj Mahal by Moonlight
description: Visitors may once again experience the Taj Mahal by moonlight after India's Supreme Court ruled in November that it should once again be open for night viewing. The white marble mausoleum, in the northern city of Agra, was closed at night starting in 1984 over fears of Sikh separatist attacks.

title: Clean Spaces For Skin-Care Products
description: ACCORDING to Lev Glazman, chief executive of the cosmetics and skin care company Fresh, there are ways for a retailer to make money even on Madison Avenue near streets numbered in the 70's, where rents run about $600 a square foot annually. For starters: don't have too many square feet.

title: Phoenix Pays a Little Homage to Much Faster Times
description: The Phoenix Suns are a much-needed breath of fresh air for an N.B.A. that remains far too bruising and boring. After 32 games, they were averaging a league-best 109.3 points, an astonishing 7.9 points more a game than the Dallas Mavericks, ranked No. 2 in that category.

title: Older, and Living in Manhattan
description: CONTRARY to what many people might assume, the warm climates of Florida and the Southwest are not the only appealing places to grow old. For many retired people, Manhattan is a wonderland.

title: Those I.P.O.'s Are Sizzling Hot. Uh-Oh.
description: AS a mutual fund manager whose specialty is freshly minted public companies, Linda R. Killian is in the business of making risky investments. But she couldn't quite bring herself to buy shares in Marchex, an online marketing company that made its Wall Street debut last March.

title: Remapping the Middle East, Maybe
description: After Saddam Hussein seized neighboring Kuwait in 1990, the historian David Fromkin published an essay in the Smithsonian journal recalling how the modern Middle East was formed, in which he wrote: "In 1922, Churchill succeeded in mapping out the Arab Middle East along lines suitable to the needs of the British civilian and military administrations. T.E. Lawrence ["Lawrence of Arabia"] would later brag that he, Churchill and a few others had designed the modern Middle East over dinner. Seventy years later the question is whether the peoples of the Middle East are willing or able to continue living with that design."

description: TEITELBAUM -- Beatrice Wohl. Beloved wife of William. Loving mother of Linda and Marc. Adoring grandmother, devoted daughter and sister. She had a zest for life and beauty that was contagious, a large and charitable heart, and great courage that never wavered. She will be dearly missed. Her passing, in Monrovia, CA, on December 28, was as gentle, elegant, and blessed as was Roberta. "Good night. We love you. See you in the morning."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SADOFF, LARRY M.
description: SADOFF--Larry M., a highly regarded Promotions Director and Marketing Consultant in the sports and entertainment industry, died November 21, 2004 at Hospice of the Valley-Maricopa in Phoenix, AZ, following a long and courageous battle with emphysema. He was 75. Mr. Sadoff enjoyed a career in an industry he loved, that spanned well over 40 years. He contributed his distinct, colorful style and expertise to prestigious organizations and groundbreaking live and tour events, resulting in numerous professional achievements and lasting friendships. Larry was preceded in death by his wife Monica. He is survived by daughters, Carla Sadoff of Hudson, NY, Susan Sadoff of Bowling Green, OH and sons, Jeff Sadoff of Chicago, IL and Harry Victor (Sadoff) of Los Angeles, CA. A memorial service is scheduled to be held in Buffalo, NY on February 4th, 2005 at the Dengler Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations be made to: St. Joseph's Pulmonary Rehabilitation in memory of Larry M. Sadoff, St. Joseph's Hospital, 350 W. Thomas Rd., Phoenix, AZ 85013.

Up the River
description: Tourists at Sing Sing -- now there's an idea. The county executive, Andrew J. Spano, floated it this week in a letter to the Empire State Development Corporation. He wants to create a museum at the maximum-security state prison in Ossining, so visitors can take a ferry up the river to the Big House, see the old electric chair where Julius and Ethel Rosenberg and Albert Fish, the serial killer-cannibal, met their fates, and wallow in the 1920's romance of the place. Like Alcatraz in San Francisco, Sing Sing in Westchester could be a cash machine, pulling in, by Mr. Spano's estimate, $20.5 million a year.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: In his eulogy for Elisabeth Kbler-Ross, Jonathan Rosen leaves out a most important point in regard to her visit to Maidanek. It was there that she discovered, in the barracks of the children who were to be exterminated, drawings of butterflies: symbols of hope and regeneration. What Rosen describes as a darker motivation for her work is rather just the opposite.

title: A Winter Garden Of Blooming Jackets
description: As winter hits its stride, designers are offering chic and cozy jackets in a wide array of shapes, shades and styles. Whether they are built to withstand blistering mountain-face conditions, like the Lucid jacket from Moonstone, or simply made for some cool swanning about town, like a raccoon-trimmed vest from Burberry, all these jackets will wear warmly and well.

title: Mr. Gehry Builds His Dream House
description: Los Angeles - FEW American architects have expressed the turmoil of the creative process with as much raw emotion as Frank Gehry: the fragmented, sometimes violent forms he has designed over the last 50 years seem to capture the whole range of human experience. And no structure has manifested that internal struggle more than his own house.

title: Strange Things Wash Up on the Jersey Shore
description: THE new Fox series "Point Pleasant" begins when Christina, a pretty blonde teenager, is rescued from the Atlantic Ocean. But Christina is no ordinary adolescent; her father is the devil and she has come to the New Jersey shore, of all places, to search for her mother (and in the process rile up the locals). "I love the concept," said Gail Berman, the entertainment president of Fox. "I call it 'Peyton Place' meets 'Rosemary's Baby.' The show (which has its premiere on Jan. 19, then picks up the next night in its regular weekly time slot) is shepherded by Marti Noxon, one of its executive producers. Speaking here with Kate Aurthur, Ms. Noxon -- who previously worked on another supernatural series, Joss Whedon's "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" -- discusses toying with censors, working with a baby and how reality television saved scripted programs.

title: Are Spendthrift Americans Really the Problem?
description: AS if an orgy of holiday spending weren't enough to remind us, the latest government figures provide a stark indictment of our profligacy. Personal saving as a percentage of disposable income was just 0.3 percent in November. Because savings, in the form of investment, are the lifeblood of the economy, our spendthrift ways will soon impoverish us or, at the very least, our children. We are sinners all.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article in Arts & Leisure today about "The Aviator," the screen biography of Howard Hughes, misstates the circumstances of Leonardo DiCaprio's early association with the project. The producer Charles Evans Jr. introduced Mr. DiCaprio to the project through a fellow producer, not through the writer John Logan, whom Mr. Evans had not met at the time. Some research material provided by Mr. Evans was sent to the fellow producer, not directly to the writer.

title: Audits Criticize U.N.Handling of Oil-for-Food
description: Internal United Nations audits of the so-called oil-for-food program in Iraq criticize an office, led by a former top aide to Secretary General Kofi Annan, for failing adequately to supervise and audit the companies hired to inspect the oil moving out of Iraq and goods going in under the multibillion-dollar program.

title: PHOTO-OP
Toxic Breast Milk?
description: If human breast milk came stamped with an ingredients label, it might read something like this: 4 percent fat, vitamins A, C, E and K, lactose, essential minerals, growth hormones, proteins, enzymes and antibodies. In a healthy woman, it contains 100 percent of virtually everything a baby needs to survive, plus a solid hedge of extras to help ward off a lifetime of diseases like diabetes and cancer. Breast milk helps disarm salmonella and E. coli. Its unique recipe of fatty acids boosts brain growth and results in babies with higher I.Q.'s than their formula-slurping counterparts. Nursing babies suffer from fewer infections, hospitalizations and cases of sudden infant death syndrome. For the mother, too, breast-feeding and its delicate plumbing of hormones afford protection against breast and ovarian cancers and stress. Despite exhaustion, the in-laws and dirty laundry, every time we nurse our babies, the love hormone oxytocin courses out of our pituitaries like a warm bath. Human milk is like ice cream, Valium and Ecstasy all wrapped up in two pretty packages.

title: Knicks Stand and Gape as James Delivers
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 8 - The steady erosion of the Knicks' season, and even of their dignity, accelerated Saturday afternoon, pushed along by the league's brightest young star and perhaps by simple momentum.

title: The SoBe Action Migrates South
description: Every year -- or is it every three months? -- there seems to be a rebirth of Miami Beach, with a new crop of clubs/bars/restaurants/shops/hotels emerging as the places to see and be seen. Until recently, all of the activity has been on South Beach proper, that strip of coolness that stretches from Fifth to about 23rd Streets. But now, some of the action is migrating south, to the neighborhood known as SoFi (pronounced so-fee).

title: Vanguard Sprints but Says It's Not Racing
description: JACK J. BRENNAN, chairman and chief executive of the Vanguard Group, is saying, as he has many times before, that his company isn't trying to become bigger. As Mr. Brennan speaks, he chops the air with his open hand for emphasis. "We've never had a growth objective," he says. "Ever. And we never will. Vanguard's goal is to deliver value to the client. How big we are is irrelevant."

description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 - Six months ago, Kevin Shelley, the California secretary of state, was generating national attention for his efforts to ensure the integrity of the voting process and was considered a promising candidate for governor or the Senate.

description: As it turns out, an important moment in the annals of modern culture may have occurred when Jon Stewart of Comedy Central went on CNN's "Crossfire" last October and decided to be serious. He told Paul Begala, on the left, and Tucker Carlson, on the right, that their show, which specializes in encouraging midlevel political types to yell slogans at each other, was "partisan hackery" that was lowering the level of political discourse. At the time, he was widely denounced for failing to be funny.

description: RAIZES--Milton and Audree. Of Naples, FL, formerly of Mason City, IA, died January 2 and January 7, 2005 respectively, Milton at the age of 88 and Audree at the age of 86. They leave behind their loving son, Dr. Gary, and his wife, Deborah Raizes, of Scarsdale, NY, Milton's dear brother, Harold, and his wife, Sonia, of Houston, TX, and their adoring grandchildren, Steven and Elizabeth, both of New York, NY. They were predeceased by Milton's brother Leon. Funeral services were held in Valhalla, NY. title: A Good Tail Fin Is Hard to Find

Beginning Saturday, "Small Forest," a new two-piece sculpture measuring 45 by 35 feet, will be on view at Paul Kasmin Gallery in Chelsea. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENFIELD, GORDON KRAUS
description: GREENFIELD -- Gordon Kraus. Died at the age of 89 on January 7, 2005, after a short illness at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Survived by wife of nearly 60 years, Harriet Copelin Greenfield; his children, Juliet Six, Gordon K. Greenfield, Jr., Faith Lewis, Hope Greenfield and James Greenfield; seven grandchildren; sister Elizabeth Zeidman and brother Albert M. Greenfield, Jr. Mr. Greenfield was a graduate of The Lawrenceville School in 1933 and Princeton in 1937. His business career began in journalism at the Washington Star before volunteering for training on the USS Wyoming in the lead-up to World War II. During the War he ws Lt. Commander on the USS Ludlow in the North Atlantic and survived losing a ship in battle off the coast of Dakar, Senegal, in 1942. For 12 years, Mr. Greenfield was president of City Specialty Stores in New York, which included the department stores of Franklin Simon and Oppenheim Collins. He then became President of America Corporation, a diversified holding company which included Pathe Film Laboraties. After that he became President of the Franchard Corporation, real estate and freight holding company. From 1965 until 2000 Mr. Greenfield was Chairman and President of QCo Industries, later named Autocue Holdings, a manufacturer and provider of a diverse range of products and services for the broadcast and media industries, with headquarters in New York and London. Equally distinguished were his accomplishments as a patron of the music world and a sponsor of several non-profit endeavors; he served as Chairman of the Board of Manhattan School of Music for 13 years and served on its Board for 29 years; he helped found, along with Dorothy Maynard as its first director, The Harlem School of the Arts; he served on the Boards of The Opera Orchestra of NY, the Little Orchestra Society, Young Concert Artists, the Santa Fe Opera, and was Past President of the Metropolitan Opera Club. He was on the Board of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, and was a deacon at the All Souls Unitarian Church in Manhattan; he served on the Committee for Romance Languages at Princeton. In the 1950's he was made a member of the Young Presidents Association and in 1969 received the Distinguished Service Award for his work on the Board of the National Arthritis Foundation. From 1966 to 1971 he was president of the Board of the Dakota Apartments in New York. Mr. Greenfield will be best remembered by his family for his fierce individualism, challenging intellect and formidable wit. He will be envisioned riding horses, which he continued to do into his 80's, at his farm in Hartland, Vermont, followed by his Jack Russell terriers. His latest dog, "Ronnie," named for Ronald Reagan, was his constant companion in his last years. A memorial service will be held at Manhattan School of Music in Greenfield Hall at a later date.

Undercover police officers were posted in the shop and in a van on the street. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRELINGHUYSEN, JOSEPH SHERMAN
description: FRELINGHUYSEN -- Joseph Sherman. Died peacefully on January 8, 2005, at age 92; sixteen days after his late wife of 67 years, Emily Lawrance Frelinghuysen. He is survived by his four children, Margaret F. Kurzman, Joseph S. Frelinghuysen Jr., Susan F. van Roijen, Barbara F. Israel, ten grandchildren, John, Joy, Nicholas, Katherine, David, Victoria, Valaer, Peter, Emily and Wendy and seven greatgrandchildren. He was the brother of Emily F. MacFarland and the late Victoria F. Bates. His mother was Emily B. Frelinghuysen and his father was US Senator Joseph S. Frelinghuysen. He graduated from the Groton School and Princeton University, Class of 1934. During World War II he served as commanding officer of a US Army Field Artillery Battery in North Africa. He was taken prisoner of war during a night reconnaissance mission and after 10 months escaped from a German prison camp in Italy. He was awarded the Silver Star for gallantry in action in 1943. He is the author of "Passages to Freedom" (1990) the story of his capture and escape and the co-author of "Keep Your Heart Running" (1976) with Paul J. Kiell, M.D. A funeral service will be held at 10 a.m. on Saturday, January 15th, at St. John on-the-Mountain Church, Bernardsville, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Church of St. John on-the-Mountain or the Army Emergency Relief Fund, 200 Stovall St., Alexandria, VA 22332.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERBST, EUGENIA VICTORIA (NEE LEVIN)
description: HERBST--Eugenia Victoria (nee Levin). On January 7, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Frank F. Herbst. Loving mother of Edward and Peter and mother-in-law of Beth Skinner and Ann Colin Herbst. Dear sister of Mimi and Rhoda. Adoring grandmother of Nico, Gabrielle, William and Nicholas. As an administrator for H.I.P., Ombudsman for City Council President Paul O'Dwyer, head of the Quality Improvement Program for the NYC Department of Health, Supervisor in the Office of Municipal Labor Relations and member of the NYS Office of Medical Conduct Ethics Panel, Jean fought tirelessly to make the public health system truly serve the public. Jean was a warm, nurturing and loving mother, motherin-law, and grandmother, but what made her so exceptional was that she extended these qualities to so many other people all over the world. Jean had friends in Indonesia, Thailand, Nepal, England, Ireland and Japan, where she recently spent two weeks on an exhaustive visit. Her openness to new people, new experiences, and new cultures was unique. We, her family, will miss her beyond expressing, as will so many people in distant places. Service Monday, 11:15 am, at "The Riverside," 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to the Bread and Roses Cultural Project of 1199 SEIU, Esther Cohen, Executive Director, 330 W. 42 St., NY, NY 10036.

title: ISIS PHARMACEUTICALS TO CUT 40% OF WORK FORCE
description: Isis Pharmaceuticals said yesterday that it planned to eliminate about 40 percent of its jobs to pare expenses and focus on developing a few key medicines, including a treatment for ulcerative colitis. Writing down the value of assets like equipment and patents will cost as much as $40 million in the fourth quarter. Additional expenses related to the layoffs will be recorded in the first quarter, Isis said. Isis, the maker of the Vitravene drug for an AIDS-related eye disorder, intends to reduce its work force to about 300 people from more than 460 employees now, a company spokeswoman, Kristina Peterson, said. The company is based in Carlsbad, Calif.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: New Center For Terrorism Study
description: A new federally financed center at the University of Maryland will study what motivates terrorists, scrutinize how terrorist groups form and recruit members, and devise ways to better predict and counter attacks. Tom Ridge, the secretary of homeland security, said the federal government would provide about $12 million over the next three years for the center. It will become the fourth university-based Homeland Security Center of Excellence. Others, each with a different focus, are based at the University of Southern California, the University of Minnesota and Texas A&M. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: No Pathologist, Bodies Pile Up
description: Some 30 bodies of suspected victims of homicides and other crimes have stacked up in mortuaries, and more are being added regularly, because the country no longer has a forensic pathologist to determine cause of death, the government's chief surgical officer said. The nation's last forensic pathologist, Alex Mapunda, resigned in May, one in a flood of medical specialists who have left Zimbabwe as its economy has crumbled and its once robust health-care system has collapsed. Families of the dead are unable to claim their relatives until forensic tests are performed on the bodies; when that will occur is unclear. "We are not experts," said the chief surgical officer, Max Hove, "and there is nothing we can do about it." Michael Wines (NYT)

description: MILLIGAN --James M. Dean David Schizer and the students, faculty and staff of Columbia Law School mourn the death of our dear friend and colleague, Dean of Admissions James M. Milligan. Jim was an integral part of our community for 25 years. He viewed our students as his children, remembering them for decades after they graduated. He was a wonderfully talented admissions professional, and a loyal and dear friend. Jim Milligan served as a trustee of the Law School Admissions Council and on many of its committees. He also served as chairman of Columbia University Community Impact, a nonprofit group that coordinates volunteer social service by students and other members of the Columbia Community. We will all rally around our colleagues in the admissions office, as we all share, and are committed to maintaining, Jim's high standards.

Paid Notice: Deaths   ANISANSEL, ARTHUR ALFRED
description: ANISANSEL--Arthur Alfred, of Jupiter, FL and Hague, NY, died January 9, 2005 at the age of 92. A man of uncommon intelligence and integrity who dealt with the physical limitations in his later life with grace and valor. Devoted husband of 60 years to his beloved late wife Dorothy. He is survived by his two children, son David (Mary) Anisansel of Henrietta, NY; daughter Cynthia (David) Rosbrook of Manlius, NY and six grandchildren. A self made man of the "Greatest Generation," Arthur was an officer in the United States Army in WWII. He began employment as a mailroom clerk in a commodities firm and ended his career as President of Imperial Commodities Corporation. Arthur was an Officer and life member of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Chairman of the National Coffee Association and previous President and life member of the Green Coffee Association of New York. Upon his retirement, he volunteered with International Executives Service Corps, serving twice in Salvador and Peru. He was also an avid Meals on Wheels driver for years. A memorial service will be held this summer at Grace Memorial Chapel, Sabbath Bay Point, NY where he served as a Trustee for over 35 years. Donations may be made in his memory to Grace Memorial Chapel and sent C/O Robert Strong, 15 Edison Drive, Niskayuna, New York 12309.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Montana: State Cancels Planned Bison Hunt
description: The first bison hunt in the state in over a decade was canceled amid concerns that it might lead to bad publicity for the state and that it did not allow the bison enough area to run from hunters. The Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks Commission voted 4 to 1 to cancel the hunt and will refund $25,000 in fees to about 8,300 people who applied for licenses. The hunt would have allowed 10 people to each kill one bison over a 30-day period. Hunts, like the one in 1989 shown above, were canceled in 1991. The governor-elect, Brian Schweitzer, a Democrat, said publicly last week that he disagreed with the hunt because of the small area allowed. The commission has tentatively approved a three-month bison hunt in a larger area to begin Nov. 15. Mindy Sink (NYT)

Sales rose 1.3 percent in the fiscal third quarter ended Jan. 1, excluding acquisitions and disposals, down from 3.5 percent a year earlier. Ms. O'Driscoll is cutting jobs and pruning Northern Foods' operating units to 4 from 15 to help improve performance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOCH, GERALD CONSTANT
description: BLOCH--Gerald Constant. Retired President of Bloch Bros. Paper Co. Inc., he died on January 9th at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He succumbed to multiple myeloma after a gallant struggle of five years. Born in Brooklyn, NY on May 30, 1925, Mr. Bloch was graduated from the Poly Prep School and from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in 1949. During WWII, he served in the European Theatre in the Corps of Engineers from early 1944 to the end of the European conflict. Mr. Bloch, a lifelong resident of New York, was President of Bloch Bros. Paper from 1948 until his retirement in 1990. The firm was founded by his father, Charles C. Bloch, in 1919. The family-run business flourished and became one of the most successful smaller fine paper companies in the United States. After his retirement, Mr. Bloch remained in real estate and other financial ventures, built a house in rural Vermont and then designed a final family home in Roxbury, CT. Devoted to the pursuit of diverse personal interests, he nurtured a lifelong appreciation of nature, was an accomplished birder whose most avid hobby was photography, particularly of birds in flight. Some of these pictures appeared in a Harry N. Abrams book. Mr. Bloch was also a highly respected photographer of the human form. An exhibit of some of his photos was displayed at the Gunn Memorial Library Gallery in Washington, CT. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Nedra Simmons Bloch; four daughters: Susan Bloch of NYC, Janice Bloch Roth of Scarsdale, NY, Dr. Amy Bloch of Larchmont, NY and Elizabeth Bloch of Chicago, IL; a sister, Myra B. Low of Guilford, CT; eight grandchildren; and three sons-in-law. A member of the University Club, Mr. Bloch served on the Paper Industry Council and on the Board of Temple Israel of the City of New York. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be held at a future date. Friends are invited to pay their respects at the Bloch home at 21 East 87th Street, NYC between 5 PM and 7 PM on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, January 10th, 11th and 12th.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Freed Militant Runs
description: Johnny Adair, known as "Mad Dog," once leader of the Ulster Defense Association, the outlawed Protestant paramilitary group, was released from a prison near Belfast after serving two-thirds of a 16-year sentence for terrorism. He was flown to Manchester, England, where his family is living, effectively in exile, and was met by an escort of British police officers. The Ulster Defense Association has threatened to kill him if he returns to Belfast, for his suspected role in the killing of a rival two years ago in an internal feud. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Jerry Springer': The Furor
description: BBC officials, workers and their families were besieged with abusive telephone calls after the broadcast on Saturday night of the award-winning satirical musical "Jerry Springer: The Opera," the BBC said yesterday. The musical, which includes foul language and portrays Jesus in a diaper, attracted 1.7 million viewers, or 10.8 percent of the audience in the 10 p.m. time slot on BBC2. The show has been seen by 400,000 people since it first opened at a small fringe theater in south London in 2001. It transferred to the West End in November 2003. A BBC statement said the calls, including some to Roly Keating, who heads BBC2, followed the publication of private numbers on a Web site. "This has been reported to the police in the normal way, and lawyers for the BBC were able to have the Web site taken down," the broadcaster said. Over the weekend, protesters appeared at BBC offices and, for the first time at the Cambridge Theater, the West End home of the show. A spokesman for Avalon, the musical's production company, said, "We have employed security to protect the theater and theatergoers." Stephen Green, the national director of Christian Voice, which says it campaigns on behalf of biblical values in law and public policy, said his group's protests would focus on the Cambridge Theater. "We didn't know the enormity of the content of it until now," Mr. Green said. PAM KENT

title: F.D.A. APPROVES AMERICAN PHARMACEUTICAL'S CANCER DRUG
description: American Pharmaceutical Partners won approval for its new form of a drug for advanced breast cancer, setting off a 28 percent gain in its share price yesterday. The Food and Drug Administration cleared the drug, Abraxane, on Friday for use in women whose breast cancer has spread and who were not helped by other chemotherapy combinations, the agency said. Shipments of the drug, also cleared for patients who relapsed within six months of initial surgery and chemotherapy, will start within 45 days, the company said. Stock in American Pharmaceutical, based in Los Angeles, rose $11.01, to $49.72 a share.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: A.C.L.U. Seeks End To DNA Sweep
description: Civil rights advocates asked law enforcement authorities to stop collecting DNA from men in Truro, a Cape Cod town, saying the tactic was invasive and would not help find the killer of Christa Worthington, a freelance fashion writer who was stabbed to death in 2002. "The mass collection of DNA samples by the police is a serious intrusion on personal privacy that has proven to be both ineffective and wasteful," wrote John Reinstein, the legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts, in a letter to the Cape and Islands district attorney, Michael O'Keefe, and the Truro police chief, John Thomas. Mr. O'Keefe said in an interview that he would not call off the sweep. Pam Belluck (NYT)

description: Microsoft is offering a 25 percent discount to customers of PeopleSoft, which was acquired last month by the Oracle Corporation. The offer covers licensing of business applications such as accounting and payroll, and the first year of support programs, Microsoft said yesterday. Microsoft is courting PeopleSoft customers worried that Oracle will not continue to provide upgrades and other support. Oracle shares fell 14 cents, to $13.19. Microsoft shares rose 13 cents to $26.80. An Oracle spokeswoman, Deborah Lilienthal, declined to comment.

title: Arts, Briefly; Long Lives the King
description: Elvis Presley's "Jailhouse Rock" (RCA) is back atop the British singles charts. A reissue of the song entered at No. 1 on Sunday, the day after what would have been the 70th birthday of Presley, right. When first released in Britain in 1958, the song was Presley's second No. 1 there, but this time it barely made it, according to Billboard, with 21,262 copies sold, the lowest weekly sales total for a No. 1 in the history of the chart, which began in 1952. It was the 999th song to reach No. 1 on the chart. An RCA reissue this week of Presley's third British No. 1, "One Night," is poised to become the chart's 1,000th No. 1. Chuck Berry is to headline the 2005 Elvis Presley Festival from June 3 to 5 in Tupelo, Miss. BEN SISARIO

The civil rights of each and every American were always on his mind. Grandpa, we love you and we'll miss you so much. A memorial service will be held in the spring.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Levitra Rights Reacquired
description: Bayer, the German drug and chemical maker, agreed to pay 208 million euros ($272 million) to GlaxoSmithKline to regain some marketing rights to the Levitra impotence pill as Bayer works to build up its drug unit. Bayer will end its Levitra partnership with Glaxo in most markets in Europe, as well as in Asia, Africa, Latin America and Canada, Bayer said. There is no change to the companies' agreement to be a co-marketer of Levitra in the United States, the companies said. Bayer, based in Leverkusen, is trying to strengthen its pharmaceuticals business after losing sales of its best-selling medicine, the antibiotic Cipro, to generic competition. Glaxo is based in Britain.

Friday's restaurant in Pennsylvania Station. Prosecutors said that Mr. Nettles confessed to several stabbings in a statement videotaped by the police after his arrest, and that charges were pending in two other stabbings, including that of a father pushing a baby carriage in Times Square. title: Maintaining Altitude or Climbing
description: MAINTAINING ALTITUDE OR CLIMBING -- Business travel this year will match or exceed last year's volume, according to a survey of 300 major North American travel managers commissioned by Carlson Wagonlit Travel. More than 80 percent of the corporate and third-party travel managers polled said they expected their 2005 business-travel spending to increase (34 percent) or stay the same (49 percent). The survey, which also polled 1,200 individual travelers, found that the top two pet peeves on flights were people who carry on bulky bags that should have been checked (32 percent cited this) and babies who cry (13 percent). Managers thought the main problems would be long security lines (29 percent) and resentment that others were paying less on the same flight (19 percent). Travelers put those at 11 percent and 5 percent, respectively.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Factory Prices Fall

description: Interstate 95 was closed at Selma after a tanker truck carrying 9,000 gallons of gasoline rolled over, burst into flames and burned for about three hours, said Pat LaCarter, a spokesman for Johnston County. The southbound lanes reopened in the afternoon, but the northbound lanes were expected to be closed well into today while the road was resurfaced. Carroll R. Langston, 61, who was driving the truck for a Rocky Mount oil company, was in critical condition at the University of North Carolina Hospitals burn center, state public safety officials said. title: Arts, Briefly; Art Thief Sentenced
description: A day after attempting suicide in his cell, a Frenchman accused of stealing more than 200 artworks from museums and galleries in Europe was sentenced on Friday to three years in prison by a Strasbourg court, which suspended 10 months of his term. The man, Stphane Breitwieser, 33, described by his lawyer, Thierry Moser, as "deeply depressed," tried to hang himself in jail late Thursday, officials said. Mr. Breitwieser, a former hotel waiter charged with stealing 23 works in France, Austria and Denmark, confessed to the theft of 239 objects, worth an estimated $1.4 billion, from institutions in seven European countries from 1995 to 2001. His mother received a three-year sentence, 18 months of it suspended, for receiving stolen items and destroying many of them. HLNE FOUQUET

title: Arts, Briefly; Jon Stewart Book Is Banned
description: After Wal-Mart decided last year not to sell "America (The Book)," a parody of a civics textbook by Jon Stewart and the writers of Comedy Central's "Daily Show" that includes satirical depictions of nine nude Supreme Court justices, Mr. Stewart invited other outlets to ban it as well. Now, a library system in Mississippi has apparently taken up the offer. The Jackson-George Regional Library System, which includes eight libraries in Jackson and George Counties near Mississippi's Gulf Coast, has refused to allow "America (The Book)" to circulate, The Associated Press reported. The news agency quoted Robert Willits, the director of the library system, as saying that the book would have been allowed if not for the single page showing the faces of the nine justices superimposed over naked, elderly bodies. "I've been a librarian for 40 years, and this is the only book I've objected to so strongly that I wouldn't allow it to circulate," Mr. Willits said. "We're not an adult bookstore." The book has been the No. 1 nonfiction hardcover book on the New York Times best-seller list for 15 straight weeks. EDWARD WYATT

The American Football Conference wild-card playoff game between the New York Jets and the San Diego Chargers delivered a victory on Saturday for ABC in its final football broadcast of the season. One program it beat was the premiere of "The Will," a new CBS reality show with contestants competing to become a 73-year-old's heir. Only 4.27 million viewers tuned in for the show, putting it in last place for the night. On Sunday, it was Fox that benefited from football's popularity: the end of the National Football Conference wild-card game between Minnesota and Green Bay gave the network a rare first-place finish. The two-hour season premiere of "24" benefited from that lead-in, as the drama drew its biggest audience ever: 14.85 million viewers watched Kiefer Sutherland, above, begin another 24 hours of efforts to save the nation. title: Arts, Briefly; Can This Soap Be Saved?
description: A fund-raising effort by fans of the British soap opera "EastEnders" gives new meaning to the "public" part of public television. Last week, WLIW, the Long Island PBS affiliate, threatened to cancel "EastEnders," which it has broadcast since 1996. But Joe Campbell, WLIW's program manager, offered viewers an opportunity to save the show: he will keep it on if they can raise $29,000, the cost of a year of licensing the series, by Jan. 31. "EastEnders," which follows the lives of residents in a working-class neighborhood in London, has been on the BBC since 1985, and it continues to be a ratings success in Britain: its Christmas episode drew 12.3 million viewers. As an import, "EastEnders" has fared less well, so its small local audience has set out to raise the money for WLIW by planning a string of benefits. The first was held Sunday when Michelle Collins, an actress formerly on the show, appeared at the West Village restaurant Fiddlesticks, where enthusiasts paid $100 each to meet her. The benefit's organizer, Larry Jaffee, said, "Everyone there was a true fan and got to chat with her." Mr. Jaffee said that the event had brought in $1,700 and that the drive had raised $8,900 so far. KATE AURTHUR

World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Yushchenko Declared The Winner
description: The Central Election Commission declared Viktor A. Yushchenko, the opposition leader, the official president-elect, bringing the protracted election closer to an end. Mr. Yushchenko, according the official count, received 51.99 percent of the vote to 44.2 percent for his opponent, former Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich. Mr. Yanukovich, who has filed several appeals to the Supreme Court, vowed to challenge the commission's result. He has a week to submit complaints, although he and his staff concede that the battle is now principally symbolic. Mr. Yushchenko's inauguration cannot be set until Mr. Yanukovich's last appeal is decided. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

If convicted, Mr. Coleman, who is white, could be sentenced to 10 years in prison and fined $10,000 for each of three counts of perjury. Steve Barnes (NYT)

The bid is 6.8 percent higher than Friday's closing share price and values Elkem at 11.6 billion kroner ($1.8 billion). Alcoa, based in Pittsburgh, holds about 46 percent of Elkem. The two companies have a joint venture that makes aluminum. A spokesman for Alcoa said the company was evaluating its options.

description: Cisco Systems announced yesterday that it would resell data storage equipment from EMC to customers looking to centralize and consolidate storage in their corporate data centers. The EMC products will be sold along with Cisco's File Engine Series, a gateway product used to increase the performance of a wide-area connection so that customers can get a complete storage package for remote offices from one vendor. Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENFIELD, GORDON KRAUS
description: GREENFIELD -- Gordon Kraus. Died at the age of 89 on January 7, 2005, after a short illness at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Survived by wife of nearly 60 years, Harriet Copelin Greenfield; his children, Juliet Six, Gordon K. Greenfield, Jr., Faith Lewis, Hope Greenfield and James Greenfield; seven grandchildren; sister Elizabeth Zeidman and brother Albert M. Greenfield, Jr. Mr. Greenfield was a graduate of The Lawrenceville School in 1933 and Princeton in 1937. His business career began in journalism at the Washington Star before volunteering for training on the USS Wyoming in the lead-up to World War II. During the War he ws Lt. Commander on the USS Ludlow in the North Atlantic and survived losing a ship in battle off the coast of Dakar, Senegal, in 1942. For 12 years, Mr. Greenfield was president of City Specialty Stores in New York, which included the department stores of Franklin Simon and Oppenheim Collins. He then became President of America Corporation, a diversified holding company which included Pathe Film Laboraties. After that he became President of the Franchard Corporation, real estate and freight holding company. From 1965 until 2000 Mr. Greenfield was Chairman and President of QCo Industries, later named Autocue Holdings, a manufacturer and provider of a diverse range of products and services for the broadcast and media industries, with headquarters in New York and London. Equally distinguished were his accomplishments as a patron of the music world and a sponsor of several non-profit endeavors; he served as Chairman of the Board of Manhattan School of Music for 13 years and served on its Board for 29 years; he helped found, along with Dorothy Maynard as its first director, The Harlem School of the Arts; he served on the Boards of The Opera Orchestra of NY, the Little Orchestra Society, Young Concert Artists, the Santa Fe Opera, and was Past President of the Metropolitan Opera Club. He was on the Board of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, and was a deacon at the All Souls Unitarian Church in Manhattan; he served on the Committee for Romance Languages at Princeton. In the 1950's he was made a member of the Young Presidents Association and in 1969 received the Distinguished Service Award for his work on the Board of the National Arthritis Foundation. From 1966 to 1971 he was president of the Board of the Dakota Apartments in New York. Mr. Greenfield will be best remembered by his family for his fierce individualism, challenging intellect and formidable wit. He will be envisioned riding horses, which he continued to do into his 80's, at his farm in Hartland, Vermont, followed by his Jack Russell terriers. His latest dog, "Ronnie," named for Ronald Reagan, was his constant companion in his last years. A memorial service will be held at Manhattan School of Music in Greenfield Hall at a later date.

title: The New Heart Disease Threat
description: The evidence has gotten much stronger that a substance known as C-reactive protein may be every bit as important as cholesterol in the diagnosis and treatment of heart disease. Now two studies published in The New England Journal of Medicine have shown that drugs that reduce the levels of that protein in patients with severe heart disease can slow the progression of atherosclerosis and prevent heart attacks and cardiac-related deaths.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINTON, LAURIE ANN
description: LINTON--Laurie Ann. On January 10, 2005, in New York City, at the age of 46, after a long illness. Laurie is survived by her brother Robert, her longtime companion, Murphy, and a host of beloved friends. Laurie was a native--and devoted--New Yorker. A graduate of Hunter College High School, Wesleyan University, and Columbia Law School, Laurie began as a litigator at Weil, Gotshal & Manges. She then turned her attention to the public sector, where she spent the remainder of her career dedicated to serving the people of New York. In positions with the Attorney General's Office, the NYC Human Resources Administration, the NYC Comptroller's Office, and as counsel to the Governor's Office under Mario Cuomo, Laurie's work affected everything from campaign finance legislation to welfare reform, the state budget to charities fraud. Laurie's contribution as an activist in the gay and lesbian community was, if possible, even more profound. She was a founder and board member of the Empire State Pride Agenda, and was instrumental in their work to pass both the Hate Crimes Bill and the Sexual Orientation Nondiscrimination Act. She also served as a Director of the Lesbian and Gay Law Association of Greater New York, and was, until her death, Vice President of the Stonewall Community Foundation's Board of Directors. The vast legion of people who counted her as their very good friend will miss her, and they would agree: her enormous love of life was surpassed only by her generosity of spirit. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, January 12, at 9:30am at "The Riverside," 76 St & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, Laurie wished donations to be made to the Stonewall Community Foundation.

The suit was filed last month in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia by Dr. Michael A. Newdow, who contends that such prayers are unconstitutional. Government lawyers noted that prayers had been part of the inauguration and legislative sessions for more than 200 years. Mr. Newdow has also challenged the recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance in his daughter's public school classroom. That effort ended inconclusively in June when the Supreme Court decided that he lacked standing to pursue the case. John Files (NYT)

description: FRELINGHUYSEN -- Joseph Sherman. Died peacefully on January 8, 2005, at age 92; sixteen days after his late wife of 67 years, Emily Lawrance Frelinghuysen. He is survived by his four children, Margaret F. Kurzman, Joseph S. Frelinghuysen Jr., Susan F. van Roijen, Barbara F. Israel, ten grandchildren, John, Joy, Nicholas, Katherine, David, Victoria, Valaer, Peter, Emily and Wendy and seven greatgrandchildren. He was the brother of Emily F. MacFarland and the late Victoria F. Bates. His mother was Emily B. Frelinghuysen and his father was US Senator Joseph S. Frelinghuysen. He graduated from the Groton School and Princeton University, Class of 1934. During World War II he served as commanding officer of a US Army Field Artillery Battery in North Africa. He was taken prisoner of war during a night reconnaissance mission and after 10 months escaped from a German prison camp in Italy. He was awarded the Silver Star for gallantry in action in 1943. He is the author of "Passages to Freedom" (1990) the story of his capture and escape and the co-author of "Keep Your Heart Running" (1976) with Paul J. Kiell, M.D. A funeral service will be held at 10 a.m. on Saturday, January 15th, at St. John on-the-Mountain Church, Bernardsville, NJ. Paid Notice: Deaths   ANISANSEL, ARTHUR ALFRED
description: ANISANSEL--Arthur Alfred, of Jupiter, FL and Hague, NY, died January 9, 2005 at the age of 92. A man of uncommon intelligence and integrity who dealt with the physical limitations in his later life with grace and valor. Devoted husband of 60 years to his beloved late wife Dorothy. He is survived by his two children, son David (Mary) Anisansel of Henrietta, NY; daughter Cynthia (David) Rosbrook of Manlius, NY and six grandchildren. A self made man of the "Greatest Generation," Arthur was an officer in the United States Army in WWII. He began employment as a mailroom clerk in a commodities firm and ended his career as President of Imperial Commodities Corporation. Arthur was an Officer and life member of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Chairman of the National Coffee Association and previous President and life member of the Green Coffee Association of New York. Upon his retirement, he volunteered with International Executives Service Corps, serving twice in Salvador and Peru. He was also an avid Meals on Wheels driver for years. A memorial service will be held this summer at Grace Memorial Chapel, Sabbath Bay Point, NY where he served as a Trustee for over 35 years.
