Paid Notice: Deaths   PUNT, WILLIAM R.
description: PUNT--William R. The Grand Lodge of Free & Accepted Masons of the State of New York, records with profound sorrow the passing of The Most Worshipful William R. Punt, Senior Past Grand Master and Permanent Member of the Grand Lodge on Friday, January 7, 2005. He died peacefully at the age of 90 at his home in Largo, Florida, with his wife Elsie at his side. William R. Punt was a 50-year member of Floral Park Lodge No. 1016. He was elected Grand Master at the 197th Annual Communication of the Grand Lodge F. & A.M. of the State of New York on May 4, 1978 and was re-elected to a second term on May 2, 1979. He was born in St. Louis, Missouri and was educated at St. Louis University, New York University and the American Institute of Banking. He was prominent in the electrical insulation industry. He was President of Punt, Incorporated from 1955 to 1971, after which he was a marketing executive with the Essex Group, Inc., a subsidiary of United Technology Corporation, until retiring in 1981. He was a founding member and past director of the Electrical Insulation Distributors Association of America and served 26 years as a Trustee of the Roosevelt Savings Bank. For four years he served as a member of the Board of Directors of Bethany Methodist Home in Brooklyn, New York. William R. Punt's Masonic legacy is his positive influence upon and wise counsel for the Masonic brotherhood he loved so deeply. He was an unparalleled proponent of the Home, now the Masonic Care Community in Utica, New York. During his administration as Grand Master, the "Think Big and Build Campaign" to remodel, refurbish and modernize the Masonic Home's facilities was undertaken and today it is a state of the art facility where residents are treated with a special kind of dignity and certain quality of life that Masons give for their residents. Grand Master Punt was a Past Master of his Lodge, a member of the Scottish Rite (33 degree), a Shriner, a former Director of the Masonic Medical Research Laboratory, a former Trustee of the Masonic Hall and Home, and the holder of the Active DeMolay Legion of Honor. From 1977 to 1984. he served as Chairman of the Masonic Home Building Fund (Think Big and Build Campaign) which realized close to $15 million. He served as Chief Commissioner of Appeals for Grand Lodge, and four years as Grand Representative for India following his appointment in 1982. Brother Punt held innumerable honorary memberships in Lodges throughout the State and was the recipient of the Charles Henry Johnson Medal in 1982. Brother Punt and his wife, Elsie, were Floral Park residents for 31 years and attend Hillside United Methodist Church, New Hyde Park, where he served as Trustee and Finance Chairman and a lay speaker. Predeceased by his son Robert in 1995, William Punt is survived by his wife Elsie, a daughter, Bonita, four grandchildren and nine great-granddaughters and two great-great grandsons. On behalf of the Grand Lodge, the entire Grand Line of Officers and the Trustee of the Masonic Hall and Home, extend condolences to the Punt family, as well as to his Masonic Brothers. M.W. Edward R. Trosin, Grand Master R.W. Gilbert Savitzky, Grand Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINTON, LAURIE ANN
description: LINTON--Laurie Ann. On January 10, 2005, in New York City, at the age of 46, after a long illness. Laurie is survived by her brother Robert, her longtime companion, Murphy, and a host of beloved friends. Laurie was a native--and devoted--New Yorker. A graduate of Hunter College High School, Wesleyan University, and Columbia Law School, Laurie began as a litigator at Weil, Gotshal & Manges. She then turned her attention to the public sector, where she spent the remainder of her career dedicated to serving the people of New York. In positions with the Attorney General's Office, the NYC Human Resources Administration, the NYC Comptroller's Office, and as counsel to the Governor's Office under Mario Cuomo, Laurie's work affected everything from campaign finance legislation to welfare reform, the state budget to charities fraud. Laurie's contribution as an activist in the gay and lesbian community was, if possible, even more profound. She was a founder and board member of the Empire State Pride Agenda, and was instrumental in their work to pass both the Hate Crimes Bill and the Sexual Orientation Nondiscrimination Act. She also served as a Director of the Lesbian and Gay Law Association of Greater New York, and was, until her death, Vice President of the Stonewall Community Foundation's Board of Directors. The vast legion of people who counted her as their very good friend will miss her, and they would agree: her enormous love of life was surpassed only by her generosity of spirit. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, January 12, at 9:30am at "The Riverside," 76 St & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, Laurie wished donations to be made to the Stonewall Community Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEIMER, PAUL K. DR.
description: WEIMER--Paul K. Dr. Paul K. Weimer, a contributor to the development of television technology, died on January 6 in Princeton, NJ at the age of 90. In 1942 he joined the RCA laboratory facility in Princeton where he worked until retirement in 1981. His first assignment, in collaboration with Dr. Albert Rose and Dr. Harold Law, was to develop a new type of television camera tube called the "Image Orthicon". This tube, which proved to be 100 times more sensitive than its predecessors, was used for the first 20 years of television broadcasting in the United States. Dr. Weimer was made a Fellow of the Institute for Radio Engineers in 1955 and was later awarded the IRE Television Prize for his work on camera tubes based on photoconductivity. In 1963 he received an individual RCA David Sarnoff Outstanding Achievement Award in Science for his work leading to extended applications for evaporated thin films. His leadership in the development of the thin-film transistor (TFT), and its use in integrated circuits led to his receiving the 1966 IEEE Morris N. Liebman Memorial Award. Other honors included election to the National Academy of Engineering (NAE) in 1981, and the 1986 "Kultur Preis" award of the German Photographic Society for his early work on solidstate television cameras. While working at RCA, Dr. Weimer was granted over 90 U.S. patents. In 1991 he shared with Dr. Albert Rose (then deceased) a Pioneer Award by the New Jersey Inventors Congress and Hall of Fame. Dr. Weimer was born in Wabash, IA. He received a B.A. in math and physics from Manchester College (1936), an M.A. in physics from the University of Kansas (1938) and a PhD in physics from Ohio State University (1942). Paul Weimer was an amateur violinist and enjoyed playing string quartets with friends on a regular basis. He was a member of the Nassau Presbyterian Church and the Old Guard of Princeton. Husband of the late Katherine E. Weimer, he is survived by three daughters: Katherine Lasslob of Chalfont, PA, Barbara J. Blackwell and Patricia W. Hess, both of Princeton, eight grandchildren and his sister, Wilodean Rakestraw of Rochester, IN. A memorial service will be held in the spring.

The moves are expected to save about $6 million a year, Tupperware said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: US Airways Executive Said to Be Leaving
description: B. Ben Baldanza, the top-ranking marketing executive at US Airways, is set to leave the troubled carrier to join Spirit Airlines, the trade publication Aviation Daily reported last night.

World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic Trial Resumes
description: After a three-week recess, Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, reappeared in the dock at his war crimes trial, where he is defending himself, evidently pleased with the testimony of his witness, ve Crpin, a French nurse. In response to his questions, she spoke at length about the "suffering of the Serbs" in the 1990's wars in Yugoslavia, where she worked for the United Nations and others. But the presiding judge, Patrick Robinson of Jamaica, called her testimony hearsay and demanded more focus and relevance to the charges against Mr. Milosevic, which include genocide. The judge said that the hearing had sounded "like a conversation over a cup of tea on the veranda." Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Second Rail Accident Attributed to Switch Left in Wrong Position
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 11 - The Federal Railroad Administration on Tuesday attributed a second derailment to the cause that is suspected in the chlorine tank car wreck near here, a hand-operated switch left in the wrong position. It also advised the railroads to make their crews fill out a new form documenting the switch position when operating in areas without electronic signals.

It is a coeducational society that offers off-campus housing, not a fraternity.

title: In New Jersey, a Defining Moment for a New Chief Executive
description: TRENTON, Jan. 11 - Vowing to restore "stability and dignity" to New Jersey's State House, Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey told a joint session of the Legislature on Tuesday that he would lead state government past its recent spate of corruption scandals by tightening ethics regulations and using the power of government to aid struggling families, the elderly and the mentally ill.

title: Regents Approve New Math Criteria for Grades Below High School
description: Reacting to problems with the Regents math exam in 2003, the Board of Regents unanimously approved broad new math standards yesterday for elementary and middle schools across New York State. The board recommended more attention to the fundamentals for young students and a greater focus on specific concepts in the higher grades.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent And Alvarion Plan WiMax Offerings
description: Lucent Technologies, the nation's largest maker of telephone equipment, said yesterday that it was teaming up with Alvarion Ltd., of Tel Aviv, to offer equipment that would provide connections between wireless and fixed-line networks. The partnership with Alvarion, a maker of broadband wireless access technology, will help promote the WiMax standard, which is used for equipment providing long-range wireless broadband, said Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J. Alvarion was chosen by Intel in July 2003 to help it develop a chip using the WiMax standard and said last week that it had developed its first mobile WiMax product. The product will probably be sold starting in 2006 when the first WiMax-enabled laptops become available.

title: Intel, Citing Brisk Demand, Posts 10% Rise in Revenue
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11 - Intel, the world's largest computer chip maker, reported strong demand for its products on Tuesday, a day after a main Silicon Valley rival, Advanced Micro Devices, warned that it expected to report lower profits because of a price war with Intel in the flash memory market.

description: Dressed in a white robe and hat and playing his grandfather's kora, the traditional harp-guitar of West African griots, Mory Kante performed his first New York City concert in 14 years on Friday night at S.O.B.'s with a band of acoustic instruments. It wasn't traditional music; it was Mr. Kante's latest, and best, pop hybrid.

title: Going to Spain for Lunch
description: A sandwich of grilled chicken with garlic mayonnaise, another with grilled vegetables lashed with romesco sauce, and a hot combination of pork loin in adobo seasonings with cheese and piquillo peppers are a few of the bocadillos, or Spanish sandwiches, being sold ($6 to $7) at Sala One-Nine, 35 West 19th Street; (212) 229-2300. It is a branch of Sala on the Bowery, which opened last month. The owner, Michael Jannetta, said he wanted to offer the kinds of quick lunches he remembered from living in Spain. Salads and soups ($5 to $8) are also available to eat at small bar tables, to take out or to order for delivery.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Congressman 'Optimistic'
description: Representative Tom Lantos of California, returning from three days of talks in North Korea, said in Beijing that officials in Pyongyang would not commit to resuming negotiations on their nuclear weapons program until they assessed changes in the second Bush administration. Mr. Lantos, the ranking Democrat on the House International Relations Committee, said he had met with officials in the Foreign Ministry, as well as a vice president of the Supreme People's Assembly, and had repeatedly told his hosts that American policy toward North Korea had bipartisan support in Congress and would not change in the new Bush administration. He said that despite their unwillingness to commit to new talks, "I am considerably more optimistic than when I left Beijing three days ago." Jim Yardley (NYT)

description: SORBO SERPICO, Italy - ROLLING hills carpeted with vineyards surround this tiny village in the Irpinia region of Campania here in southern Italy, where the landscape has hardly changed for centuries. Then it hits your eye, a sleek structure of glass, brushed steel and concrete, Feudi di San Gregorio's new $25 million winery and hospitality center, as likely a feature of this countryside as an alien spaceship.

U.P.S. LOWERS FOURTH-QUARTER PROFIT FORECAST
description: United Parcel Service, the delivery company, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit was less than it expected because the growth of package shipments slowed in the final week of 2004 and storms in the Midwest raised costs. Profit, excluding a gain from a tax benefit, was 75 cents to 76 cents a share, United Parcel said, down from a previous forecast of 83 cents to 87 cents. Net income in the quarter was 84 cents to 87 cents a share, the company said. In the same quarter a year earlier, U.P.S. earned $856 million, or 75 cents a share. Shipping volume rose 1.6 percent in the quarter, less than an earlier estimate of 2.5 percent, United Parcel said. The company, based in Atlanta, did not say how much the severe weather in the Midwest had raised costs.

Metro Briefing | New York: M.T.A. Proposes Dropping No. 9 Train
description: New York City Transit officials yesterday proposed restoring all local stops on the No. 1 train in upper Manhattan and the Bronx. This would eliminate the need for the No. 9 train, which now operates during the weekday commuter rush. Beginning in 1989, when the "skip-stop" service was introduced for weekday daytime hours, the lines alternately skipped stations between 137th Street in Manhattan and 242nd Street-Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. But three stations -- 125th, 181st and 191st Streets -- have since been added as all-day stops, and midday skip-stop service was discontinued in 1994. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: The Neediest Cases; Trying, on a Tight Budget, to Be Both a Father and a Mother
description: Here, in this narrow apartment in Harlem where pictures of the Virgin Mary adorn the walls, the most important object might just be a spiral-bound notebook that Greg Aparicio and his son, Chris, share. It is a book of secrets, wishes and favorite things where father and son pose questions to one another and write answers too personal to print in a newspaper. This is their way of staying close.

title: Fodder for Reform's Cynics, and a Blot on Bipartisanship
description: TWICE upon a time, or at least twice within the past dozen years, an American president issued the audacious promise to solve a seemingly intractable social problem. title: Arts, Briefly; 'Medium' Is Ratings Magic
description: According to Nielsen's overnight ratings, Monday night's primetime programming was a close race among CBS, NBC and Fox. CBS, which broadcast a night of repeats, had the most households; NBC had the most total viewers and won the 18-to-49 demographic; Fox lost the 18-to-49 by a hair and was a close third in total viewers. These numbers represent improved outlooks for Fox and NBC, both of which spent the fall season flailing. In NBC's case, the Monday turnaround can be pinpointed to the network's new psychic friend: "Medium," starring Patricia Arquette, above. An audience of 16.29 million watched the supernatural mystery's second episode, making it the night's biggest draw. Fox's prime time hours were devoted to another two-hour episode of "24," which attracted a smaller audience than the splashy premiere the previous night: 12.57 million against 14.85 million. But that was enough to make Fox a contender with its regular Monday programming for the first time this season. KATE AURTHUR

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Elderly In Street Protests
description: Pensioners held scattered demonstrations for a third day to protest the government's replacement of Soviet-era social benefits with cash payments. Protests were reported in Barnual in Siberia, Togliatti on the Volga River and in other cities after similar ones on Sunday and Monday in an unusual expression of public discontent with President Vladimir V. Putin's government. On Monday, several hundred elderly demonstrators gathered at the outskirts of Moscow and briefly blocked the main highway to St. Petersburg; 12 were arrested. On Jan. 1, the government began replacing benefits like free transportation, prescriptions and housing for pensioners and the disabled with cash payments of $20 to $120 a month, which critics argue are too meager to compensate for the lost benefits. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: A New Hybrid Citrus Finds Its Way To the Table
description: Mandarinquat is the clunky if accurate name coined for this small citrus hybrid, a cross between a mandarin orange and a kumquat (shown left at twice its size). It is similar to calamansi, an ancient Asian cross between the two fruits that is rounder and often green, and tastes pretty much the same. Each mandarinquat yields a generous tablespoon of lip-smacking, tart juice. It is a good substitute for Seville or sour oranges in dishes like duck  l'orange. The skin, however, has the tender sweetness of kumquat, so simmer strips of the peel in sugar syrup to garnish the duck. A pound of them, easily a dozen, is $9.99 at Agata & Valentina and the Orchard in Midwood, Brooklyn, and $12.99 at Eli's Manhattan and the Vinegar Factory.

The strike involves 600 drivers and other workers for the Command Bus Company of East New York, Brooklyn, and Green Bus Lines of Jamaica, Queens. The city wants to take over the private bus companies, but their workers are worried about pay and health care benefits. A meeting is scheduled for tomorrow between city negotiators and union officials. John Longo, president of Local 1179 of the Amalgamated Transit Union, said a new contract was not on the agenda, but a spokesman for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that the goal was "to address their grievances and to settle the strike." Nicholas Confessore (NYT)

title: Some Hearty Pasta For Hearty Weather
description: This is the time of year to come home to a bowl of earthy, rustic pasta tossed with chunks of sausage and bold, garlicky sauted broccoli rabe beneath a drift of tangy pecorino. An excellent choice for the pasta would be the artisanal brand Latini, especially its nutty-tasting farro pasta, made with spelt, an ancient wheatlike grain. The pasta is cut on traditional bronze dies, resulting in a rough texture designed to sop up the ingredients that dress it. At www.gustiamo.com, 10 shapes of farro pasta are available, each $6.50 for a 1.1-pound box plus shipping. For sausage, the short mezzi rigatoni is best. But the pastas also take beautifully to thick vegetable-based sauces and sturdy ragus made with canned San Marzano tomatoes. And your classic carbonara will never be the same. It's worth noting that farro pasta cooks faster than regular pasta, so shave a couple of minutes off the boiling.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Industrial Output Falls
description: Industrial pro-duction in Brazil fell slightly in November from the previous month, suggesting that economic growth slowed in the last quarter of 2004 after a series of interest rate increases. The government's statistics agency said output slipped 0.4 percent in November from October, dragged down by a 7.5 percent drop in pharmaceuticals production. But measured year to year, industrial output increased for the 15th consecutive month, rising 8.1 percent from November 2003, when Brazil was trying to recover from a recession. The drop in industrial activity prompted some economists to predict that the central bank might raise interest rates only slightly at its next monetary policy meeting. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: XTO ENERGY TO PURCHASE ANTERO RESOURCES
description: XTO Energy, a natural gas producer, agreed yesterday to purchase the Antero Resources Corporation, a privately held natural gas producer. XTO, based in Fort Worth, said it would pay $337.5 million in cash, 10 million shares and warrants for an additional 1.5 million shares. Antero, based in Denver, has 440 billion cubic feet of proven gas reserves and output of 60 million cubic feet a day, XTO said. The purchase will give XTO access to one of the largest gas fields in the nation, the Barnett Shale region north of Fort Worth, where the gas deposits are hidden beneath up to 800 feet of rock. Because of the purchase, XTO raised its 2005 target for output growth to 21 percent to 23 percent, from 18 percent to 20 percent. XTO shares rose 16 cents to $33.20.

Technology Briefing | Hardware: Unisys To Post Loss On Contract Write-Off
description: The Unisys Corporation, which sells server computers and consulting services, had an unexpected loss in the fourth quarter after the company wrote off costs from a contract. The shares fell as much as 9.5 percent. The loss totaled 7 cents to 10 cents a share, the company, based in Blue Bell, Pa., said yesterday. The company had forecast a profit of 27 cents to 31 cents. Unisys said it had pretax costs of $120 million for the write-off. Sales also trailed analysts' estimates, in part because the company changed how it accounted for a large order. Revenue in the fourth quarter fell to $1.52 billion to $1.53 billion, 7 percent less than in the year-earlier period, Unisys said. Analysts on average expected $1.71 billion, according to Thomson First Call. Unisys said last month that it would not meet analysts' earnings estimates for 2005 because of slow growth in technology spending. The company is cutting 1,400 jobs by the end of the second quarter. Unisys's net income has declined year over year for the last three quarters and will continue to drop in the next two periods, according to Thomson First Call. Shares of Unisys fell 56 cents, or 6 percent, to $8.75. Unisys will release final fourth-quarter results on Jan. 25.

title: Arts, Briefly; Two Singers, One Voice
description: Extra drama was injected into a performance of Wagner's "Rheingold" at the Royal Opera in Covent Garden in London on Monday when the Welsh bass-baritone Bryn Terfel, left, lost his voice and was unable to sing Wotan. But the opera house was determined that the show go on, and a frantic search for a replacement ensued. Elaine Padmore, Covent Garden's director of opera, said: "Efforts to fly in other singers from Germany were thwarted by flight cancellations due to high winds. But then things improved a bit when we discovered that someone who had just landed at Gatwick was the famous Wotan of many past Ring cycles here, Sir Donald McIntyre." Because there was no time to rehearse, and the production involved a moving set and climbing up ladders, Sir Donald, 70, who most recently performed in the "Ring" last year at the Longborough Festival, sang from the pit, while Mr. Terfel acted the role onstage. title: From the Show Floor: Bells, Whistles and Bluetooth

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Bail For Pinochet
description: An appeals court authorized Gen. Augusto Pinochet's release from house arrest on bail of $3,500 in connection with a case in which the 89-year-old former dictator has been ruled fit to stand trial on 10 counts of kidnapping and murder. But the same panel unanimously refused a request by an Argentine judge that General Pinochet also be stripped of his blanket immunity from prosecution in order to be questioned in another murder case, that of the 1974 assassination in Buenos Aires of his predecessor as military commander, Gen. Carlos Prats. Larry Rohter (NYT)

Foster's Buys 18.8 Percent of Rival Australian Winemaker
description: The Foster's Group Ltd., Australia's biggest brewer and winemaker, has bought an 18.8 percent stake in Southcorp Ltd., prompting speculation that it planned a takeover bid of at least 3.1 billion Australian dollars ($2.4 billion) to gain control of top-selling brands like Penfolds and Rosemount.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Pilots To Be Briefed On Lasers
description: Secretary of Transportation Norman Y. Mineta announced new measures to alert and prepare pilots for the possibility of lasers being shined at their airplanes and to streamline the process of investigating such incidents in an effort to prosecute those involved. Since Dec. 23, Mr. Mineta said, the authorities have received 31 reports of lasers shined into the cockpits of airplanes as they were taking off or about to land at airports around the country. Pilots have said they were temporarily distracted by the beams. Mr. Mineta, who spoke at an aeronautical research center in Oklahoma City, said he did not think the episodes were related to terrorism. John Files (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the civil rights leader James Forman yesterday misstated a word in describing his call, in 1969, for reparations to be paid by Protestant and Jewish groups for the crimes of slavery. Mr. Forman asked for $500 million for crimes perpetrated against generations of blacks, not "by" them.

description: BANDA ACEH, Indonesia, Jan. 12 - Indonesia announced Wednesday that all foreign troops assisting in the relief operation must leave by late March.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Kyocera Cuts 600 Jobs In San Diego
description: The Kyocera Corporation, which makes electronics and telecommunications equipment, said yesterday that it would eliminate 600 jobs in San Diego by the end of March as it moves manufacturing and service operations abroad. The action is being taken "because manufacturing in La Jolla, Calif., is cost-prohibitive," James Kelly, chief operating officer for Kyocera Wireless, said. Shifting most of the manufacturing operations to a Kyocera plant in Tijuana, Mexico, will lead to the elimination of about 450 manufacturing jobs at the San Diego headquarters, Kyocera said. A further 150 jobs in San Diego will be cut as more of Kyocera's global service centers take on service and repair work, the company said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: U.S. Turns Away N.Y.-Bound Flight
description: Three hours after it left Heathrow in London for Kennedy Airport in New York, a British Airways Boeing 747 turned back to Britain when American authorities said they would not allow one of it 239 pasengers to disembark. The United States Transportation Security Administration said the name of a passenger traveling on a French passport matched a name on an anti-terrorism watch list. The passenger manifest for the flight, BA175, had been transmitted to American authorities after the plane left London, standard procedure for international flights leaving for the United States. The suspect passenger was interviewed for two hours by British police officers on his return to London and was later set free. A British Airways spokesman said passengers were rescreened, and the plane took off again for New York. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: The Tsunamis and Child Trafficking
description: Children were one-third of the casualties of the tsunamis, and those who survived are suffering the worst effects of their aftermath. Untold thousands have been orphaned or separated from their families. Without protection or caregivers, they are at greatest risk for starvation and disease. They are also in danger from human traffickers, who have long operated in South Asia with near impunity, and who must have viewed the tsunamis as providing an opportunity to prey. Amazingly, these criminals seem to have been largely stymied by governments determined to prevent further tragedy. In a region devoid of cheer, this is at least a hopeful moment.

title: In Turin, Olympics, Italian Style
description: TURIN, Italy - Looming over the Piazza Castello, a vast square in Turin's heart where elaborate nightly medal presentations will be staged during the 2006 Winter Olympics, is a 100-foot-high castle incorporating Roman, Renaissance and Baroque architecture. Across nearly eight centuries of the city's history, layer upon layer was added to the Palazzo Madama, a simultaneous tribute to change and tradition.

title: The international court in decline
Knicks Still Trying to Get the Message
description: In an inspired moment in late November, Isiah Thomas composed a manifesto for winning. Once typed and formatted, the font just right, the screed was photocopied and framed, and a copy was hung in every Knick's locker stall at Madison Square Garden.

title: Hong Kong's Leader Apologizes but Promises to Remain in Office
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 12 - Facing broad public dissatisfaction and renewed speculation over whether he might step down, Hong Kong's leader made several apologies on Wednesday for his governance but promised to remain in office.

description: FORT HOOD, Tex., Jan. 12 - Interrogators at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq gave the military police orders to "soften up" or give harsh treatment to detainees in the weeks leading up to the night that a group of soldiers put naked and hooded prisoners in sexually humiliating positions and photographed them, several soldiers and a detainee testified in a military court here on Wednesday.

title: A King, His Castle and His Bishop Hold Court and Shadows Flee
description: The city of Glendale wanted to make a dim passageway between a parking garage and its main street, Brand Boulevard, safer and more welcoming. A local group of chess enthusiasts, meanwhile, wanted an outdoor spot to play and to hold competitions. So the city commissioned Rios Clementi Hale Studios, an architectural and design firm in Los Angeles, to turn the space, which measures 30 by 150 feet, into the Chess Park. Samantha Harris and Anthony Paradowski, designers at the firm, created giant sculptural chess pieces including a rook, a bishop and a king (from left to right above). The pieces, which are covered in canvas, provide lighting for the park, and a stage allows for theatrical and musical performances. Chess pieces for play can be borrowed from a nearby bookstore.

title: Dictators beware!
Baseball: Fresh produce for the Big Apple
ZEON UNIT PLEADS GUILTY TO JUSTICE DEPT. CHARGES
description: A unit of the Zeon Corporation agreed to pay a fine of $10.5 million and plead guilty to charges of fixing prices of a synthetic rubber that is used to make auto parts, hoses, belts and adhesives, the Justice Department said yesterday. The unit, Zeon Chemicals of Louisville, Ky., will admit that it conspired with other companies between May 2002 and December 2002 to eliminate competition in the market for acrylonitrile-butadiene. Zeon Chemicals said that it cooperated with the investigation and established a reserve in the fourth quarter of 2004 to pay the fine. In October, Bayer agreed to plead guilty and pay a $4.7 million fine for participating in the conspiracy.

description: God does not play dice with the universe, but Universal Studios is playing God with the dice.

title: Arts, Briefly; No Cameras at Jackson Trial? Just Hire Some Actors
description: E! Entertainment, a cable channel that traffics heavily in celebrity scandal, isn't letting a little thing like a camera ban get in the way of its coverage of the Michael Jackson, right, molestation trial. Using court transcripts, E!, in conjunction with British Sky Broadcasting, says it will broadcast daily re-enactments of the trial. The five daily half-hour programs are to begin on Jan. 31 in more than 50 countries. In addition to the re-enactments, legal analysts will provide commentary. No word yet on what actor will be cast to play Mr. Jackson. LOLA OGUNNAIKE

title: Jordan's Guests, Deeply Palestinian and Deeply Skeptical

description: The Minnesota Vikings' owner, Red McCombs, asked Fox Sports yesterday to remove Joe Buck from calling the divisional playoff game in Philadelphia because of critical remarks he made about Randy Moss last Sunday.

description: PARIS, Jan. 12 - President Jacques Chirac took an important symbolic step on Wednesday toward repairing France's tattered relationship with Iraq, welcoming his Iraqi counterpart for a four-day visit.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Request For Aid After Train Crash
description: Gov. Mark Sanford has asked for federal disaster assistance for Aiken County in recovering from the train crash and chlorine leak in Graniteville last Thursday, which killed nine people and sent hundreds to hospitals. The leak forced about 5,400 residents to leave, and they have been kept from their homes for a week. The authorities would allow half of those residents to return today, since crews had finished transferring the remaining chlorine from two damaged cars, said Susan Terpay, a spokeswoman for Norfolk Southern, which operated the train. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: A Censorship Story Goes Up in Smoke
description: LONDON, Jan. 12 - The story has been around so long that it has acquired the patina of truth: how the prudish Victorian critic John Ruskin was so horrified by the erotic drawings left behind by the artist J.M.W. Turner that, like some 19th-century Savonarola, he burned them on a bonfire after Turner's death.

description: Former President Bill Clinton's best-selling memoir, "My Life," will be published this summer in two paperback formats, his publisher announced yesterday.

title: Pakistan's Army to Confront Nationalists in the Southwest
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 12 - Army troops have been sent to Pakistan's largest natural gas field, in southwestern Baluchistan, after attacks by Baluchi nationalists forced the authorities to close the plant, officials said Wednesday. Pakistan pledged tough action against the nationalists, who are demanding greater royalties for the gas extracted in their area.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Jury Deliberates In Terror Trial
description: The jurors in the trial of Lynne F. Stewart, a lawyer accused of aiding terrorism, began to deliberate yesterday, after the judge cautioned that they could not convict on the basis of her political views. The decisions must be unanimous on 16 questions concerning Ms. Stewart and two co-defendants, Ahmed Abdel Sattar and Mohamed Yousry, who are charged with conspiring to lie to the government and to help terrorists in Egypt. Judge John G. Koeltl, who read 139 pages of instructions, told them that "expression of opinion alone, even an opinion advocating violence, is not a crime in this country." Julia Preston (NYT)

title: BORDERS RAISES FORECAST FOR FOURTH-QUARTER EARNINGS
description: Borders Group, the bookstore chain, said it would post net income of $1.60 to $1.62 a share for the fourth quarter after holiday sales rose more than it expected. The projection compares with its earlier forecast of $1.55 to $1.62, the company said. Borders, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., had net income of $119.8 million, or $1.50 a share, in the fourth quarter a year ago. Total sales rose 4.8 percent from Oct. 25 through Jan. 9, while sales at superstores open at least a year increased 1.4 percent during the holiday period. Sales also rose at Borders stores overseas, helped by a weaker dollar. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected Borders to earn $1.58 a share in the quarter.

description: Ever so gradually, the big payoff in wages from a college education is losing its steam, which calls into question the emphasis that the White House, under both Bill Clinton and George W. Bush, has placed on a bachelor's degree as a sure-fire avenue to constantly rising incomes.

The transaction will close in Cisco's third quarter, which ends April 30. Both companies are based in San Jose, Calif. Shares of Cisco rose 29 cents, to $18.93.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: West Orange: Codey Seeks Stem-Cell Speed
description: Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey, expanding his proposal for increased state funds for stem-cell research, said yesterday that he wanted to distribute grant money over 7 years instead of the usual 10, to put New Jersey in a better position to compete for research talent and investment. Mr. Codey announced in his State of the State address on Tuesday that he planned to allocate $150 million in unspent bond money to build and equip the new Stem Cell Institute of New Jersey and that he would ask voters' approval for $230 million in research grants. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: Saudi Court Orders Lashings for 15 Demonstrators
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Jan. 12 - In a rare public display, the Saudi government announced on Tuesday that a religious court had sentenced 15 demonstrators, including one woman, to public lashings and prison terms for taking part in demonstrations against the government.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Consumer Confidence Rises
description: Rising share prices, cheaper gasoline and increased employment helped spur consumer confidence in Australia this month to its highest level in almost 11 years, according to a survey. The consumer confidence index rose to 123.5, a 4.2 percent increase from December and the highest figure since June 1994, according to the survey, which was conducted by the Westpac Banking Corporation and the Melbourne Institute. A reading above 100 shows that optimists outnumber pessimists. Confidence is at the second-highest level in the 30-year history of the survey.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Cull Weighed After New Mad Cow Case
description: Alberta's premier, Ralph Klein, left, said that a cull of older cattle may be necessary to manage the mad cow crisis in Canada, after two cows tested positive for the disease in the last 10 days. He offered no details as to how many animals might be culled, but the fact that such an action is being considered shows how seriously the industry is reacting to the outbreak and to the possibility that the United States might not reopen the border to imports of young Canadian cattle in March, as announced two weeks ago. The latest cow found to be infected was born months after restrictions on feed were put in place to prevent mad cow disease, raising new concerns about the the effectiveness of Canada's feed regulations. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Chairman of TiVo Decides to Let Someone Else Be Chief
description: Michael Ramsay, a founder of TiVo, the most prominent developer of digital video recorders, said yesterday that he would resign as chief executive but remain chairman.

title: Two Weeks, Two Big Shows
The Rams and Martz Regroup Just in Time
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga., Jan. 12 - The St. Louis Rams looked like a broken team last month. Hours before a game against the Arizona Cardinals, there were news reports that Coach Mike Martz could be fired. Martz fumed, calling the reports irresponsible and destructive. The Rams went out and were trounced by the Cardinals, 31-7, dropping their record to 6-8.

With just a moment to act, she grabbed her little girl but could not manage to carry her older son, Mohamed, who drowned.

description: After just two months on the job, Brian Anderson, the chief financial officer of OfficeMax, resigned yesterday, less than a month after the company announced that it had uncovered improprieties in the way it accounted for rebates from a large supplier. title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Explanation Not Needed In Smuggling Case
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit overturned a district judge's order that the Justice Department explain whether race was a factor in its decision to seek the death penalty in a 2003 alien-smuggling case. The judge, Vanessa D. Williams of Federal District Court in Houston, had said that unless prosecutors complied with her order, she would inform jurors of the government's refusal and allow them to weigh it in the penalty phase of the trial should they convict the defendant, Tyrone M. Williams. The appeals delayed the trial of Mr. Williams, 33, a driver accused of abandoning a truck in which more than 70 illegal immigrants were locked. Nineteen of them died of heat exhaustion. Mr. Williams, who is black, is the only one of 14 defendants in the incident, which occurred at Victoria, who was charged with an offense punishable by death. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: FIVE SENIOR EXECUTIVES HAVE LEFT US AIRWAYS
description: US Airways said yesterday that five senior executives have recently left or retired from the airline, which is in bankruptcy protection for the second time in two years. The executives include B. Ben Baldanza, the airline's senior vice president for marketing and planning, who joined Spirit Airlines as its president and chief operating officer. US Airways said Mr. Baldanza would be succeeded by Bruce Ashby, the president of US Airways Express, the company's commuter airline. The company said the others departing were Kathleen Harris, a vice president and deputy general counsel, who left in December; William Bozin, the vice president for safety and regulatory compliance; Eilif Serck-Hanssen, vice president for finance; and Richard E. Pfennig, president of US Airways Express. Micheline Maynard (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENSON, GUY KENNETH
description: BENSON--Guy Kenneth. Died peacefully on January 4, 2005 at age 84. He lived for 46 years in the Hudson River town of Dobbs Ferry, NY. There he and his wife, Philippa Day of Sydney, Australia raised their three children. He attended Lawrenceville School and Yale College, served in the Army in Europe during World War II, and was Vice President of Trident Films. He will be sorely missed by all who knew his extraordinary and persistent intelligence, humor, wit, patience, and stubborness. A memorial service will be held on January 22 at 2PM at South Church in Dobbs Ferry.

U.S. Trade Deficit Rises to New High; More Risk to Dollar
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 - The United States trade deficit soared to a monthly record of $60.3 billion in November, the Commerce Department reported on Wednesday. The figure confounded predictions that the deficit would diminish with the weakening of the dollar and an easing in the price of oil.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Study Predicts Increase In Truck Traffic
description: Truck traffic on the roads of New Jersey could increase by 80 percent over the next 15 years, according to a study released yesterday by the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, a group that advocates more government spending on the region's freight-rail network. By 2020, trucks could be traveling 15 million miles a day in New Jersey, making streets and highways more crowded and dangerous, the report concludes. The wear and tear from heavy trucks, each of which causes as much damage to roads as 2,000 to 3,000 cars, could cost as much as $3.7 billion a year by 2020, the report estimates. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

title: Bloomberg From the Block
description: In a State of the City address this week that served as a kind of opening bell for his re-election campaign, Mayor Michael Bloomberg was lively, charming, persuasive and, at points, even tough. And he seemed right at home, even though he was not in Manhattan, but in the Bronx -- the borough of Jennifer Lopez, as he noted. When he spoke a little Spanish, the translation was less important than its real meaning. It was a brazen notice to a field of Democratic mayoral hopefuls in a decidedly Democratic town: be afraid -- be very afraid.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Agency to Issue O'Hare Expansion Plan Early
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 12 - The Federal Aviation Administration will issue a 5,000-page analysis of the city's plan to expand O'Hare International Airport on Thursday, a month ahead of schedule, a step that Mayor Richard M. Daley said "moves us closer to accomplishing our goal of dramatically improving the nation's busiest airport."

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: SBC And Hewlett Form Alliance
description: SBC Communications and the Hewlett-Packard Company have entered an alliance to develop and market products and services jointly, the companies said yesterday. The nonexclusive deal represents SBC's first alliance with a hardware maker and Hewlett's first North American alliance with a telecommunications company. Under the deal, the companies will begin to market their services and products jointly during the first quarter. Corporate customers will largely receive a single point of contact and a single bill, depending on whether there is an existing sales relationship with either company, Jason Hillery, an SBC spokesman, said. During the first half of the year, the companies will also begin to develop joint offerings. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: New York, Connecticut and New Jersey
Corrections
description: An obituary last Thursday about Dr. Maclyn McCarty, the last surviving member of the medical team that demonstrated in the 1940's that genes are made of DNA, misstated what was known at the time about the pneumococcus bacterium, which the team used in its experiments. Scientists knew that the rough form of the bacterium was NOT virulent. The article also misstated a procedure in the experiments. The inherited factor that proved to be DNA was transferred from the virulent (or smooth) form of the bacteria to the nonvirulent (rough) form, not the reverse.

title: When Dinosaurs Ruled, a Mammal Ate (a Little) One
description: In the time of dinosaurs, mammals were the meek that had yet to inherit the earth. They were small creatures, many no bigger than mice, and essentially nocturnal, feeding mainly on insects and cowering in holes and underbrush from the terrible tread of the reptilian lords of the land.

Apple Tries to Break Out
description: Apple Computer's classic advertisements urge buyers to "think different," and this week the company took its own advice. It broke with its longstanding policy of catering to the connoisseurs of high-end cool and unveiled both a $499 desktop computer, called the Mac Mini, and a $99 stripped-down version of the iPod digital music player. We'll see whether the strategy works, but it's interesting to see a company whose customers have always regarded themselves as a lonely elite deciding to try a new direction.

title: Arts, Briefly; Wining, Dining, Reading
description: People who like to eat, drink and talk about books -- all at the same time -- are in for a treat. Starting tonight and running through June 9, the Brooklyn Academy of Music will hold a monthly evening of dinner and music that ends with a reading and a discussion with a prominent writer. The six evenings begin with Rick Moody, followed by Paul Auster, Walter Mosley, Jhumpa Lahiri, Joyce Carol Oates and Edward P. Jones, above. The playwright Wendy Wasserstein will moderate the first three, and the journalist and novelist Tour will lead the rest. The evenings, titled "Eat, Drink & Be Literary: Dinner & a Reading at BAMcaf" begin with wine and live music, followed by a buffet; the literary program follows. FELICIA R. LEE

Today, amends were finally made when Britain's Architecture Foundation picked Ms. Hadid's striking geometric design for its new exhibition center on London's South Bank. The pavilion, due to open in late 2006, will be her first permanent building in London.

title: Meeting Death With a Cool Heart
description: Bangkok - IN 22 years of using Bangkok's airport, Don Muang, the busiest in Southeast Asia, I have never known it to be anything but crowded. On New Year's Eve, five days after the tsunami that devastated Phuket and much of the rest of southern Thailand, it was empty. I called friends from the airport, and found that nobody I knew had died; but everyone knew someone who was missing, from every walk of life: businessmen, prostitutes, dealers in marijuana, doctors, politicians. The tsunami made no social distinctions.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Guilty Plea In Museum Theft
description: An employee accused of stealing more than $850,000 from the Whitney Museum pleaded guilty yesterday to grand larceny charges. Justice Gregory Carro of State Supreme Court in Manhattan sentenced the woman, Naseem Wahlah, to 200 hours of community service over the objections of the Manhattan district attorney's office, which had requested a tougher sentence. Ms. Wahlah, who worked as the museum's manager of visitor services, has repaid much of what she stole. Another former museum employee, Rowan Foley, pleaded guilty in August to grand larceny and was sentenced to five years of probation, the district attorney's office said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

Arts, Briefly; 'Loser' Is a Winner
description: In Tuesday's battle of the reality finales, there was one big fat loser: a mere 3.73 million viewers watched the two-hour finale of Fox's "Rebel Billionaire." In contrast, NBC's weight-loss show "The Biggest Loser" brought in 13.74 million viewers over its 90 minutes. At the final weigh-in, broadcast live, Ryan Benson won the $250,000 prize, having lost 122 pounds since the show began. For its final half-hour, the number of viewers of "The Biggest Loser" spiked to 15.55 million, which helped NBC win the Nielsen overnight ratings competition. NBC was also helped by a new episode of "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit," which drew an audience of 15.98 million, making it the night's most-watched show. KATE AURTHUR

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Shot To Death
description: A 38-year-old man died yesterday after being shot twice in the torso and once in each arm as he sat in a minivan in front of 2546 Creston Avenue in Fordham, the police said. A neighbor, Mary Ganley, identified the man only by a first name, Nelson. She said that just before the shooting, which occurred a few minutes before 6 p.m., she looked through a window and saw him get into the minivan while speaking to a friend when four shots rang out. Ms. Ganley, a retired nurse, ran outside and took his pulse, but he was already dead, she said. She said he had grown up on the block and visited frequently. Michelle O'Donnell

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Visa Bar To The 'Disrespectful' Backed
description: The lower house of Parliament gave preliminary approval to legislation that would bar entry to foreigners who show disrespect to the country, its leaders, symbols or values. The provision is part of a package of legislative amendments intended to ease restrictions on foreigners visiting or working in Russia by, among other things, offering extended visas. But in what appeared to be a new sign of official sensitivity to international criticism, it would also allow the authorities to deny visas to anyone who committed "actions of an openly disrespectful character," as defined by Russian officials, according to the official Russian Information Agency. The legislation, which is subject to two more votes and approval from the upper house and President Vladimir V. Putin, does not specify what exactly would amount to disrespect. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science and Health: Nervous Start For NASA Mission
description: A NASA spacecraft began its journey to a comet with a smooth liftoff, but then waited 90 long minutes before telling scientists its solar panel had deployed. The panel's failure to open would have doomed the $330 million mission. The craft, Deep Impact, is to release a probe that will cross the path of the comet Tempel 1 and smash into it on July 4. The device carries a 220-pound copper wedge that will dig a crater into the comet's core, blasting loose a cloud of gases and dust that is to be analyzed on the craft. Scientists say they want to know the exact composition of a comet's interior, since it is made of the same material that condensed to form the Sun and the rest of the solar system. Stefano S. Coledan (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Orchestras' Big Donations
description: For the San Francisco and Philadelphia orchestras, it has been a big week for fund-raising. Both have received $10 million challenge grants from donors. The San Francisco Symphony has received the largest grant in its history for "Keeping Score: MTT on Music," a $23 million project to popularize classical music through television, video and Internet programs featuring Michael Tilson Thomas, the orchestra's music director. A pilot episode of the program was shown on PBS stations last June, and part of the grant would finance three related series beginning early next year. The grant, from the Evelyn and Walter Haas Jr. Fund, was announced yesterday and requires that the orchestra raise $10 million on its own in the next three years. The Philadelphia Orchestra announced on Tuesday that it had received a $10 million promise from the family foundation of Joseph Neubauer, the chairman of the Aramark Corporation. The gift requires that the orchestra raise $20 million by Aug. 31, and the orchestra said all but $6 million of the challenge had already been met. The $10 million grant would set up three funds for commissioning new works, recording and broadcasts, and to endow the orchestra's principal trombone chair. BEN SISARIO

title: Arts, Briefly; Overseeing Sony BMG Classics
description: The classical division of the conjoined record company Sony BMG finally has someone in charge. The company has announced that Gilbert Hetherwick will become its president. Before the joint venture between the two recording giants, Mr. Hetherwick had been vice president and general manager of BMG Classics. Now he will supervise the combined classical divisions and oversee labels including RCA Red Seal, Sony Classical, Odyssey, Deutsche Harmonia Mundi and Arte Nova. Performers on the company's roster include Yo-Yo Ma, Joshua Bell, Evgeny Kissin and Nikolaus Harnoncourt. In recent years Sony and BMG have reduced their issues of strictly classical recordings, moving more toward crossover projects and film music. But they also have in their vaults countless recordings by the great artists of the 20th century, including Caruso, Heifetz, Rubinstein, Bernstein, Szell and Oistrakh. Eyes will now focus on how Mr. Hetherwick moves forward with new classical projects and what will happen to that back catalog. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Grows
description: Japan's current-account surplus rose 1.8 percent in November from October, the first increase in three months, as demand for Japanese exports picked up. title: The F.B.I.'s Virtual Nonstarter
description: One of the most alarming vulnerabilities to emerge after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks has been the Federal Bureau of Investigation's continuing inability to come up with a computer system that enables field agents to act quickly in sharing information and suspicions about where the next threats may emerge. In Senate hearings soon after the attacks, the bureau admitted that its 1980's computer technology could not search its files for cross-references to two words, like "flight" and "schools" -- a lethal shortcoming in light of where some of the terrorists prepared for their suicide mission. But a more effective system was in the works, the bureau promised lawmakers. They poured hundreds of millions of dollars into the effort, expecting the F.B.I. to meet its goal of having the antiterrorist centerpiece -- the Virtual Case File -- finally up and running by December 2003, a date already a year behind the original goal.

Arts, Briefly; Fighting Words
description: The producers of the new Iraq war documentary "Gunner Palace," below, said yesterday that they would appeal the R rating the film received last week from the Motion Picture Association of America. The film profiles the soldiers of the 2-3 Field Artillery, known as the Gunners, who occupied the abandoned palace of Saddam Hussein's son Uday after the fall of Baghdad. The motion-picture association, which does not discuss its ratings decisions, gave the film the rating for language. Though the movie, directed by Michael Tucker and Petra Epperlein, does not show combat violence, it does include interviews and spontaneous, or freestyle, raps with expletives. Reached by phone in Berlin, Mr. Tucker said: "The film is not about violence. It's about language, and the language is the reaction to the violence." The filmmakers expressed hope of persuading the board to change the rating to PG-13. "People understand that these are young people in combat," Mr. Tucker said. "It shouldn't be sugarcoated." Palm Pictures is to release the film on March 4. JOEL TOPCIK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WASHBURN, GEORGE
description: WASHBURN--George 90, died January 3, 2005 after a long fight with Alzheimer's. Beloved husband for 57 years of Anne Gibson Clark Washburn, and loving father of Constance Clark Washburn of Lagunitas, CA, and Lynn Washburn Hanke of New York. He leaves five grandchildren: Andrew and William Castle and Leigh, Randall and David Hanke. Mr. Washburn was born in Reading, PA in 1914. During the Depression, he worked his way through New York University (Class of 1936). During World War II, he served in the U.S. Navy from 1941 to 1945 on patrol in the North Atlantic with experimental subchasers and later in command of the Destroyer Escort USS Vammen, which saw combat in the Okinawa invasion. Managing men, arms and supplies prepared him for the responsible leadership he would later demonstrate during a forty-plusyear career as a pioneer of the mutual fund industry. He managed the first mutual fund department on Wall Street at Kidder Peabody from 1949 to 1953. By 1961 he formed the Sales Training Institute to prepare a fast-growing sales force, and served as the first President of the National Mutual Fund Managers Association in 1967. He was a partner at Paine Webber Jackson & Curtis from 1963 to 1971, and later with Loeb Rhodes & Co. and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette he continued to advance the development and marketing of mutual funds. From postwar years in Forest Hills where he joined the West Side Tennis Club to The Maidstone Club in East Hampton and The Bath & Tennis in Palm Beach, Mr. Washburn was a fixture on the tennis court and the dance floor. A lifetime of skiing, skating, sailing, golf and ocean swimming made him a tireless ballroom dancing partner. He also had a passion for sailboat racing where he often served as both cook and navigator on Bermuda races. A gracious gentleman who could never be found without his warm smile and engaging sense of humor, George Washburn will be missed by all who knew him. A memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Church in East Hampton at 4PM on Sunday, May 29th of Memorial Day Weekend.

'THE LEOPARD'
description: Luchino Visconti's 1963 masterpiece "The Leopard" opens in 1860, soon after Garibaldi has landed in Sicily and a year before Victor Emanuel II has been crowned the first king of a unified Italy. Fabrizio Corbera, Prince of Salina, played with magnificent grandeur by Burt Lancaster (alas, badly dubbed), reigns over a house teeming with relatives and servants, all of whom tremble in his wake. At once disturbed by change and existentially resigned to it, the Prince is facing his future as stoically as one of the age-beaten marble statues in his garden. Lancaster based his character on Visconti, a Marxist from an aristocratic family who had a sensuous appreciation for the glories of the un-unified Italy, evident here in the mansion's frescoed ceilings and the lace curtains billowing with winds of change. Visconti had an eye for sumptuous detail, but his triumph in "The Leopard" was how he tapped into the human core of this political story. It is the Prince's nephew, Tancredi (Alain Delon, above, with Claudia Cardinale as his love interest), who delivers the film's famous line, a crushingly cynical observation about power: if we want things to stay as they are, things will have to change. The Prince helps save Tancredi -- and, by extension, the decadent breed to which they both belong -- but does nothing to save himself, which makes him not just the subject of "The Leopard" but also its hero. The film will be shown at Film Forum in the restored version, complete with inadequate subtitles. (Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village, (212) 727-8110, through Jan. 20. Tickets: $10; $5 for members. MANOHLA DARGIS

title: In Hilo, Hawaii
description: OF all the tropical postcard places in the Hawaiian Islands, Hilo, on the Big Island of Hawaii, may have the least to offer the traditional tourist. And that's exactly the reason to go. The center of power of Kamehameha the Great, the king who unified the islands in the early 19th century, Hilo combines history and raw natural power to offer a rich alternative to the usual resort scene. Orchids and anthuriums, fostered by the wet climate, grow amid some of the most magnificent physical characteristics on earth, and the city exudes a genuine, small-town warmth and prototypical Aloha Spirit. No one works the tourist hustle, and the visitors don't come to vegetate. There's too much to see and do in a natural wonderland where some of the tallest mountains on earth, as measured from sea bottom, dominate magnificent landscapes of beach and garden, rain forest and desert, with flowing lava adding more territory every day. CHARLES E. ROESSLER

title: Arts, Briefly; An Embattled Playwright Speaks

Rioters who objected to her play, set in a Sikh temple and including scenes of murder and rape, shattered windows and stormed doors last month at the Birmingham Repertory Theater, where it was playing. Writing in The Guardian of London, Ms. Bhatti, who has had to leave her home, said the theater had no alternative to closing the play "when people's safety could not be assured." She added, "I certainly did not write 'Behzti' to offend," but she continued, "Theater is not necessarily a cozy place, designed to make us feel good about ourselves. It is a place where the most basic human expression, that of the imagination, must be allowed to flourish." PAM KENT

title: STEPHANIE BLYTHE
description: A contralto by any other name would sing as deep. Stephanie Blythe is billed sometimes as a mezzo-soprano, sometimes as a contralto, but what she's got is the main thing you want from any vocal artist: a distinct sound that reaches out and grabs you, an immediate vocal presence. In her case, that presence is big, strong, warm and colorful; and it's coupled with an artistry flexible enough to take her, it seems, just about anywhere she wants to go. In the last 12 months, New York has heard her in Handel's "Rodelinda" at the Met; in Meyerbeer and Berlioz with the New York Festival of Song, and in Wagner, Strauss and Mahler on her latest album. For her next trick -- a recital at Alice Tully Hall -- she's offering something completely different: three songs by Frank Bridge and Ralph Vaughan Williams's "Songs of Travel," coupled with seven melodies by Faur and "Songs Parodying Advertisements" by the irreverent musical polymath Nicolas Slonimsky. It's clear that Ms. Blythe defies categorization. More to the point: she's just plain good. (Sunday afternoon at 5, Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $48.) ANNE MIDGETTE

The agreement, which requires approval of a federal judge, covers current and former workers at 25 call centers in 13 states over a period of about two years, and amounts to about $202 a person. title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Rosa Parks's Medical Records
description: A day after a federal judge made public some medical records of Rosa Parks, the civil rights figure, a lawyer for her said that the dementia she has suffered for several years should have no bearing on two lawsuits filed in her name. The records say that Ms. Parks, who will turn 92 next month, was suffering from progressive dementia in October 2002. On Wednesday, in response to a request by The Detroit Free Press, a federal judge in Detroit released the six pages of medical information. Gregory Reed, the lawyer who filed two lawsuits on Ms. Parks's behalf contending that members of the music industry had used her name in a song without permission, said her medical records should not affect the two related lawsuits, filed in 1999 and 2004. The suits, which named Ms. Parks as the plaintiff, accused the rap group OutKast, BMG and several record companies and music distributors of defamation. But some relatives of Ms. Parks have since expressed doubt that she understood the lawsuits and have said they think she was exploited. Gretchen Reuthling (NYT)

'HERITAGE OF POWER: ANCIENT SCULPTURE FROM WEST MEXICO: THE ANDRALL E. PEARSON FAMILY COLLECTION'
description: Ball players, warriors, shamans, couples, animals, a musician and a dancer are among the lively clay figures dating from 200 B.C. to A.D. 400 that appear in "Heritage of Power: Ancient Sculpture From West Mexico." They are from the rich and varied lands around the Sierra Madre Occidental mountains, where in ancient times diverse cultures had in common the worship of ancestors, the skilled working of clay, and trade connections. A burial procedure also shared among these peoples interred the high-status dead in shaft-and-chamber tombs deep in the ground, where they joined powerful ancestors. Accompanying the deceased were offerings of ceramic art like those shown here, ranging in size from a few inches to some 2 1/2 feet. Their differing styles are named for the modern-day states that the area has become: Jalisco, Colima and Nayarit. The figures from Jalisco have a dynamically human presence, like the male dancer standing with his right leg crossed over the left, head cocked, one hand to mouth, the other at his hip, clad in the briefest of garments. Those from Nayarit seem more stolid, like the "Standing Female Figure," above, with vertical stripes painted on the lower half of her face, who holds up a cup in her right hand, her miniskirt half concealing a pair of thick legs firmly planted on two flat feet. From Colima come more stylized figures with large noses and animal imagery, like a well-armored turtle in the form of a vessel from whose upper shell a large spout emerges. The collection, a promised gift to the museum by the Andrall E. Pearson family, will give welcome exposure to a little-known ancient American art. (The Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through April 3. Hours: Sundays, Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 65+, $7.) GRACE GLUECK

description: The Carphone Warehouse Group, the largest European mobile phone retailer, said yesterday that annual profit would beat previous forecasts after demand for the latest phone designs surged in the last quarter. Pretax profit in the year ending in March will exceed 100 million ($189 million), beating an earlier prediction, the chief financial officer, Roger W. Taylor, said in an interview. In the 13 weeks to Dec. 25, the company connected 23 percent more people and increased retail sales 25 percent from a year earlier. The company, which is based in London and owns 1,329 stores across Europe, is benefiting from the growth of the cellphone market as prices fall and consumers seek new clamshell-shaped phones. The global handset market grew 26 percent, to 167 million units, in the third quarter of 2004, according to Gartner. The chief executive, Charles W. Dunstone, said yesterday that he was "confident of delivering a full-year result ahead of current consensus market expectations." Mr. Taylor said consumers were attracted by cheaper phones and offers for prepaid cards. Shares of Carphone Warehouse rose 12 pence, or 7.6 percent, to 170 pence in London.

title: 'NAKED BOYS SINGING!'
description: Who would have guessed? When "Naked Boys Singing!" opened at the Actors Playhouse in Greenwich Village in July 1999, the reviews were affable enough but hardly high praise. Yet five and a half years later, the show is still around (it moved uptown in March) and going strong. Once every gay man in New York had seen it, apparently, the so-called bachelorette parties started arriving. Productions are also running in Chicago and Atlanta, and a 39-city European tour is to begin in March. "Naked Boys Singing!" is just what the title suggests: a lineup of good-looking, young men nude most of the time -- doing musical numbers, lots of them slightly naughty and largely forgettable. But between the songs about masturbation, unwelcome erections and pornography, the show sometimes reveals a soul. Its finest musical moment is Mark Winkler and Shelly Markham's "Mitchum," a tribute to one young man's favorite 1950's movie star, "a perfect 10 back in the days of real men." With the accompaniment of life-size dancing Mitchum cutouts, Frank Galgano (fully clothed) laments the era of bottled-water-drinking boys with perfect gym bodies and longs for the days when guys came in all shapes and sizes, smoked and drank gin. "I know he was a little beefy and soft," Mr. Galgano sings (Tom Gualtieri originated the number in New York). "But when he took it all off . . . " One likes to think that Mitchum, who died in 1997, would, rather than rolling over in his grave, just raise a brow and narrow those bedroom eyes, suggesting that hey, he might try anything once. (This weekend's schedule: tonight at 10:30 and tomorrow at 6 and 10:30 p.m., 47th Street Theater, 304 West 47th Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200. Tickets: $35 to $65.) ANITA GATES

title: U.S. AGENCY ACCUSES SIDLEY LAW FIRM OF AGE BIAS
description: Sidley Austin Brown & Wood, a law firm with more than 1,500 lawyers, has been sued by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which accused the firm of firing older partners or forcing them to retire. The suit filed yesterday in United States District Court in Chicago said that in a 1999 overhaul, Sidley, based in Chicago, fired or demoted 31 lawyers over 40 years old because of their age. . The firm has a mandatory retirement age of 60, a violation of federal law, said John Hendrickson, a commission lawyer. Paul Verbinnen, a spokesman for Sidley, said that the suit was without merit. As an active member of the psychoanalytic community, she trained therapists at NPAP and the Manhattan Center for Psychonanalytic Studies. Also at 10 p.m. was the battle between the New York City crime dramas, and on that front, NBC's veteran "Law & Order" is gaining ground. Wednesday's episode featured the departure of Elisabeth Rhm, below, as an assistant district attorney. "Is this because I'm a lesbian?" she asked as she was being fired, much to the surprise of viewers, who have been shown little about the characters' personal lives. The NBC show won in total viewers and tied CBS's "CSI: NY" in the 18-to-49 demographic: in that age group, "CSI: NY" was soundly beating "Law & Order" earlier in the season. On Thursday, CBS won the night despite the weakness at 8 p.m. of "Wickedly Perfect," the domestic diva reality show. Because of that show's poor showing, CBS announced on Thursday that it would move up the premiere date of "Survivor" from March to Feb. 17, when it will reassume the 8 p.m. time slot. title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Annual Inflation Within Target Range
description: Inflation in Brazil was within the central bank's target range last year for the first time since 2000. The government's statistics agency said its consumer price index, the central bank's main gauge in setting interest rates, rose 7.6 percent in 2004, compared with a 9.3 percent increase in 2003. While that was higher than the central bank's target of 5.5 percent, it fell within a 2.5 percentage point tolerance band that allowed for an inflation rate of up to 8 percent. Though inflation eased on an annual basis, it accelerated in December for the third consecutive month, with a larger-than-expected rate of 0.86 percent. The central bank is expected to raise its benchmark lending rate next week for a fifth consecutive month to curb the increase in monthly inflation. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: The Mentally Ill as 'Frequent Fliers'
description: Pressed by rising costs, the states are scrambling for ways to keep millions of people who are released from jails and prisons each year from coming back. An obvious first step would be to abolish senselessly punitive laws that make it difficult for felons to reconstruct their lives, like those in all 50 states that bar ex-convicts from occupations that have nothing at all to do with their crimes. Another prudent step would be to create high-quality programs that provide newly released people with counseling and job placement. title: Arts, Briefly; Fox Responds to Muslim Complaints
description: After weeks of accusations that its drama "24" represents Muslims in an offensive way, Fox has announced plans to provide its affiliates with public service announcements showing Muslims in a favorable light. The spots are to be sponsored by the Council on Islamic-American Relations, the organization that has led the criticism of Fox. The show had its season premiere in a two-hour episode on Sunday, followed by another two-hour episode the next night. On the show, an Islamic family is portrayed as a terrorist sleeper cell in which the mother (Shohreh Aghdashloo, right, nominated for an Academy Award as best supporting actress last year for "House of Sand and Fog") kills her son's non-Muslim girlfriend to ensure the family's cover. Fox's local stations will be able to choose when or if they want to broadcast the public service announcements. KATE AURTHUR

Fiorina, said in December that the board had considered breaking up the company three times, but decided its diversified portfolio of printers, computers, digital cameras, servers and information-technology services helped it weather fluctuations in the cyclical technology sector. description: YOU may guess the secret about young Stella Meredith (Gail Russell) in THE UNINVITED (1944), but not before you've been properly scared in this old-fashioned, romantic ghost story set in prewar England. Roderick and Pamela Fitzgerald (Ray Milland and Ruth Hussey), brother-and-sister Londoners, set the tale in motion by buying a grand, long vacant country house in Cornwall, on a cliff overlooking the sea. The price is right and the staircase is fabulous, but the dog refuses to go upstairs, the air is always cold in the second-floor studio, and in the middle of the night the new owners hear the mournful sound of a woman crying. "It comes from everywhere and nowhere," Pamela says. "I've searched. There's never anything there." title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAGE, FRANK JARVIS
description: PAGE--Frank Jarvis, 88, died peacefully on December 30, 2004, in his home in Quail Ridge Country Club, Boynton Beach, FL. Known as Jarvis, he was born in Maplewood, N.J., September 3, 1916, one of four sons of Leslie M. and Margaret Owen Page. Jarvis was a member of one of the first graduating classes of Columbia High School and attended the University of Virginia. After Pearl Harbor, he enlisted in the Army Air Corps, becoming an instructor pilot for P-47 Thunderbolt aircraft, and specialized in aerial dog fighting. He served in the Pacific theater in 1944. He was promoted personally by President Roosevelt, who asked him why he had washed out two well-connected West Point graduates. He replied, "I felt they were a danger to the other men, sir." On February 10, 1944, he married the former Virginia Ferrell Barfield of Hahira, Georgia. After the war, Jarvis and Virginia moved to Garden City, L.I., and Jarvis continued in his family's hat business with his brothers Homer and Chauncey. In 1954, he was caught in the LIRR commuter train wreck, sold his business in the city and bought a precision metal parts manufacturer in L.I. An avid amateur golfer his whole life, Jarvis competed in the Walter J. Travis at Garden City Golf Club, where he was a former member, in various tournaments at Cherry Valley Golf Club, where he was a lifetime member. He was the founding President of the Midland Golf Club, an invitational golf tournament, named for the predecessor golf course to Cherry Valley, and remained as Honorary Chairman until his death. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Virginia Barfield Page of Boynton Beach, FL, and his two daughters, Ferrell Page McClean of Oyster Bay, N.Y. and Hobe Sound, FL and Beatty Page Cramer of N.Y. and Southampton, two grandchildren, Ferrell Page McClean and William Chichester McClean IV and a brother, Chauncey Owen Page of New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers donations in honor of Jarvis may be made to Hospice by the Sea, Palm Beach County, 1531 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, FL 33441; or The Page Family Endowment at Foxcroft School, Development Office, P.O. Box 5555, Middleburg, Virginia, 20118 or The Green Vale School, Valentine's Lane, Glen Head, N.Y. 11545. A memorial service will be scheduled with the Spring meeting of the Midland Golf Club in Garden City, New York.
