Arts, Briefly; Superheroes in Bookstores
description: Marvel Enterprises, Inc., the publisher of comic books starring Spider-Man and the X-Men, has announced a licensing agreement with four mass-market book publishers. The deal is aimed at expanding Marvel's presence in bookstores and will include titles for everyone from pre-schoolers to adults. DK Publishing will create encyclopedia-like "Ultimate Guides" to Marvel superheroes, including Iron Man and the Avengers. HarperCollins will release child-friendly novelizations and activity books tied to Marvel's films like "The Fantastic Four," above, which has its premiere on July 1, and "X-Men 3," scheduled for next year. Simon & Schuster Pocket Books will publish prose novels, aimed at adults, chronicling new adventures of various Marvel heroes. Meredith Books will produce a series of audio story books and coloring books. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

But it could not get him past another, Gaston Gaudio, the French Open champion.

title: Arts, Briefly; Scott Peterson's Ex-Girlfriend Tops Best-Seller List
description: The memoir of Amber Frey, the California massage therapist who met Scott Peterson on an arranged date and whose testimony helped convict him of murdering his wife, Laci, was the No. 1 nonfiction book in the week ended Jan. 8, according to the New York Times best-seller list to be published Sunday. In its first week on the list, "Witness," published by ReganBooks, an imprint of HarperCollins, displaces "America (The Book)," the faux civics textbook by Jon Stewart and others from Comedy Central's "Daily Show," which had been No. 1 for 15 weeks. Ms. Frey's memoir was helped by her Jan. 4 appearance on NBC's "Dateline." The episode was the program's most-watched broadcast in nearly two years. EDWARD WYATT

BLOCKBUSTER STILL PURSUING HOLLYWOOD ENTERTAINMENT
description: Blockbuster Inc., the video-rental chain, said yesterday that it remained committed to its pursuit of the Hollywood Entertainment Corporation, which agreed last week to be acquired by the Movie Gallery for $13.25 a share, or about $850 million. Still, Blockbuster said it no longer made sense to start the tender offer of $11.50 a share for Hollywood Entertainment that it made in November. Blockbuster said it was evaluating the price in light of a $27 million termination fee due to Movie Gallery, based in Dothan, Ala., should its proposed deal fall apart. Blockbuster is based in Dallas and Hollywood Entertainment is based in Wilsonville, Ore.

description: A major showdown in the family that controls the Cablevision Systems Corporation ended yesterday with the son outmaneuvering the father and persuading directors to vote to put the company's troubled satellite business up for sale.

title: A Columnist Jumps Newspapers, and Taverns
description: THREE days a week for the past 28 years, Ed Lowe, 58, had written his first-person column for Newsday, doling out comfort by the column-inch with his sketches of common folk. His stories about real people, whether on Long Island's beaches, ball fields and barrooms, or its docks, dens and decks, were infused with humanity, humor and an everyman's sensibility.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: ETA Car Bombing In Basque Town
description: The Basque militant group ETA exploded a car bomb in northern Spain, slightly injuring a police officer, according to government officials. A phone call to the Basque newspaper Gara warned of the bomb's location before it exploded, suggesting it was not intended to cause significant casualties. But the bomb appeared to be more powerful than those used in the string of nonfatal attacks that ETA has been carrying out since the summer. The explosion occurred in Getxo, a town near Bilbao that is home to many business and financial executives, common targets of ETA extortion in the past. Renwick McLean (NYT)

For Some New Yorkers, the Attica Uprising Is a Current Event
description: When the bloodiest prison insurrection in American history occurred at Attica prison in upstate New York in 1971, Liz Fink was 26 years old and a dedicatedly leftist law student. She instantly got involved and spent the first three decades of her career defending the inmates for a rebellion that, it turned out, was brutally ended by waves of indiscriminate shootings, beatings and torture by state troopers and guards. No officials would admit that after the chaos of the morning raid on Sept. 13; instead, the state tried to sell a story that all the deaths in the assault -- 10 hostages and 29 felons -- were the work of inmate sociopaths.

description: Nassau County Republican officials say they will nominate Gregory P. Peterson to run next fall against County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi, a Democrat. Mr. Peterson, a lawyer in private practice, served in the 1990's as the supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, where a majority of Nassau's residents live, as well as chairman of the county's Off-Track Betting agency. A spokesman for the County Legislature's Republican minority, Edward Ward, welcomed him as "a proven, strong vote-getter" to lead the ticket for county offices. Nassau's Democratic Party chairman, Jay S. Jacobs, predicted re-election for Mr. Suozzi, the first Democratic executive here in 30 years. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Jet Deliveries Top Forecast
description: Empresa Brasileira de Aeronutica, the Brazilian aircraft manufacturer known as Embraer, said it delivered 148 planes last year, three more than its most recent forecast and up from 101 deliveries in 2003. Embraer, the world's fourth-largest producer of commercial jets, cut its delivery forecast in October to 145 planes from 160 after two of its biggest customers, US Airways and the regional carrier American Eagle, suspended some orders because of financial difficulties. In the fourth quarter alone, Embraer delivered 42 planes, up from 30 a year earlier. It ended 2004 with $10.1 billion in orders, and expects to deliver 145 planes in 2005 and in 2006. Todd Benson (NYT)

World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Nestl Promotes Chief
description: Nestl, the food company, combined the jobs of chairman and chief executive by naming its chief executive, Peter Brabeck-Letmathe, left, to succeed Rainer E. Gut as chairman in April. The appointment does not require approval by shareholders, according to Robin Tickle, a Nestl spokesman. Mr. Brabeck-Letmathe, 60, has been Nestl's chief executive since June 1997. The company also nominated two board members, Andreas Koopmann and Rolf Hnggi, as vice chairmen. Mr. Koopmann will head the group that sets Mr. Brabeck-Letmathe's pay, and Mr. Hnggi will lead Nestl's audit committee. Nestl is based in Vevey, Switzerland.

title: Sandwich Shop With No Frills, Until You Take a Bite
description: With its "no loitering" signs and fluorescent lighting Tony Luke's Old Philly Style Sandwiches, a Philadelphia import that just opened at 576 Ninth Avenue (41st Street), is hardly inviting. Place an order at one window and pick up the food at another. Sandwich assemblers are visible in back. And there are just a few seats.

Summers, the university's president, saying his recent statements about innate differences between the sexes would only make it harder to attract top candidates.

title: BATTLE OVER PRESCRIPTION BENEFITS IN OHIO SPREADS TO CVS
description: The CVS Corporation, the drugstore chain, will stop honoring the insurance of Ohio's state employees and the Toyota Motor Corporation workers because their prescription plans cut retailers out of the competition for long-term refills. CVS, with more than 305 Ohio stores, will not accept the state government's drug coverage through Express Scripts Inc. as of April 18. Participation in Toyota's pharmacy network, administered by WellPoint Inc., will end Feb. 18, CVS said. The insurers do not reimburse workers with chronic conditions for maintenance prescriptions obtained at a drugstore, instead requiring use of their own mail-order services, CVS said. Another drugstore giant, Walgreen Company, stopped honoring benefits for state employees Jan. 1.

Pataki proposed a $105.5 billion budget on Tuesday that would dedicate increases in taxes and fees to mass transit but leave in doubt the future of such major projects as the Second Avenue subway and Long Island Rail Road access to Grand Central Terminal.

title: A Symphonic Night at the Movies, Without the Movies
description: A few years into the last century a number of musicians started thinking that art for art's sake wasn't such a good idea after all. They had had enough of musical heroism, big-bang tragedy and heaven storming. Music would be an asset to our daily lives, like toothpaste or automobile transmissions. Paul Hindemith codified a new stylistic camp and even gave it a name: "Gebrauchsmusik" or roughly "music to be made use of."

title: National Briefing
Complying With Marching Orders
description: THE arcane "Dietary Guidelines for Americans 2005," published last week by the federal government, is not without value. Its basic tenet is clumsily stated: "Combined with physical activity, following a diet that does not provide excess calories according to the recommendations in this document should enhance the health of most individuals." But the point is familiar to anyone who has read anything about the interrelation of diet, exercise and health in the last 20 years.

title: Arts, Briefly; Commuter Choreography
description: The Rambert Dance Company went underground, literally, in London on Monday, when dancers dressed in white coveralls, below, danced aboard a Jubilee Line train traveling from Canary Wharf in London's financial district to the Eurostar terminal station, Waterloo, a 30-minute journey. As bemused passengers looked on, 12 dancers from the city's oldest contemporary dance group, established in 1926, moved from car to car performing excerpts from its new production, "Constant Speed," scheduled to have its premiere at Sadler's Wells Theater in May. Choreographed by Mark Baldwin, the company's artistic director, the piece was commissioned to celebrate the centenary of Einstein's groundbreaking scientific theories, published when he was 26. The performance was part of a tourist board initiative to highlight London's theater offerings in 2005. Caught red-handed, Mr. Williams apologized for blurring his role. But the Education Department insulted the public's intelligence -- and defended essentially an act of bribery -- by describing its arrangement with Mr. Williams as "the straightforward distribution of information about the department's mission."

title: Arts, Briefly; Oh, the Agony
description: On Monday's episode of "Bachelorette," Jen Schefft, below, agonized over her dating choices, issuing the now-standard disclaimer that she had no idea it would be so hard to whittle down the group of potential suitors. But how could that be true when every "Bachelor" and "Bachelorette" who has come before her has said the same thing? The repetitiveness of this dating show, once a reality hit, might be why its viewership has eroded in this, its ninth season, even though ABC switched both its time slot and its location. This season's "Bachelorette" was filmed in New York for the first time. Its two-hour premiere last week drew a mere 9.18 million viewers, according to Nielsen's overnight ratings, and Monday's second episode was even weaker: it attracted an audience of 8.45 million. With that poor lead-in, the series premiere of "Supernanny," another reality offering, did better than expected in the competitive 10 p.m. hour; 9.99 million viewers watched the extreme makeover: brat edition program. CBS won Monday in both total viewers and in the 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

description: Colonial BancGroup Inc. of Montgomery, Ala., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire FFLC Bancorp for about $232 million to add 16 branches in central Florida. FFLC shareholders may choose two shares of Colonial stock or $42 in cash for each share held, Colonial said. FFLC's First Federal Savings Bank of Lake County, based in Leesburg, operates in Lake, Sumter, Citrus and Marion Counties, Colonial said. FFLC had total assets of $1 billion, $795 million in total deposits and total loans of $884 million as of Dec. 31, Colonial said. On completion of the FFLC purchase and the pending acquisition of Union Bank of Florida, Colonial said, it will have $7.4 billion in deposits in the state.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Juniper Networks Says Profit Quadrupled
description: Juniper Networks, the world's second-largest maker of equipment to route Internet traffic, said yesterday that fourth-quarter net income rose to $66 million, partly on the acquisition of a security-products maker. Net income increased to 11 cents a share from 3 cents a share, or $14.7 million, a year earlier, the company said. Sales more than doubled to $430.1 million from $207 million, exceeding analyst forecasts. Sales at Juniper, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., topped $1 billion last year for the first time in company history as demand increased. The chief executive, Scott Kriens, spent $3.63 billion last year to buy NetScreen Technologies, which makes computer security devices, to lessen Juniper's reliance on sales of routers to phone companies.

description: Silicon Storage Technology, which makes computer memory chips, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an informal inquiry into trading of company shares before a forecast announcement last month. "We believe the inquiry involves trading in shares of our common stock by an executive officer and a director," Silicon Storage said in a regulatory filing. "We are cooperating with the enforcement office." Silicon Storage said on Dec. 20 that fourth-quarter sales would rise to $102 million to $108 million, below its forecast of $120 million to $130 million. Silicon Storage, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said the commission was investigating trading before that announcement. It had sales of $95.2 million a year earlier. title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Jewish Leaders Praise Pope
description: A mostly American group of 130 Jews that included rabbis and cantors met with Pope John Paul II and thanked him for his efforts to improve relations between the two faiths. The pope noted in his remarks that 2005 is the 40th anniversary of the Nostra Aetate, the Vatican declaration that rejected the accusation that Jews were collectively responsible for the crucifixion. The audience, described by the Vatican as the largest ever granted to Jewish religious officials, came amid a renewed debate on the refusal to allow Jewish children who had been sheltered by Catholics during World War II to return to their families, and on the role of Pope Pius XII, now a candidate for sainthood. Pius XII received measured support from some of the Jews at the meeting. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

The Republican-controlled Legislature will choose Mr. Kilgore's successor. He has recommended that his deputy for the civil division, Judy Jagdmann, take his place for the remainder of his term, which ends this year. James Dao (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCLOUD, STEWART C.
description: McCLOUD--Stewart C. The Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York records with profound sorrow the passing of Most Worshipful Stewart C. McCloud, Past Grand Master, on Sunday, January 16 at his home in Monroe Township, NJ after a long illness. He is survived by Irene, his wife of 17 years, and sons Geoffrey and Stewart II, grandchildren Stewart III, Jason, Theresa and Geoffrey Jee Ho. His first wife, Georgine, passed away in 1987. The McClouds were residents of Floral Park, LI for many years prior to moving to Rossmoor in New Jersey five years ago. They also had a home in Ormond Beach, Florida. He was born in Brooklyn, NY in 1927. He served in the United States Navy in both World War II and the Korean conflict. He joined the Long Island Railroad in 1946 and rose thru the ranks to become Assistant Superintendent - Transporta tion and then an executive in the Training Department before retiring in 1978. In 1979 he became Consultant to Taconic International Rail-Transit Operations, followed by several years as Manager Test and Acceptance of Equipment at Bombadier Inc. for Metro North Commuter Railroad before he retired again in 1990. Grand Master McCloud had a long and distinguished Masonic career culminating in his Election as Grand Master in 1998 and his reelection in 1999. His theme as Grand Master was "Together We Build." During his term he established The Grand Lodge Fund to assist Lodges and indigent Masons in overcoming financial difficulties. A Mason for 47 years, he joined Dunton Lodge 1017 (now Springfield Gardens Lodge 1057) in November 1957 and served as its Master in 1970. In 1979 he became Assistant Grand Lecturer and District Deputy Grand Master in 1981. In the Grand Line he served as an Assistant Grand Marshal, Deputy Grand Marshal, and then Grand Marshal. From 1990, through 1992 he was the elected Grand Treasurer of the New York Grand Lodge of Masons. In 1995 he was elected Deputy Grand Master. Past Grand Master McCloud was a distinguished member of the Royal Arch Masons. In 1978 he was elected Grand High Priest of the Grand Chapter-R.A.M. of the State of New York. He served as a Trustee of the R.A.M. Medical Research Foundation, Inc. from its inception until his passing; for the past 20 years as its President. The Foundation supports the world famous Masonic Medical Research Laboratory in Utica, where a conference room in the new Molecular Genetics facility was named in his honor in June 2004. Past Grand Master McCloud was a proud member of the York Rite, Scottish Rite, and Blue Lodge Masonry and he received numerous awards, honors and honorary memberships. He received the highest honorary Masonic Degree having been coroneted Thirty Third Degree in 1997. The Grand Lodge of New Jersey accorded him the title of "Honorary Past Grand Master", and this past year he received one of the highest honors that can be bestowed by the New York Grand Lodge, The Charles Henry Johnson Medal. On behalf of the entire Masonic family in New York, the Grand Lodge extends condolences to the McCloud family and his Masonic Brothers. M..W.. Edward R. Trosin, Grand Master R..W..Gilbert Savitzky, Grand Secretary

description: SHORTLY after the 1925 Scopes "monkey trial," the usually astute historian Frederick Lewis Allen concluded that fundamentalism had been permanently discredited by the prosecution in Dayton, Tenn., of John T. "Legislators might go on passing anti-evolution laws," Allen wrote, "and in the hinterlands the pious might still keep their religion locked in a science-proof compartment of their minds; but civilized opinion everywhere had regarded the Dayton trial with amazement and amusement, and the slow drift away from fundamentalist certainty continued."

description: Retail sales in Brazil rose in November at their slowest pace in nine months, climbing 6.44 percent from the year-earlier period, the government statistics agency said. While the result came in below most forecasts, the monthly increase was the 12th consecutive one in retail sales, which climbed an accumulated 8.98 percent in the first 11 months of last year. Paid Notice: Deaths   ANGUS, ELENA RIONDA DOTY
description: ANGUS--Elena Rionda Doty, 93, of 2 Farmington Heights, Charlottesville, VA, died at her residence following a lengthy illness. She was born January 2, 1912 on the family sugar plantation in Tuniucu, Cuba. She was the daughter of Elena Hernandez Rodriguez y de la Toriente and Oliver Keys Doty. After tutoring for several years in Cuba she graduated from the Horrace Mann School in New York where she was elected permanent president of her class. In 1933 she graduated from Sweet Briar College and was an honor girl in the May Court. She married Bruce Angus and lived in New York and Sandersfield, MA until 1972. While in New York she was a member of Colony Club, on the Board of the New York Mayflower Society, and was Assistant General from the State of New York on the National Board. She was also chairman of the annual meetings and the annual ball of the Society. Mrs. Angus was also a member of the Tierra Ball committee of the Spence Chapin Adoption Service. In Charlottesville she continued her Colony Club and Mayflower membership and was a life member of the DAR. Services will be private.

title: Arts, Briefly; Lloyd Webber Ponders Sale
description: Andrew Lloyd Webber, the hugely successful composer of musicals like "Phantom of the Opera," "Cats" and his current West End attraction, "The Woman in White," is considering selling at least 4 of the 11 West End theaters he owns to an unidentified buyer, according to a report in The Evening Standard of London. The newspaper reported that the theaters that may be up for sale are the Duchess, Apollo, Garrick and Lyric. A spokesman for the composer issued a statement saying, "Andrew Lloyd Webber has received an inquiry in relation to the acquisition of some parts of his businesses." After adding that Lord Lloyd Webber was seeking advice on all available options, the statement continued: "The process is in its formative stages, and no decisions have yet been made." PAM KENT

title: Liberty Media's Boss Tries to Simplify His Holdings
description: IN a further effort to simplify his holdings, the cable magnate John C. Malone has had his Liberty Media International make an offer to buy out the public shareholders of UnitedGlobalCom, a Denver cable company with interests in Europe and Japan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABRONS, HERBERT L.
description: ABRONS--Herbert L. The Board of Directors and staff of Wave Hill mourn the passing of Herbert L. Abrons, our devoted and unwavering supporter and neighbor for more than a quarter century, a member of the Board and Executive Committee from 1981 to 1997. He provided vitality and leadership in the pivotal years when Wave Hill established its horticultural reputation, expanded its operations and developed its cultural programming. We will miss his quiet wisdom, quick wit and generous spirit. Our heartfelt condolences extend to his family and friends, especially his loving wife, Hyonja. David O. Beim, Chairman Kate French, President ABRONS--Herbert. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Herbert Abrons, whose passion for the arts, education, and the Jewish community left an indelible mark. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Hyonja; his brother Richard; his sister Rita Aranow; and his children & grandchildren. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. ABRONS--Herbert. The Board of Directors and staff of Riverdale Neighborhood House extend our sincere condolences to Hyonja Abrons and the Abrons family on the passing of our dear friend and benefactor, Herbert Abrons. His good works in Riverdale will long be remembered.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Law Bans Using Internet As a Lure
description: A bill to make it illegal to lure someone over the Internet to commit a crime has been signed into law by Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey. The bill, signed Monday, followed a case in 2002 in which a stranger menaced Patricia Barteck of Wood-Ridge after reading her address in an Internet chat room. Her cousin, Jonathan Gilberti, was convicted of posing as Ms. Barteck on the Internet, where he had posted her home address and added an explicit sexual invitation. Adult luring, as defined in the new law, will be punishable by a maximum of five years in prison and a $15,000 fine. Jessica Bruder (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, ISABELLE K.
description: WEISS--Isabelle K. On January 17, 2005, of Altamonte Springs, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY. Devoted wife of Saul R. Weiss. Beloved mother of Helaine Signer and Dena Luxenberg. Wonderful mother-in-law of Richard D. Signer and Jerry S. Luxenberg, all of Winter Park, FL. Adored grandmother of Brian and Matthew Signer and Liza and Betsy Luxenberg. Loving sister of her late siblings: Herbert King, Rae Gottlieb, Natalie Tannen and Bernard Kauff. Services today, January 19th, 2005 in Orlando, FL.

The chart at the top detailed the transmission of eye color under a genetic theory that the Nazis considered proof of their belief that parents of differing races produce inferior offspring; it did not detail that belief. The image at the bottom was of a metal case holding 20 glass eyes used in studies, not a skin-color chart.

Toby was our very close and beloved friend for nearly fifty years. Toby's generous spirit, his friendship and concern for others will be greatly missed by all of us who knew and loved him.

title: Mr. Pataki's State Budget
description: Yesterday, Gov. George Pataki presented a $105.5 billion budget for next year that attempts to tackle one of the state's thorniest and most costly issues: Medicaid spending. Mr. Pataki is right to attempt to reform New York's $44 billion Medicaid program, which shoves too much of its cost onto local communities. It's not clear yet, however, whether this major overhaul of the health care program for the disadvantaged and the elderly would be as humane as it appears to be thrifty.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Wading River: Groups Oppose Natural-Gas Plant
description: Environmental and civic groups announced their opposition yesterday to a $700 million plan for a floating natural-gas plant the size of a cruise ship in eastern Long Island Sound. The groups said the project posed environmental and safety risks. If approved by regulators, the plant will open in 2010. The plant, the size of the Queen Mary II, was proposed by Broadwater Energy Corporation of Houston. The floating plant would convert natural gas from a liquefied state and supply it to the New York metropolitan area through an underwater pipeline. John Rather (NYT)

Paid Notice: Deaths   STEVENS, WILLIAM THOMAS
description: STEVENS--William Thomas of Lido Beach, NY on January 18, 2005 at 84. Born September 3, 1920 in New York City to Irving T. Stevens and Mary Coughlin. A 1936 graduate of Xavier High School in Manhattan and a 1940 graduate of the College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, MA. Graduated Columbia University School of Law in 1943. WWII veteran, served in the United States Army from 1942-1946. A wellrespected attorney in private practice and a member of the New York Bar Association for 62 years. Husband of Louise McDonnell Stevens and extraordinary father of seven children, William T. Stevens, Jr., Nancy Coffey, Mary Rafferty, Jean Brennan, Elizabeth Murdy, Thomas Stevens and Kathryn McCormack. Devoted grandfather of 15 grandchildren and one great-grandchild. He will be remembered by many for his wit, charm and intellectual curiosity, but above all for his genuine interest in 'all creatures great and small'. Visitation Thursday at Macken Mortuary, 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Center. Funeral Mass Friday, 11 A.M., Our Lady of Miraculous Medal, Point Lookout. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Queens.

description: Several dozen former workers at Windows on the World, the restaurant destroyed in the attack on the World Trade Center in 2001, will open a cooperative restaurant called Colors at 417 Lafayette Street, according to the Restaurant Opportunities Center of New York, a group working with the employees. Officials with the group said that they signed a lease yesterday and that the restaurant, south of the Public Theater, would open later this year. Colors, which is to serve American food with global influences, is receiving financial support from a consortium of Italian food cooperatives. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; New Challenge for 'Survivor'
description: Richard Hatch, right, who achieved fame as the winner of the first "Survivor" series, has been charged by the federal government with filing false income tax returns that omitted more than $1 million he received from the show and some $321,000 paid to him by a Boston radio station. Filed yesterday in the Federal District Court in Providence, the charges against Mr. Hatch, 43, a corporate trainer and consultant from Newport, R.I., who has become a spokesman and a motivational speaker, were announced by Robert Clark Corrente, the United States Attorney for the district of Rhode Island, and Joseph A. Galasso, of the Internal Revenue Service. Each of the two counts carries a maximum penalty of five years in federal prison and a $250,000 fine. Court documents filed yesterday said that Mr. Hatch had entered an agreement to plead guilty. He is to be arraigned on Monday. Mr. Hatch could not be reached for comment. ERIC LICHTBLAU

description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the biggest discount broker, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit fell 64 percent on job cuts and the sale of its capital markets business. A rival, Ameritrade Holding Corporation, said earnings rose 29 percent to a record in the same period.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: New Leaders Set To Return Home
description: Somalia's prime minister, Mohammed Ali Geedi, announced that the country's three-month-old transitional government, which has been operating from Kenya, would soon move to Mogadishu. Some government officials will make the move in the coming weeks, he said, estimating that the entire government would be operating from Somalia as early as March or April. Somali officials have been hesitant to move because of security concerns in Mogadishu, the lawless capital where some hard-liners oppose the new government. Marc Lacey (NYT)

A dedicated and distinguished faculty member since 1973, she became Head of the History Department, a member of the Administrative Team and Director of Studies. Among her greatest gifts to our school were her scholarship and her unbounded devotion to her students. We extend our profound sympathy to her husband, Barry, and to her entire family. Ella M. title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Another Bias Suit Against Waffle House
description: Black customers of Waffle House restaurants in Alabama, Georgia, North Carolina and Virginia filed racial discrimination suits against the chain and some franchisees. The customers said restaurant workers had announced that they did not have to serve blacks, had used racial epithets and had ignored them while whites were seated and served. In a statement, Waffle House said it had no tolerance for discrimination and would defend itself in court. Eighteen other suits against Waffle House or its franchisees are pending, said Susan Huhta of the Washington Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights and Urban Affairs, which is counsel of record in all the suits. Juries in two similar suits rejected accusations of racial discrimination against the chain. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEAKE, EUGENE WALTER JR.
description: LEAKE--Eugene Walter Jr., 93, died at home in Monkton, MD, January 15, 2005. The renowned landscape painter studied painting at Yale University, was president of the Maryland Institute College of Art, Baltimore, 1961-1975, and trustee of the Guggenheim Museum, NY. He taught painting at Yale and Johns Hopkins Universities, and received the University of Maryland's first Maryland arts Lifetime Achievement Award. He is survived by daughters Nora Cameron and Nina Richardson and three grandchildren.

title: Trouble in a One-Synagogue Town
description: GREENPORT, N.Y. - Until recently, this old whaling village had a small Jewish population with a simple story. Over the years, Jews arrived as shopkeepers or bought summer homes and eventually settled here. They carried Torah scrolls from home to home, before building a small synagogue in 1903. The high point every year was a September dinner party and fund-raiser.

Vincent, included charges that he had enlisted influential former American government officials, who were not identified, to discuss ways to help Saddam Hussein avoid international economic sanctions.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Some Charges Dropped In Priest's Abuse Trial
description: The prosecutors dropped a number of criminal charges at the start of the trial of Paul R. Shanley, a defrocked priest who was a central figure in the sexual abuse scandal that rocked the Boston Roman Catholic Archdiocese. The prosecutors dropped charges related to one of four men who had originally accused Mr. Shanley of raping them, leaving one man to testify. The prosecution dropped charges involving the two other accusers in July. Mr. Shanley, 73, was indicted in June 2002 in the rape of four boys at St. John the Evangelist Parish in Newton from 1979 to 1989. Four jurors were chosen on the first day of jury selection. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Principal Given Harsher Sentence
description: A Brooklyn elementary school principal who sexually assaulted a girl who is now 14 over a six-year period did not appear at his sentencing yesterday and was given eight extra years. The principal, Leroy Johnson, 43, of Jamaica, recently pleaded guilty to sexually assaulting the girl, a relative, and agreed to a 12-year sentence. He was free on $100,000 bail and failed to appear in State Supreme Court in Queens yesterday, so Justice Barry Kron sentenced him to 20 years. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Qualcomm Posts 46% Profit Increase
description: Qualcomm said yesterday that first-quarter profit rose 46 percent on climbing demand for handsets that let users play games, take photos and read e-mail. Net income rose to $513 million, or 30 cents a share, in the quarter that ended Dec. 26, from $352 million, or 21 cents a share, a year earlier, the San Diego-based company said. Sales rose 15 percent to $1.39 billion, compared with the $1.40 billion estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. The chief executive, Irwin M. Jacobs, is trying to benefit as mobile-phone users upgrade to handsets using Qualcomm chips that play games and carry video clips. The company is attracting new customers as wireless carriers switch to networks that are based on the technology developed by Qualcomm. The company said that excluding the Qualcomm Strategic Initiatives investments unit, second-quarter profit would be 25 cents to 27 cents a share, falling short of the 30 cents expected by analysts in a Thomson First Call survey. Sales on that basis will be $1.35 billion to $1.45 billion, missing the $1.49 billion expected by analysts. The company's shares fell $2.67, to $38.40, in extended trading. The stock had declined $1.55, to $41.07, in regular trading.

title: Arts, Briefly; Another Coup at Bonnaroo
description: For the last three years, the Bonnaroo festival in rural Tennessee has been one of the most celebrated pop events in the country, drawing tens of thousands with boldly eclectic programming. This year's lineup is no disappointment. With a core of big-name jam bands, including the Dave Matthews Band, Widespread Panic, the Allman Brothers and Jack Johnson. It will also feature rock luminaries like Modest Mouse, Joanna Newsom, Iron and Wine, Brazilian Girls and M. Ward, as well as the country legends John Prine and Earl Scruggs; the modern bluegrass stars Alison Krauss and Bela Fleck; the teenage British soul singer Joss Stone, above, and the reggae heroes Toots and the Maytals, the festival announced yesterday in a preliminary listing of 29 acts out of an expected 60. The festival, in Manchester, Tenn., south of Nashville, will run from June 10 to 12. BEN SISARIO

As first seen in Peter Hall's soul-stirring production of Shakespeare's "As You Like It," at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, this fabled sylvan outpost of civilization looks as forbiddingly cold and wind-swept as New York is at the moment. There doesn't appear to be anything appetizing to eat there. And its visitors tend to fill their time kvetching, keeping warm, philosophizing and navel gazing.

Paid Notice: Deaths   ABRONS, HERBERT LEHMAN
description: ABRONS--Herbert Lehman died in his 93rd year on January 15, 2005 in Naples, FL. He was a son of Louis Abrons and Anne Schroeder and attended Yale College and Yale Law School. During World War II he served in the Navy as gunnery officer on a ship carrying munitions to the Philippines. He was an assistant U.S. Attorney General and then counsel for General Aniline & Film Corp. After retiring, he managed Overlook Groves, a citrus grove in Hardee County, FL. A trustee of The Louis and Anne Abrons Foundation, he supported settlement houses, AfricanAmerican education, opera, and parks. He served as President and Chairman of The Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side, where his parents met at a dance in 1903, and on the boards of Wilberforce University and Wave Hill. He is survived by his children, Henry, Alix, and Anne, four grandchildren, a great grandchild, siblings Rita Aranow and Richard Abrons, and his extended family. He is also survived by his third wife, Hyonja Lee Abrons and her children, Jai, Jason, and Janet. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. Services will be private. Contributions may be made to the Abrons-Aranow Scholarship Fund, c/o The Henry Street Settlement, 265 Henry St., NY NY 10002.

title: Focus Changes in Terror Case Against Sheik
description: Nearly two years ago, Attorney General John Ashcroft personally announced to Congress that federal prosecutors had filed terrorism-financing charges against a Yemeni sheik and his aide. Law enforcement officials indicated that the sheik, Mohammed Ali Hassan al-Moayad, had used a Brooklyn mosque to help funnel millions of dollars to Al Qaeda and had boasted that he had personally delivered $20 million to Osama bin Laden.

The two men, David Lemus and Olmedo Hidalgo, are serving 25 years to life for the murder of Marcus Peterson at the Palladium nightclub. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

description: Trico Marine Services, which transports equipment to offshore oil rigs, won court approval of a plan to exit bankruptcy that will wipe out $270 million in debt and give bondholders a majority stake in the company. Judge Stuart M. Bernstein of Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan confirmed the plan yesterday, less than one month after Trico filed for bankruptcy protection. Shareholders will get warrants to buy up to 10 percent of the shares, with management getting options for the rest. Trico is based in Houma, La.

title: Arts, Briefly; Kasparov Says Count Me Out
description: Garry Kasparov, right, the world's top-ranked chess player and former world champion, has bowed out of the process to reunify the world chess championship title that has been split since 1993. In a news release, Mr. Kasparov said that he was no longer willing to work with the world chess federation, Fdration Internationale des checs, known by its acronym FIDE (pronounced FEE-day), because the federation had been unable to arrange a match between its current champion, Rustam Kasimdzhanov of Uzbekistan, and Mr. Kasparov. The winner of that match was supposed to meet Vladimir Kramnik, the other current world champion, as part of a 2002 plan to reunify the title. The federation originally announced that the match between Mr. Kasparov and Mr. Kasimdzhanov would take place in Dubai in January, but the sponsorship fell through. According to Mr. Kasparov's statement, it was the fourth time in the last two-and-a-half years that a match between the federation's champion and Mr. Kasparov had been canceled. In his statement, Mr. Kasparov said he would continue to play but he has grown disillusioned "with the process and the others on which it depends." DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Fines Over Chemicals Cartel
description: The European Commission fined three major European chemical companies nearly 217 million euros (about $282 million) for colluding to fix prices for a compound commonly used in detergents, glues and thickeners. title: Ah, Winter, When Gardeners Get Busy
description: HURRAH, it's finally winter: down to 9 degrees this week in New York, or zero with the wind chill. After weeks of extremely mild weather -- some of us planted tulips at 60 degrees -- we gardeners can do what we're supposed to be doing. No, not hibernating. Pawing through catalogs. Surfing the Web into the wee hours. Sending e-mail orders to small growers like Select Seeds in Union, Conn., which cagily mentioned that it has a "limited supply" of Lord Bute, a forgotten maroon geranium edged in crimson. title: National Briefing | Washington: Report On National Zoo
description: The National Zoo has improved the care it gives its animals, but must still remedy serious deficiencies, a National Academy of Sciences panel reported. Congress ordered the review after the deaths of several animals, including two rare red pandas, which swallowed rat poison in 2003. The panel listed several shortcomings, including the lack of either a strategic plan or systematic, formal training for animal keepers. The zoo's acting director, David L. Evans, described the report as fair and said he was encouraged by the findings that most animal care had been appropriate. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

The company said that 38 percent of this year's budget, or $1.27 billion, would be used to increase production of ferrous metals like iron ore, a primary ingredient in steel, while $976 million would be spent on copper, nickel, aluminum and coal projects. C.V.R.D., which said it planned to open offices in Australia and Venezuela this year, also set aside $760 million to buy new trains and improve logistics at ports. Todd Benson (NYT)

description: WOLF--Greg. Our firm is in deep mourning over the death of Greg Wolf, the son of our beloved and adored Managing Director, George Wolf. For more than two years Greg has been battling leukemia with the resolve, confidence and strength of character that marks the noble warrior. All the while, he completed his studies with excellence so he could graduate with his '04 Duke class, and despite painful and seemingly endless treatments, including a bone marrow transplant, Greg maintained his keen sense of humor and adorably mischievous persona to the delight of his parents, five siblings, many friends and teams of doctors and nurses. description: An employees' union has been authorized at a second Wal-Mart Stores outlet in Canada. The union, the United Food and Commercial Workers Canada, said yesterday that it had received a notice from Quebec's labor relations board certifying a bargaining unit for the store in St. Hyacinthe, about 40 miles southeast of Montreal. Employees at a Wal-Mart store in Jonquire, Quebec, were permitted to join the union last year and are negotiating their first contract with the retailer. Andrew Pelletier, a spokesman for Wal-Mart Canada, said the labor board's latest decision was "seriously flawed and undemocratic" because it did not require a secret ballot. Paid Notice: Deaths   CARTER, SIDNEY, M.D.
description: CARTER -- Sidney, M.D. Members of the Department of Neurology at Columbia University and the Neurological Institute of New York mourn the death of Dr. Sidney Carter on January 16, 2005. He was the Dwight D. Eisenhower Professor of Neurology Emeritus and had been Director of Pediatric Neurology at Babies Hospital from 1951 to 1978. Dr. Carter was one of the founders of pediatric neurology. He led the development of this superspecialty of neurology, established guidelines, obtained financial support for pediatric neurology training programs, and designed the requirements for certification of child neurologists. He was a brilliant clinician and an outstanding teacher who made Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center the center of child neurology in the United States for over 25 years. An internationally recognized leader, he served as President of both the American Academy of Neurology and the American Neurological Association. He was beloved by all who knew him and the field of pediatric neurology is his lasting legacy. We extend our sympathy and admiration to Elizabeth (Buff), his wife for 60 years, his sons Jeffrey, Jonathan and Jeremy, and their families. Timothy A. Pedley, M.D. Henry and Lucy Moses Professor of Neurology Chairman, Department of Neurology & Lewis P. Rowland, M.D., Chairman Emeritus, Department of Neurology

The woman he is accused of abusing said she awoke to find Mr. Percival "licking her feet and toes without her consent," according to a detective's statement. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

BOEING LOWERS ESTIMATE OF FOURTH-QUARTER CHARGE
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter charge for canceling its 717 aircraft had been revised to $280 million on a pretax basis, from $340 million. Boeing said in a regulatory filing that it would account for the remaining $60 million in 2005. The company, based in Chicago, said the revision was made to comply with pension accounting rules. The fourth-quarter expense included $171 million to terminate contracts with suppliers, $36 million to halt production, $43 million for pension curtailment and $30 million for severance, the company said. Boeing halted production of the 100-seat aircraft because of lack of orders.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bloomberg Catches Ferrer
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has gained ground on the perceived Democratic front-runner in the race to unseat him, Fernando Ferrer, left, the former Bronx borough president, according to a poll of New York City voters released yesterday. The Quinnipiac University Poll found that if the election were held now between Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Ferrer, each would get roughly 43 percent of the vote. The poll of 1,027 registered city voters had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points. Mr. Ferrer has held leads of four to seven percentage points over the mayor in Quinnipiac polls dating back to last February. Jim Rutenberg (NYT)

A Pleasure Dome Kubla Khan Could Die For
description: The trade winds have reached the former East Germany. In Brand, only an hour's drive from Berlin, a new indoor resort called Tropical Islands (above, right) is housed in what was originally an airship hangar (top left). The pleasure dome contains sandy beaches (and 850 lounge chairs), thatched huts and a blue fresh-water lagoon (with waterfall), as well as restaurants and shops. The air is kept at a comfy 77 to 82 degrees (the lagoon is 95 degrees), and if the sun is shining, patrons can get a tan. (The roof allows in ultraviolet rays.) Every two hours performers from Bali (left) and other Asian countries put on a show. (In the future, according to the Tropical Islands Web site, the focus will shift to other warm-weather locales, allowing visitors to "dip into the unknown of exotic cultures again and again.") Visitors can pitch a tent and sleep on the beach if they wish (the complex is open year-round, 24 hours a day), lulled to sleep by insect and bird noises emitted by rock-shape speakers and gently roused by a sunrise projected on the wall. The complex covers more than 700,000 square feet at ground level and can accommodate up to 7,000 people. The Statue of Liberty could fit inside it, upright.

title: Study Cites Human Failings In Election Day Poll System
description: The research firms that designed the $10 million polling system used by news organizations during last year's presidential election have concluded that the system erroneously showed John Kerry to be leading the race not because of a technological breakdown but because of more human variables. These included the relative youth of the pollsters, who were more successful securing interviews with supporters of Mr. Kerry as they left polling places than with those of the actual winner, President Bush.

title: World Briefing | The Arctic: Greenhouse Gases Linked To Increased River Flows
description: Human-caused global warming appears to be a "major driving factor" behind recent increases in the flows of rivers emptying into the Arctic Ocean, British climate scientists have concluded. The researchers ran computer simulations of the earth's climate and water cycles with and without increasing levels of smokestack and tailpipe emissions linked to rising temperatures. Only simulations that included man-made greenhouse gases generated rising Arctic river flows similar to those actually measured since the 1960's, said the researchers, from the Hadley Center for Climate Prediction and Research. Their findings, described in the next issue of Geophysical Research Letters, are significant because freshening of Arctic waters in millenniums past has sometimes caused abrupt changes in climate around the Northern Hemisphere. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Saudi Prince Buys The Savoy
description: A British bank and a real estate concern controlled by Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia, left, have acquired the Savoy Hotel in London. Quinlan Private, a privately held Irish investment company, said it sold the hotel, which has 263 rooms and overlooks the Thames, for an undisclosed price. Quinlan acquired the property in April when it bought the Savoy Group, which owns other British hotels and a restaurant. Quinlan said it would retain the other properties and rename the company. The buyers of the Savoy -- HBOS and Prince Talal's company, Kingdom Hotels International -- will retain the Savoy name, and Fairmont Hotels and Resorts of Toronto will continue to manage it. title: Defense Budget Squeeze
description: The continuing high costs of the Iraq war are finally forcing the Pentagon to pare back its order lists for unneeded and extravagant cold war weapons. That should have been done years ago. The Defense Department will have to go well beyond its current cost-cutting plans if it wants to be able to afford the ground-warfare soldiers and battle systems it desperately needs today and to develop the more advanced weaponry likely to be needed in coming decades. Even the spendthrift Bush administration recognizes that it can no longer afford to keep buying all the wish-list weapons designed in the late 20th century for fighting a high-tech superpower foe.

Paid Notice: Deaths   JERVIS, WAYNE TALMAGE, JR.
description: JERVIS--Wayne Talmage, Jr. Beloved husband of 37 years to Ruth G. Jervis, passed away the evening of January 18, 2005 in Los Angeles, CA. The son of Wayne Talmage Jervis, Sr. and Virginia Wheeler Jervis, he was the loving father of Margaret Sculley Allnatt, John Blackburn Sculley, Wayne Talmage Jervis, III, and Geoffrey Grace Jervis and beloved "Poppa" of seven grandchildren. He is also survived by his brother, Oliver Wheeler Jervis, of Monteagle, TN, and his family. Wayne Jervis was born on April 25, 1927 in Charlotte, NC, graduated from Webb School in Bell Buckle, TN, the University of the South in Sewanee, TN (B.A. 1950) and the University of Chicago School of Business (M.B.A. 1960). Wayne was a World War II veteran (USN), and his career culminated with the founding of Jervismark, a marketing firm based in Los Angeles, CA. Jervismark was instrumental in the development and deployment of statistical analysis for new product development and marketing and consumer purchasing motivations in the consumer products industry. Wayne Jervis is known for his graciousness, impeccable character, integrity and loyalty by his friends, colleagues and family. A devoted Christian, Wayne Jervis was a member and Deacon of Bel Air Presbyterian Church. He was an ardent supporter of Christian charities and medical research, specifically the Cancer Research Institute of New York, NY where he was a Director, He was a valued mentor to many, especially his children and grandchildren, in academics, athletics and the lifelong development of character. He loved American history, golf, tennis, reading, sailing, world travel, summers in Martha's Vineyard and his beloved Tennessee, where he spent as much time as possible at his residence in Monteagle. His generousity, humor, great common sense and kindness will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Memorial services will be held at 11:30am on Friday January 21, 2005, at Bel Air Presbyterian Church in Los Angeles, CA. In lieu of flowers the family suggests donations to the Cancer Research nstitute or the John Douglas French Alzheimer's Foundation.

title: At the Limits of Ocean and Air
description: Most humans have never seen a gray-headed albatross or, for that matter, any albatross. And for good reason. The gray-headed albatross breeds in grassy tufts set high on the cliffs of remote islands in the seas just north of Antarctica. But the bird's true habitat is the tumultuous air above those seas. In April 1999, scientists fixed tiny locaters to the albatrosses in a cohort breeding on Bird Island, near South Georgia. The data retrieved -- a map of the migratory patterns of 22 birds -- will help scientists understand where albatrosses are most likely to cross paths with fishing boats, which often hook and kill the birds with baited hooks floating just under the water's surface. That could make all the difference to this species, which belongs to the most threatened family of birds on the planet.

Paid Notice: Deaths   FEINER, ARTHUR H., PH.D.
description: FEINER--Arthur H., Ph.D., ABPP. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute and Society profoundly mourn the death of a much celebrated and influential graduate and colleague, Fellow Emeritus, Senior Editor Emeritus of the journal, "Contemporary Psychoanalysis," Training and Supervising Analyst, and faculty member. A psychoanalyst for 45 years, Art was a poet, lyricist and editor of the Journal for an unprecedented 25 years. During this tenure, and with indefatigable energy and an unwavering commitment and scholarly excellence, Art established the Journal as the open-minded, curious, multitheoretical flagship publication that it is today. Dr. Feiner brought vision, passion and an engaging and feisty frankness to his many pursuits, and his brilliant and hilarious musical lampoons of the Institute brought joy and mirth to numerous Institute graduations. The author of many articles on psychoanalysis, Arthur co-edited the classic work, "Countertransference and the Anxiety of Influence," and recently published his book, "Interpersonal Psychoanalytic Perspectives on Relevance, Dismissal and Self-Definition." Dr. Feiner left an enduring legacy. We shall yearn for his largerthan-life inspiring presence among us and we shall miss him always. Our deep condolences to Alice Feiner, his beloved wife of 60 years, and to his dear family, friends, colleagues and patients. Joerg Bose, M.D. Institute Director Gurmeet Kanwal, M.D. Society President Donnel Stern, Ph.D., Editor Contemporary Psychoanalysis

title: China's Lost Leader
description: Few figures have played a larger role in shaping today's China, particularly its most positive features, than Zhao Ziyang, the former Communist Party leader who died Monday after more than 15 years of house arrest. In trying to treat his death as virtually a state secret, China's current leaders reveal more than they intend about their own profound feelings of political insecurity. Powerful as they are, China's rulers have let themselves be spooked by a ghost, even to the point of defying the tradition of granting full official funeral honors to ranking former leaders, regardless of ideological differences. It may be possible to airbrush Mr. Zhao temporarily out of official Communist iconography. In the long term, China's people will surely reclaim a more honest history.

title: The Listings; ASHLIE ATKINSON
description: In one of the many poignant moments in "Fat Pig," the unpoignantly titled new play by Neil LaBute, Ashlie Atkinson stands before an imaginary mirror, trying on a series of wraps as she prepares for a day at the beach. Since Ms. Atkinson, and the character she plays, are -- euphemism alert! -- plus-size, the moment could be played for maximum pathos. Refreshingly, it isn't. In Ms. Atkinson's scrutinizing look can be seen everyday doubts and dissatisfactions, maybe a mild grimace at a shape-hiding muumuu, but nothing like shame or fear or despair. The moment beautifully encapsulates the character's clear-eyed, hard-won approach to her life. She has reckoned long with the diminishments and insults that overweight people have to endure, accepted the possibility of compromise but retained a sustaining belief that good things may still be in store. (Guess she doesn't know who wrote the play.) Ms. Atkinson's entirely winning performance has itself not diminished a jot in its appeal since she has acquired a new partner. Steven Pasquale has joined the cast of this Off Broadway hit, replacing Jeremy Piven, off to HBO's "Entourage." No worries: Mr. Pasquale is both brashly funny and affecting as a young man struggling to keep a clammy grip on the courage of his convictions. Though that was nearly seven million fewer people than the show's Tuesday premiere drew, it was enough to put Fox in first place in total viewers and among 18-to-49-year-olds. ABC's "Lost," in direct competition with "Idol" from 8 to 9 p.m., held up well -- its overnight ratings remained above its season average, and it drew an estimated 19.55 million viewers. With that strong lead-in, ABC's recharged "Alias" moved into first place at 9 p.m., which was bad news for the series premiere of "Point Pleasant" on Fox. That series, a New Jersey-based, Devil-teen horror show, lost nearly 15 million viewers from the "Idol" audience. A different network was No. 1 in each hour of Wednesday night: at 10 p.m., opposite a repeat of CBS's "CSI: NY," an estimated 15.09 million viewers watched the debut of Annie Parisse, above, as a regular cast member on NBC's "Law & Order." Ms. Parisse's role, that of an assistant district attorney, is the "Law & Order" slot that has changed the most in its 15 seasons: she is the sixth person to play the lead lawyer's second-in-command. title: The Listings; 'ARNESON AND THE OBJECT'
description: Robert Arneson (1930-1992) was the most adventurously ambitious ceramic sculptor of modern times. The father of California Funk was not the only artist to give clay a bigger-than-pedestal-scale life; Peter Voulkos and Viola Frey did, too. But no one brought to clay the range of imagery, themes and purposes that Arneson did, from the surrealistically personal to the ferociously political. "Arneson and the Object," an exhibition organized by the Palmer Museum of Art at Pennsylvania State University, might sound as if it would sample only a narrow slice of his oeuvre, but it is a measure of his dauntless imagination that while focusing on things like shoes, flowerpots and household appliances, Arneson could explore a wondrous variety of conceptual and expressive concerns. The show includes a misshapen sixpack of green, gold-capped Coca-Cola bottles; a lustrously glazed bathroom scale with footprints and five disembodied toes pressed into its surface; bronze bookends commemorating the death of Jackson Pollock; and a portable television filled by the head of Ronald Reagan. The most striking piece is the ceramic sculpture of a pair of bulbous, pink shoes (above), each over a yard long. The sole of one shoe bears the inscription, "Hommage to Philip Guston 1913-1980." The reference is, of course, to the darkly comical shoes that frequently piled up in Guston's late paintings and to the visceral pink color he favored. Arneson's poignantly affectionate funerary monument asks in effect, "Who could ever fill these shoes?" (George Adams, 41 West 57th Street, (212) 644-5665, through Feb. 26.) KEN JOHNSON

description: The music and the political struggles of Shostakovich and Prokofiev are by now well-known in the West, but even some of the most important voices among the following generation of Soviet composers have seldom been heard in New York. The conductor and new music champion Joel Sachs seeks to remedy this with help from his New Juilliard Ensemble. Juilliard's annual Focus Festival will be exclusively devoted to the post-Shostakovich generation of Soviet composers. Tonight's opening concert will feature New York or American premieres by Valentin Silvestrov, Giya Kancheli and Alfred Schnittke, above, as well as "Pro et Contra," an early and raw cello concerto by Arvo Prt that predates his shift toward a more prayerful and serene style. The festival continues with five other concerts through next Friday, featuring works by by Tigran Mansurian, Sofia Gubaidulina, Peteris Vasks, Oleg Felzer, Vladimir Tarnopolsky, Valentin Bibik and many others. (The conductor has admirably stocked his programs with plenty of works from the non-Russian Soviet Republics.) On Tuesday night, a panel will discuss the music and its historical context. One can't help but wonder, for example, whether it was in spite of -- or because of -- the conditions of their daily reality and artistic life, that these composers created music of such expressivity and depth. Or was it some ever-shifting combination of both? (Tonight at 8, Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 769-7406. All concerts are free, but tickets are required tonight and next Friday.) JEREMY EICHLER

description: Provocative! Shocking! Controversial! Plenty of movies deck themselves out in words like these for marketing purposes, but how many really earn them? Over time, even the most daring assaults on taste and taboo tend to grow tame and familiar. But there are some movies that retain their power to shock, offend and baffle polite opinion, and two of them can be seen this weekend in the decorous confines of the American Museum of the Moving Image in Queens. In conjunction with the New York Film Critic's Circle, the Museum is playing host to a continuing series called "Breaking Boundaries." Future screenings will include such beloved exercises in cinematic transgression as "Pink Flamingos" and "Belle de Jour." Tomorrow, though, Nathan Lee, the fearless chief film critic of The New York Sun, will introduce Pier Paolo Pasolini's uncompromising "Salo" (1975), which brings the visions of the Marquis de Sade into Mussolini's Italy, and reveals the deep, unsettling connections between libertinism and fascism. On Sunday, J. Hoberman of The Village Voice will present "Myra Breckenridge," Mike Sarne's notoriously over-the-top adaptation of Gore Vidal's novel -- an extravanganza of crossdressing, political satire and all-around tastelessness that features Mae West, Raquel Welch and Rex Reed, surely the only member of the Circle to have undergone an on-screen sex change operation. Shocking indeed. (Tomorrow at 2 and 4:30 p.m. and Sunday at 4:30 p.m., American Museum of the Moving Image, 35th Avenue at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens, (718) 784-4520. Tickets: $10. The series runs through Feb. 13. For a complete schedule check, www.movingimage.us.) A.O. SCOTT

title: Arts, Briefly; A New Yorker Clone Folds
description: Novy Ochevidets, a Russian magazine that uncannily resembled The New Yorker, has folded after just four months. It said it derived more from pre-Revolutionary literary journals than from The New Yorker, with which it did not have a licensing agreement. The publisher refused to comment about the closing, and the editor could not be reached. Moscow is flooded with glossy magazines about fashion and luxury goods, but there had been nothing to meet the needs of upper-middle-class intellectuals bored by musty Soviet-era literary journals. The demise of Novy Ochevidets, whose title translates as New Eyewitness, was predicted by many media critics, who said it was doomed to publish at a loss and found the contents too staid and derivative. title: BONUS PLAN FOR ENRON EMPLOYEES IS APPROVED
description: The Enron Corporation, the bankrupt energy trading company, won court approval yesterday to pay as much as $45 million in bonuses to employees who are responsible for winding down the company's operations. Enron, which is selling its assets to repay creditors, estimates that employees will ultimately receive about $16.8 million in bonuses. The company, which is based in Houston, will cease to exist once the asset sales are finished. Judge Arthur Gonzalez of United States Bankruptcy Court in New York authorized the payments after the company said it needed to give employees an incentive to stay with Enron until the liquidation was complete. Enron estimates proceeds from the remaining asset sales will total $1.1 billion, which would mean employees would receive $16.8 million, Brian Rosen, Enron's lead bankruptcy lawyer, said. Judge Gonzalez authorized bonuses of as much as $45 million if the proceeds reach $3 billion or more.

description: EPSTEIN--Fannie (Fine, Altman), March 27, 1915-January 16, 2005, of Manhattan, formerly of East Meadow and Brooklyn. Also by grandchildren, Michael and Rachel Bochnia, Sarah Luijpers (Patrick), Eve Burian (Ron), Beth Hounza (Max), David Koistinen (Tomoko), Janice Harris (Andrew) and seven greatgrandchildren. Fannie was a most loving daughter, sister, friend, wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Although she had little recognition or memory at the end of her long and productive life, her face would still light up with pleasure at the sight of her newborn great - granddaughter. Those of us who saw her smile and call Arielle "My baby" as she reached for her hand, were very moved. Fannie was a woman of opinion, dedication and awareness. Politically active till well into her 80's, her unflagging interest and involvement in the events of the world and the city in which she lived, never wavered. She loved the staff and her work at the Nassau Center in Woodbury, Long Island, and her winters in Guadalajara, Mexico. Her last 24 years were spent in New York City, where she was an active supporter of the Arts. She will be missed by everyone whose life she touched and she will be remembered by all with love and humor. Cremation private. We will arrange a memorial meeting for her in New York City this spring. Contact C/O Epstein, Apt 1505, 525 Audubon Ave, New York, New York 10040.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Warlord Escapes Suicide Bomb
description: A suicide bomber blew himself up in northern Afghanistan in what appeared to be an assassination attempt on the Uzbek leader Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, left, who survived unharmed. At least 21 others were injured. A Taliban spokesman, Abdul Latif Hakimi, contacted by telephone, said the Taliban carried out the attack in Shiberghan, General Dostum's hometown, as retribution for what he called his close collaboration with American forces in overthrowing the Taliban and his forces' ruthless treatment of Taliban prisoners. General Dostum's militia is being disarmed and demobilized, but he has been allowed to keep 200 bodyguards. He has made many enemies over the years, switching allegiances repeatedly to remain in power. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: State Jobless Rate Rises
description: New York State's unemployment rate rose slightly to 5.3 percent in December 2004, up from 4.9 percent in November, according to the federal government. It was the third consecutive month in which the state's unemployment rate was lower than the nation's, which remained at 5.4 percent. The job count in New York State's private sector increased by 4,400, or 0.1 percent in December, the same as the nation's rate of growth for the same period, the State Labor Department reported yesterday. Job growth was firmest in the educational and health services fields and in the leisure and hospitality industries, led by an increase in tourism in New York City. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUNNIFF, CAROL LESLEY (BAXTER)
description: CUNNIFF--Carol Lesley (Baxter). Carley Cunniff (Baxter) died of breast cancer on January 16, 2005, at her home in Lyme, Connecticut. Born on April 1, 1950, in Rockville Centre, NY, Carley was a graduate of Swarthmore College and Harvard Business School. She began her career at Dillon, Read & Co. and, after brief stints at Harry Winston and Warburg, Paribas, Becker, joined Ruane, Cunniff & Co. in 1983, where she was serving as executive vice president and director of both the firm and The Sequoia Fund upon her retirement in 2002. Carley had been diagnosed with breast cancer in late 2001. Famously generous with her time and energy, Carley sat on the Board of Managers at Swarthmore College, the Overseers Visiting Committee at Harvard Business School and the executive committee of the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering. Most recently, she served on the board and as director of the investment committee of the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme, Ct. Though Carley was a sharp-eyed investment analyst, she always had time to share with younger people in the investment business and at her firm. A number of her former associates have gone on to found their own successful firms and credit Carley's advice, support and friendship as critical to their success. Upon her retirement at the end of 2002, Carley and her husband Andy spent most of their time at their home in Lyme, Ct. Carley's natural creativity came to the fore as she spent much of her time landscaping and planting glorious gardens which surrounded her during her final years. She derived enormous pleasure from the radiance she created after she left the world of finance. Carley was a great beauty with impeccable taste, and a creature of unsurpassed kindness. She was a doting aunt and godmother, her husband Andy's perfect mate, a peerless friend and the best possible sport. She will be deeply missed by a wide circle of friends, former associates, and by her dear family. She is survived by her devoted husband, Andy of Lyme, Ct.; her parents, Richard and Marilyn Cunniff of Lloyd Harbor, NY; sisters, Hilary Cunniff of Pennington, NJ, and Jeanne Foussard of St. Paul, MN; brothers, Richard, Jr. of NYC and Peter of Harrington Park, NJ, and her stepdaughter, Eliza Riley of Mill Valley, Ca. A memorial service will be announced shortly. In lieu of flowers, Carley's family would appreciate contributions to The Carley CunniffPeter S. Dixon, M.D. Foundation, a charitable trust in formation, in memory of Carley. Its principal mission is to further understand the power of the human spirit during health and illness as it relates to the practice of medicine. Contributions may be directed to P.O. Box 800, Essex, Ct. 06426. CUNNIFF--Carley, on January 16, 2005, at home in Lyme, CT, of breast cancer at age 54. Until her retirement in 2002, Carley was Executive Vice President of Ruane, Cunniff & Co., Inc., and a Director of the firm's flagship Sequoia Fund. She joined the firm in 1983 and over the next 19 years worked diligently to make it a better place. All who knew her respected her integrity and judgment and admired her warmth and good will. She was a perceptive and skeptical analyst who proved a wonderful mentor. She was a trusted adviser who spoke to clients with clarity and wisdom about our investment philosophies and results. We were proud to have her as a colleague, but prouder to know her as a friend. We extend our affection and condolences to her family. Ruane, Cunniff & Goldfarb Inc. CUNNIFF -- Carley Baxter. The Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center mourns the passing of its Treasurer, Carley Cunniff Baxter. As a member of The Society's Executive Committee, Carley's wise counsel and sensitive leadership will be greatly missed. We offer our sincerest condolences to those who loved her. Mrs. Arie L. Kopelman Pres., The Society of MSKCC CUNNIFF--Carley. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme, CT mourn the passing of their beloved Trustee on January 16, 2005. We honor her accomplishments on our behalf and will always remember Carley's brilliant mind, wonderful sense of humor and gracious spirit.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Ex-Commissioner Pleads Guilty
description: The state's former agriculture commissioner has pleaded guilty to extortion and lying to federal agents in a scheme to assist a cockfighting ring. As part of the plea agreement, 10 other counts against the commissioner, Charles R. Sharpe, will be dismissed. Mr. Sharpe pleaded guilty to taking $10,000 from the ring after his 2002 election as commissioner in return for help with regulations, and to lying to the F.B.I. about a conversation with the local sheriff in which he said the attorney general approved the ring's activity as scientific bird testing, lawyers in the case said. Mr. Sharpe, who has been suspended since his indictment, submitted a resignation letter on Monday, his lawyer said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Pop Goes Shakespeare
description: The pop group Barenaked Ladies, right, will lend its talents to Shakespeare this summer, writing music for the Stratford Festival of Canada's production of "As You Like It." The Toronto-based band, best known for its playful live shows and often humorous songs like "If I Had a Million Dollars" and "Be My Yoko Ono," will record incidental music as well as the music for five songs in the play that will be sung by the actors. The Barenaked Ladies' lead singer, Steven Page, described writing music for Shakespeare's words as "a gift." In a statement, he said, "It's hard to ask for a better co-writer, really, even if he is a little unbending in his approach to collaboration." Set in the 1960's, this "As You Like It" will be directed by Antoni Cimolino and run from June 4 through Oct. 30 at the annual Shakespeare festival in Stratford, Ontario. COLIN CAMPBELL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WRISTON, WALTER B.
description: WRISTON--Walter B. On January 19, 2005 in New York City after an 18 month fight with pancreatic cancer. He was 85. Mr. Wriston was one of the most innovative financiers of our time. Mr. Wriston was born in Middletown, CT, and graduated from Wesleyan University and the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University. Following a year's service as a U.S. State Department officer and a four-year tour with the U.S. Army during World War II, Mr. Wriston joined Citibank in 1946. He held numerous positions at Citibank and served as chairman and chief executive officer of Citicorp for 17 years before retiring in 1984 after 38 years with the company. Mr. Wriston was a visionary who saw the future of the banking industry and the important role it would play in the global economy. He is credited with jumpstarting the electronic banking revolution with the introduction of the ATM as well as the expansion of Citibank's international franchise. At the time of Mr. Wriston's retirement, Citibank had bcome the world's largest bank with branches in 79 countries and its investment in computers and software surpassing $1.75 billion. An outspoken advocate on the need for the deregulation of the banking industry and the free flow of capital, Mr. Wriston was also a powerful voice in Washington and was named chairman of President Reagan's Economic Policy Advisory Board in 1982. Widely quoted for his forward thinking remarks, his most famous quote, "Information about money has become almost as important as money itself," is inscribed in the lobby of the New York Library of Science, Industry and Business. Mr. Wriston served as a director of several corporations including General Mills, General Electric, J.C. Penney, Pfizer and ICOS. In June 2004, Mr. Wriston received the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the Nation's highest civilian award. He is also the author of two books, In the Twilight of Sovereignty and Risk and Other Four-Letter Words. He is survived by his wife, Kathryn; daughter, Catherine Quintal; son-in-law, Richard Quintal; two grandchildren, Christopher and Barbara Catherine; and his sister, Barbara Wriston. Burial services will be private. A memorial service will be held in New York City on a date in February. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to The Lust Garten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer, 1111 Stewart Avenue, Bethpage, New York 11714. WRISTON--Walter B. The Trustees, Life Trustees, Physicians and Staff of NewYorkPresbyterian Hospital and the Overseers, Faculty and Staff of Weill Medical College of Cornell University are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend, Walter B. Wriston. A financier, philanthropist and Presidential Medal of Freedom recipient, Mr. Wriston championed the democratizing effects of globalization and information technology. A member of the Board of Trustees of the Hospital since 1975, he lent his uncommon vision, keen intellect and leadership skills to furthering our mission of excellence in patient care. We especially appreciate his early and prescient efforts to bring the benefits of information technology to the Hospital and Medical College as a member of the institutions' Joint Board. We also remember him as the co-founder of "Cabaret!," NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center's annual fund-raising event. He leaves an outstanding legacy of stewardship and benevolence. We will miss his wisdom, kindness, and friendship, and join with all those who knew him in mourning his loss. Our deepest condolences are extended to his beloved wife, Kathryn, and to the entire Wriston family. John J. Mack, Chairman, Board of Trustees Dr. Herbert Pardes, President & CEO Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Vice Chairman Charlotte M. Ford, Vice Chairman Peter A. Georgescu, Vice Chairman Jerry I. Speyer, Vice Chairman NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Sanford I. Weill, Chairman, Board of Overseers Dr. Antonio M. Gotto, Dean Weill Medical College of Cornell University

description: The individual who occupies the White House is almost always at the center of American political life, but Inauguration Day is about the presidency, not the president. So it was fitting that the noontime ceremony in Washington yesterday focused less on George W. Bush himself than the office he has been elected to occupy for another four years.
