description: Several people were shocked by stray voltage in separate incidents yesterday, officials said. In one case, four workers hired by the city to shovel snow said they felt currents through a grate near Seventh Avenue and 21st Street. Three of them were taken to St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan for treatment and released last night. A fourth refused treatment. In the East Village, a man was shocked by stray voltage from a scaffolding yesterday morning near the corner of Avenue B and East 13th Street, the Fire Department said. He was taken to Beth Israel Medical Center for treatment, but his condition was not known. A spokesman for Consolidated Edison said workers found stray voltage on a light hanging inside the scaffolding passageway and shut off the electricity. There were several other cases, but no serious injuries were reported. Con Ed said it was investigating. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Part Of Fast-Food Suit Reinstated
description: A federal appeals court yesterday gave new life to a lawsuit that seeks to hold McDonald's liable for obesity and heart ailments in teenagers who ate its hamburgers and fries. A ruling by a panel of judges for the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan reinstated part of the suit, after it was entirely dismissed in January 2003 by a federal district judge. The suit charges that McDonald's falsely advertised that its fast food was nutritionally beneficial when eaten regularly, and failed to disclose additives. The appeals court said that the suit could go forward under one broad New York statute that bans "deceptive acts or practices" in business. The suit was filed in 2002 on behalf of two New York teenagers, Ashley Pelman, who was 14 at the time and weighed 170 pounds, and Jazlen Bradley, then 19, who weighed 270 pounds. Julia Preston (NYT)

title: A Costly but Valuable Medical Device
description: Even as the Bush administration rails about the ballooning costs of entitlement programs, its Medicare officials are planning a big expansion of coverage for implantable devices that can help prevent sudden death from heart failure. The expansion could cost perhaps $3 billion a year and would be the most expensive decision about covering a single technology in the memory of Medicare officials. By statute, Medicare is required to base its coverage decisions only on health benefits, not price tags. The decision provides an excellent example of how medical costs are driven inexorably upward by costly but valuable technologies that save lives.

A graduate of New York University in 1935, he was a Certified Public Accountant, before becoming president of Polyplastex United, Inc. He was active in resettlement of Jewish immigrants from Europe to the Dominican Republic during the Holocaust. He was invited to join the government of the new State of Israel, but declined. His loving wife, Charlotte Peskin, predeceased him in 1990. After her death, he lived with his beloved companion Trudy Rose for 12 years. He leaves two sons Roger Peskin and Dennis Peskin, two daughters-in-law, Diane and Regina, a brother Solomon Parker, eight grandchildren, five great grandchildren, and two nephews. description: Alberto Gonzales's nomination as attorney general goes before the Senate at a time when the Republican majority is eager to provide newly elected President Bush with the cabinet of his choice, and the Democrats are leery of exposing their weakened status by taking fruitless stands against the inevitable. None of that is an excuse for giving Mr. Gonzales a pass. The attorney general does not merely head up the Justice Department. He is responsible for ensuring that America is a nation in which justice prevails. Mr. Gonzales's record makes him unqualified to take on this role or to represent the American justice system to the rest of the world. The Senate should reject his nomination.

The company, Jumpking Inc. of Mesquite, which announced the recall along with the Consumer Product Safety Commission, said it had received reports of numerous injuries related to the products, including head traumas and severe lacerations. The company said consumers should stop using the products, and call (866)302-8669 for free repair kits and more information. John Files (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Illegal Immigrants Detained
description: Four illegal immigrants from China, two men and two women, were discovered aboard a single-engine private plane that first fled from airborne federal agents and then followed its flight plan and landed in San Antonio. The authorities said after questioning the four that none appeared to pose a security threat and that they had probably paid to be smuggled into the United States to find work. The four are likely to be deported and the pilot, a Mexican, will probably be charged with immigrant smuggling, the police said. The plane was spotted by agents who were pursuing a second aircraft, which they also forced to land, and which was carrying 100 pounds of marijuana. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Outcry At Claims Against Jews
description: After an outcry by Russian liberals, human rights activists and Jewish leaders, a group of Communist and nationalist lawmakers withdrew their appeal to the prosecutor general demanding that Jewish organizations around the country be investigated and possibly closed down. The text of the seven-page letter, which became public on the eve of President Vladimir V. Putin's trip to Poland for the 60th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz, accused Jews of carrying out ritual killings, controlling Russian and international capital, and staging hate crimes against themselves. In a statement, the Israeli Embassy in Moscow called the letter "a classic demonstration of anti-Semitism" and demanded that Russian authorities take immediate measures. The Foreign Ministry said the lawmakers' appeal had "nothing to do with the official position of the Russian leadership." Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: AFTER MARKETWATCH PURCHASE, DOW JONES TO CUT 97 JOBS
description: Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, yesterday said it would cut 97 jobs as the company completed the purchase of the online news service MarketWatch. "The eliminated positions came from across the full range of operations, including from human relations, finance, technology, marketing and news," Mr. Christie said. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Vodafone Adds Customers
description: The Vodafone Group, the world's largest wireless company, said that it added 5.4 million customers in the fourth quarter of 2004, raising its customer total to 151.8 million and beating analysts' expectations. The chief executive, Arun Sarin, left, said the company continued to perform strongly across Europe and in the United States, where it is part owner of Verizon Wireless, but was still struggling in Japan, where it lags its competitors in offering third-generation mobile phone technology. The company cut its forecast for Japan and Mr. Sarin said he did not expect Vodafone's market share in the country to grow "for a few years." Heather Timmons (NYT)

description: With "American Idol" at 8 p.m. and "House" at 9 p.m., Fox has scheduled an odd pairing on Tuesday nights: the only thing this reality singing competition and this scripted hospital drama have in common is that each is led by a cranky British character (Simon Cowell for "Idol" and Hugh Laurie for "House"). But in the lineup's debut, the union appeared to work. As expected, the third episode of "American Idol" mowed over all competitors, drawing an estimated 27.7 million viewers, according to the overnight Nielsen ratings, and winning in every demographic that advertisers like. In the hour that followed, "House," lost more than half of the "Idol" audience, but it still managed to be No.1 in total viewers and among 18-to-49-year-olds, beating original episodes on all the other networks for the first time. One of the shows in its wake was NBC's "Scrubs," which has recently moved to 9 p.m. and continues to do poorly in the overnight ratings. Tuesday's episode did not benefit from the presence of Colin Farrell as a guest star: the episode yielded some of the sitcom's worst numbers for the season. KATE AURTHUR

On Tuesday night, the man, Nicholas Martin Jr., 17, above, was shot twice, once through the left wrist and once in the torso, the police said. He was taken to Jacobi Medical Center, where he was in serious but stable condition. The police said Mr. Martin, who is on mental health medication, brandished the knife when officers would not let him go to his room. But the set reflects his unflagging interest in slick design, with an oak screen by the Tokyo interior design firm Wonderwall, brass lamps by Shuwa Tei, a Japanese architect, and a teak table by BassamFellows, a New York design team. "The set is all solid hardwood," Mr. Brl said. "You walk into the studio and it smells fantastic." The show, which began on Tuesday, combines interviews, documentary segments and on-location reporting. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

The net loss equaled a penny a share and compared with a loss of $5.33 million, or 3 cents a share, a year earlier, the company, based in Seattle, said. Sales rose 34 percent, to $72.5 million, from $54.1 million, exceeding the $68.8 million average estimate of nine analysts polled by Thomson First Call. RealNetworks is selling more songs, games and subscriptions to watch music and video as it moves from selling software to selling content. Music sales almost tripled in the quarter, reaching 30 percent of total revenue. The company expects sales of $73 million to $74.5 million this quarter and a net loss of 1 cent to 2 cents a share, including the costs of an antitrust lawsuit against Microsoft. .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLAU, MAXINE
description: BLAU--Maxine. Resident of South Orange, New Jersey, passed away at her home on January 24 with her loving sister, family, and devoted friend by her side. Maxine was born on July 8, 1940 to the late Hope & Raymond Blau. A graduate of the University of Chicago, Maxine worked as a mainframe consultant for Honeywell and several other large corporations. Later she joined the family business Max Blau & Sons, Inc., and eventually became a principal in the company. Maxine enjoyed work, travel, cars, art and music. Her adventurous spirit knew no bounds. Her orchid and photography collection reflected her love of nature. She took time to enjoy all of life's beauty. She is survived by her devoted sister Adele, nephews David and Greg Cass, and beloved friend of 27 years Murray Levine. Maxine showed limitless strength in her battle with cancer. She lived significantly longer than everyone expected, and was a fighter until the end. Through her personal strength and positive attitude along with the support of Adele and Murray, and the dedication of doctors Daniel Roses, James Speyer, Silvia Formenti, and John Golfinos of NYU she lived with dignity and a high quality of life. Thank you all. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the NYU Clinical Cancer Center, c/o Dr. James Speyer, 160 East 34 St, 8th fl, NY, NY 10016. Family and friends will be received at her home, 218 North Woods Dr., South Orange, New Jersey, on Wednesday and Thursday January 26 and 27 from 2PM to 5PM and 7PM to 9PM.

This Los Angeles rapper, who was born Jayceon Taylor and is the latest protg of Dr. Dre, made a remarkably strong showing on the top of the Billboard album charts, with sales of 587,000 copies of his major-label debut, "The Documentary" (Interscope). In the typically slow period that follows the holiday shopping rush, the Game's album sold nearly 600 percent more last week than its nearest competitor, Green Day's "American Idiot" (Warner Brothers), which had 85,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. In fact, "The Documentary" sold 7.5 percent more than all the other albums of the Top 10 combined, including Eminem's "Encore" (Interscope, No. 3), Lil Jon's "Crunk Juice" (TVT, No. 4) and John Legend's "Get Lifted" (Columbia, No. 5). title: Snapping Out of a Dream With a Sharp Sliver of Funk
description: In "Black Bottom," a new piece Geri Allen played with her trio at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night, a sharp sliver of a funk phrase kept returning intermittently. It was nothing major, just a mark of the composer's hand. But a few minutes into the bustling piece, with all its movement and freedom and color and distraction -- the piece is named after a Detroit neighborhood, and perhaps it's a musical street-scene -- you started waiting anxiously for that phrase again. It snapped the piece back into focus from a drifting state.

title: GLAXO RECEIVES SECOND CLAIM FROM I.R.S. IN TAX DISPUTE

The Internal Revenue Service is seeking $1.9 billion in taxes on profits earned from 1997 to 2000, before a merger that formed the company. Glaxo, which is based in London, would also be responsible for $700 million in interest if the I.R.S. is successful. Last year, the I.R.S. claimed $2.7 billion for taxes between 1989 and 1996. The dispute concerns how Glaxo priced its drugs for sale through a unit in the United States. Glaxo estimated that it would owe the I.R.S. $2.5 billion in interest if the original claim is successful. Glaxo is contesting the claims and has taken a provision for the taxes.

description: The Korean mobile telephone company SK Telecom said its profit fell for a third consecutive quarter, declining 20 percent to 348 billion won ($337 million) in the fourth quarter. The town, Kitsault, built to support a molybdenum mine that closed just a few years after opening, has been deserted since the early 1980's, but caretakers have maintained it, cutting lawns and keeping buildings heated. Originally built by Amax Canada Development for about $40 million and later acquired by Phelps Dodge, the town reportedly sold for less than the asking price of $5.7 million. The new owner, Krishnan Suthanthiran, based in Springfield, Va., told The Globe and Mail that his ideas for the 320-acre town, 500 miles north of Vancouver, include a movie studio, a resort or an education center. title: Technology Briefing | Software: SAP To Forgo Profit Growth
description: SAP, the world's largest maker of business management software, will forgo profit growth this year as it offers discounts and invests more to lure American customers. Earnings growth will also slow as the company, based in Walldorf, Germany, hires about 3,000 employees in 2005. License growth is expected to rise 10 percent to 12 percent this year, the fastest growth since 2000, SAP said yesterday. Shares of SAP fell 3.11 euros, or 2.5 percent, to 120.99 euros in Frankfurt. Some analysts, including Mairi Johnson at the Goldman Sachs Group, had forecast margin growth of as much as 1 percentage point for 2005. The chief executive, Henning Kagermann, plans to take customers from Oracle as that company integrates its $10.3 billion purchase of PeopleSoft after an 18-month takeover battle.

(Sharon Stone received a worst supporting actress nod for her role in the film.) The historical epic "Alexander," starring Colin Farrell, Angelina Jolie and Val Kilmer, received six nominations, including worst picture, worst actor (Mr. Farrell) and worst actress (Ms. Jolie), with a worst director nod to Oliver Stone. The Razzies, as they are known, are selected by the members (about 675) of the foundation, founded by John Wilson, a self-described "lifelong cynic and cinemaniac." Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Plans To Cut 1,700 Jobs
description: AT&T plans to cut 1,700 jobs and close four customer service centers, according to the Communications Workers of America, a union representing telecommunications industry employees. The union said yesterday that AT&T planned to cut 200 technicians and 1,500 customer service representatives as part of a shutdown of call centers in Mesa, Ariz.; Syracuse; Marietta, Ga.; and Town and Country, Mo. AT&T said the layoffs were part of a previously announced reduction related to its plans to stop building its consumer telephone business. AT&T cut some 14,000 jobs last year and plans another 5,100 job cuts this year, including the latest 1,700 layoffs, said Tracey Belko, an AT&T spokeswoman. description: The Long Island Rail Road last night headed off the threat of a strike by persuading a federal judge in Brooklyn to bar engineers from walking out before a Feb. 18 hearing. A strike could have started as early as next week. The judge granted a temporary restraining order that will prevent a strike before then by members of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and Trainmen, said Vincent O'Hara, a lawyer for the union. Robert Evers, general chairman of the union, had threatened a walkout over a dispute about whether nonunion workers can move the railroad's trains when they are in a yard for repairs. The two new victims were from southern provinces. Health officials are also investigating the source of the disease in a family in the north. In that family, the infection was confirmed in two brothers, one of whom died. A third brother did not develop symptoms, and no other cases have been identified among others in the community. The W.H.O. said it expected addition sporadic human cases and occasional family clusters to occur. Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

description: A news analysis article on Dec. 16 about a thaw in relations between Egypt and Israel referred imprecisely to the numbers of Palestinian refugees living in refugee camps. Currently almost 4.2 million Palestinian refugees are officially registered, of whom 1.3 million live in camps, according to United Nations figures. The number of officially registered refugees passed one million in 1957; the camp population passed one million in 1995. Thus the number of Palestinian refugees who have lived in camps for generations is not in the millions. (Official refugee numbers do not reflect Palestinians who fled the West Bank during the 1967 war or their descendants, now believed to exceed 800,000; they are officially considered displaced persons.) The error was reported to The Times on Dec. 16; this correction was delayed for checking with several refugee organizations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, PHILIP
description: JOHNSON -- Philip. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of our esteemed Trustee Philip Johnson, whose devotion to the Museum spans its entire seventy-five-year existence. A leading member of the circle of young aesthetes who both supported and were nurtured by the vision of Alfred H. Barr, Jr., MoMA's founding director, Philip passionately devoted his energies to the institution throughout its history. A great number of its critically important milestones bear his imprint. Philip was present at the opening of the Museum, in 1929; he was the first director of MoMA's Department of Architecture -- unique among museums at the time--in 1931; with Henry-Russell Hitchcock, he organized the Museum's first architectural exhibition, the landmark "International Style" show, in 1932; and he organized "Machine Art," the Museum's first major exhibition on industrial design, in 1934. In 1949 he was appointed the first director of the recently unified Department of Architecture and Design, stepping down in 1954 to become the first Chairman of the Trustee Committee on Architecture and Design, a position in which he served for thirty-seven years. He joined the newly formed International Council of The Museum of Modern Art in 1955 and was named a Trustee of the Museum in 1957. Philip's devotion to Barr and to MoMA helped shape the institution not only intellectually but physically. Having returned to Harvard at the age of thirty-four to train as a professional architect, he became the Museum's principal adviser in its building programs and often served as its architect himself. Beginning in 1949, with the Grace Rainey Rogers Annex, he designed numerous structures and spaces that visually enhanced the Museum, including the beloved Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden, for fifty years the institution's very heart--a cherished restful space within the metropolitan bustle of midtown Manhattan. The south facade of his 1964 East Wing, now beautifully restored as part of the Museum's recent renovation and expansion, stands as a tribute to his midcareer devotion to the International Style architecture of Mies van der Rohe, whose reputation in America was largely built upon Philip's faithful support. Philip not only gave of his energies and talents but also bestowed upon the Museum an astounding munificence -- in works of art as well as financial support--that will long be remembered in an institution that is known for the generosity of its leaders. Instrumental to the extraordinary breadth of the collection of the Department of Architecture and Design, his giving also touched every other curatorial department, from drawings by Marcel Duchamp to prints by Donald Judd to photographs by Lionel Feininger. The experience of visitors to The Museum of Modern Art would be decidedly diminished without the magnificent paintings Philip gave it, including Oskar Schlemmer's "Bauhaus Stairway," Mark Rothko's "Number 10," Jasper Johns's "Flag," Andy Warhol's "Gold Marilyn Monroe," and Roy Lichtenstein's "Girl with a Ball." While crisscrossing Europe with Henry-Russell Hitchcock in 1930 to see the new architecture they would soon dub the International Style, the twenty-four-yearold Philip wrote to his mother of what had become a notable event: "Last night I hardly dreamt of buildings at all. It is a strange fact that not one night has gone by but that I have had some dream of architecture." Indeed, Philip never stopped dreaming of architecture, and for this, the staff, the Department of Architecture and Design, and the Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art will always be grateful. We extend our sympathies to David Whitney, his partner of forty-two years, to Mrs. John B. Dempsey, his sister, and to his entire family. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director Patricia Phelps de Cisneros, Chairman, Trustee Committee on Architecture and Design Terence Riley, The Philip Johnson Chief Curator of Architecture and Design Leon D. Black, Chairman, Trustee Committee on Painting and Sculpture John Elderfield, The Marie-Jose and Henry Kravis Chief Curator of Painting and Sculpture The Museum of Modern Art, New York

description: Federal investigators reviewing a deadly explosion at an acetylene-processing plant were examining whether a propane-fueled space heater may have caused the blast. Sandy Gilmour, a spokesman for the United States Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board, said that a preliminary investigation pointed to a heater with a five-foot-tall propane tank that was designed to keep several water tanks from freezing at Acetylene Service Company, where the blast occurred Tuesday, killing three workers and critically injuring a fourth. The propane tank itself did not blow up, Mr. Gilmour said. "The question is, did propane gas get loose and get ignited somehow?" Acetylene is still a possible cause, Mr. Gilmour added, but because there appeared to have been no acetylene tanks or pipes in the room where the blast occurred, propane is the investigation's focus. title: A Celebration of Soloists in Music Fit for an Emperor
description: At weddings in the German-speaking world today, friends of the couple often perform skits. In the 18th century, they did operas. When the Archduke Joseph of Austria married in 1765, the Imperial court had a composer write an opera for four of the Archduke's sisters to perform. The princesses had so much fun with the result, "Il Parnaso Confuso," that they asked him to write them another opera, "La Corona," for their father's name day a few months later. They must have been pretty solid singers. The composer was Christoph Willibald Gluck, and although it was a few years after the premiere of "Orfeo ed Euridice," his first great "reform opera," he didn't see the need for similar reforms in his music for his imperial patrons. The arias of "La Corona" are full of florid ornament, especially in the da capo sections.

After a Journey to Remember, St. Joseph's Finds a Quieter Path
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 - After last Tuesday night's game in the Palestra, that rocking, antediluvian bandbox of an arena, Phil Martelli, the baldish coach of the St. Joseph's basketball team, his tie askew, plopped down in a chair in the interview room. He was handed the box score of the game. He hooked on his reading spectacles, peered down at the sheet and winced, something he almost never did last season, when his Hawks were the talk and darling of the college basketball scene. Martelli knew the final score of this game, of course -- Penn 67, St. Joseph's 59 -- but examining the box score simply made it all the more painful.

title: Arts, Briefly; Ratings? They're 'Simple'
description: NBC's "West Wing" has worked with weak lead-ins all season: both "Hawaii" and "LAX" have been canceled, and "The Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Model Search" is doing poorly. Wednesday's episode of "The West Wing," now a retooled political drama, ended with an amicable, intelligent conversation between the show's two new characters, the Republican candidate for president, played by Alan Alda, and his Democratic rival, portrayed by Jimmy Smits, below. In its own way, this was as fantastical a scenario as ABC's "Alias" spins in the same 9 p.m. time slot, with its doomsday prophecies. . In the 9 p.m. hour in Nielsen's overnight rankings, "The West Wing" was fourth, "Alias" was third, and an hourlong block of CBS's "King of Queens" took second place. What was No. 1? The season premiere of Fox's "Simple Life," launched into first place by the "American Idol" booster rocket that preceded it at 8. In its third season, "The Simple Life" will follow Paris Hilton and Nicole Richie through a series of internships, in which they will undoubtedly excel as workers and treat their fellow man with kindness. Fox won the night in all key measures. KATE AURTHUR

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Prostitute Ring Dismantled
description: A yearlong investigation into an Internet escort service that authorities said generated more than $3 million a year culminated yesterday with the arrest of 25 people on various prostitution and money-laundering charges, the police said. The service, which called itself Julie's of New York City Escorts and Body Rubs, had been in operation for 10 years and employed 25 prostitutes, the police said. Yesterday's arrests included 15 prostitutes, as well as customers, security officers and phone operators. The police raided four Midtown apartments used for prostitution and one used as a phone center, and searched the owner's house in Nassau County. The owner, who they did not identify, is being sought. Michael Luo (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Taiwan Semiconductor Profit Growth Slows
description: The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, the world's largest supplier of made-to-order chips, said yesterday that profit growth slowed for the fourth straight quarter as factory use slid. The company said it would increase investment this year. Fourth-quarter net income rose 39 percent, to 22.2 billion Taiwan dollars ($697 million), or 0.96 Taiwan dollar a share, from 16 billion Taiwan dollars, or 0.69 Taiwan dollar a share, a year earlier, said the company, based in Hsinchu, Taiwan. Sales, reported earlier, rose 10.5 percent. Orders from companies like Texas Instruments failed to keep pace with Taiwan Semiconductor's expansion, reducing factory use to 88 percent. The chairman, Morris Chang, said the company still planned to invest $2.6 billion in 2005, or 8 percent more than in 2004. Taiwan Semiconductor said it expected to use 78 percent of its capacity in the first quarter.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Merrill In Joint Venture

Teaming with a local brokerage firm would allow Merrill to collect fees for domestic share sales and earn trade commissions when China opens its $435 billion stock market, Asia's third largest.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Radio D.J. Suspended
description: The radio station Hot 97 (WQHT-FM) suspended indefinitely its morning-show D.J., Tarsha Jones, known as Miss Jones, and her crew on Wednesday for broadcasting "Tsunami Song," which ridiculed the victims of last month's catastrophe in South Asia. The station said that Emmis Communications, which owns the station, and Hot 97 "will not tolerate such derogatory and racially insensitive content." "Tsunami Song," a parody of the 1980's famine relief song "We Are the World," has lyrics that include "Go find your mommy, I just saw her float by/A tree went through her head and now the children will be sold to child slavery" and several racial epithets. The song, first broadcast last week, has provoked outrage and prompted several sponsors, including McDonald's and Sprint, to sever ties with the station. Councilman John C. Liu, a Queens Democrat, said he would push to have the station fire Miss Jones. Lola Ogunnaike (NYT)

Where "The Cup" was the "Going My Way" of Buddhism, humanizing the earnest young monks and stern elders of a Buddhist retreat by portraying their goofy, adolescent enthusiasm for soccer, "Travelers and Magicians" takes an opposite approach. It is the secular humanist Dondup (Tshewang Dendup), a petty government official assigned to a remote village in the tiny Himalayan kingdom, who learns to suspect his affection for all things Western and regain a respect for traditional Buddhist ways.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEINBERGER, ILSE
description: STEINBERGER -- Ilse. Died peacefully January 5, 2005, in Manhattan, aged 98. Mother of Erica Steinberger McLean and grandmother of Chloe Helene Gordon McLean, both of New York City, and widow of Harry Steinberger. Ilse Helene Bretschneider was born December 22, 1906, in Buffalo, New York, and moved to Oakland, California with her family following her high school graduation at 15. She later graduated with Great Distinction from San Jose State College, where she was elected to Phi Kappa Phi. A gifted teacher, Ilse taught elementary school first in Modesto, California, beginning in 1956, and then on the Monterey Peninsula until her retirement in 1974. In 1978 she moved to New York, where she served as a tutor in the public school system, a reader for Lighthouse International, and a founding member and treasurer of the Gamma Alpha chapter of Delta Kappa Gamma International, a professional honorary society of women educators. She is also survived by a brother, Herman Schleusener, of Lake-of-the-Pines, California. Ilse was a wonderful, positive presence, a loving individual who possessed an appreciation of both children and adults, a youthful enthusiasm - for books, ideas, new experiences - a generous heart, an enduring love of life and a great capacity for laughter. Services will be private. Donations in her memory may be made to the Reading Services Program of Lighthouse International, 111 East 59th Street, New York, New York 10022, Attn: Marc Feinstein, or the World Fellowship Fund of the Delta Kappa Gamma Society International, P.O. Box 1589, Austin, Texas 78767-1589.

description: "See Arnold Run" may sound like a condescending title for an A&E biography of Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, but it is not a mean-spirited film. Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, PHILIP
description: JOHNSON -- Philip. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of our esteemed Trustee Philip Johnson. Philip was present at the opening of the Museum in 1929. He organized the Museum's first architecture and design exhibitions: "The International Style" in 1932 and "Machine Art" in 1934. In 1949 he was appointed the first director of the recently unified Department of Architecture and Design, stepping down in 1954 to become the first Chairman of the Trustee Committee on Architecture and Design, a position in which he served for thirty-seven years. Beginning in 1949, Philip designed numerous structures and spaces that visually enhanced the Museum, including the beloved Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden. The south facade of his 1964 East Wing, now beautifully restored as part of the Museum's recent renovation and expansion, stands as a tribute to his mid-career devotion to the International Style architecture of Mies van der Rohe. Philip bestowed upon the Museum an astounding munificence--in works of art as well as financial support--that will long be remembered in an institution that is known for the generosity of its leaders. Instrumental to the extraordinary breadth of the collection of the Department of Architecture and Design, his giving also touched almost every other curatorial department. The experience of visitors to The Museum of Modern Art would be decidedly diminished without the magnificent paintings Philip gave it, including Oskar Schlemmer's Bauhaus Stairway, Mark Rothko's Number 10, Jasper Johns's Flag, Andy Warhol's Gold Marilyn Monroe, and Roy Lichtenstein's Girl with a Ball. We extend our sympathies to David Whitney, his partner of forty-two years, to Mrs. John B. Dempsey, his sister, and to his entire family. David Rockefeller Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel President Glenn D. Lowry, Director Terence Riley, The Philip Johnson Chief Curator of Architecture and Design The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: The Listings; 'UNICA ZRN: DRAWINGS FROM THE 1960'S'
description: The artist and writer Unica Zrn (1916-1970) worked as a film editor and journalist before turning her attention to fiction, poetry and art. In 1953, divorced and the mother of two children, she met the artist Hans Bellmer, 14 years her senior, with whom she began a long, fruitful but tormenting relationship. She moved with him to Paris, where she met members of the Surrealist circle, including Henri Michaux, then immersed in his decadelong experiments with mind-altering drugs. Zrn called their encounter a "miracle," but it marked the onset of the mental illness the plagued her for the rest of her life. Despite repeated confinements to psychiatric hospitals, she wrote books of poetry, fiction and autobiography, and during a brief period in the 1960's produced the extraordinary drawings on view at Ubu Gallery. Inspired in part by Surrealist automatic techniques and by Asian and African objects that she remembered from her childhood home, the pictures are a cross between extravagant doodles and minutely controlled images of fantastic beings: human and bestial; figurative and abstract; composed of webs of delicate pen strokes in red, black or white ink. Like run-on nightmares, they are at once grippingly varied in detail and almost crushingly similar in overall tone. In 1970, with an autobiographical novel, "Dark Spring," completed, Zrn once again left a clinic to return to Bellmer, who, paralyized from a stroke, ended the relationship. Having nowhere to go, she jumped from the window of his apartment to her death. (Ubu Gallery, 416 East 59th Street, (212)753-4444, through April 16.) HOLLAND COTTER

description: Jean Grae is Tsidi Ibrahim, the daughter of two South African jazz musicians: the pianist Abdullah Ibrahim (formerly Dollar Brand) and the singer Sathima Bea Benjamin. She's also a cult hip-hop star, beloved (by a few) for her intricate rhymes, filled with elegantly stacked syllables and bittersweet jokes about the elusive (or, perhaps, illusive) nature of hip-hop fame. Last fall, she released her second album, "This Week" (Orchestral/Babygrande), which was sent to journalists with a news release promising, "This will be the record taking her out of the underground and into the mainstream." Um, maybe not -- Grae's quiet, monotone rhyme style provides lots of small pleasures but few big ones. Still, those small pleasures are sometimes enough, especially in "Not Like Me," where Grae spits a series of typically clear-eyed pick-up lines: "I walk up different on 'em/Talk slang often/Bought dinner on dutch/While most women do the wallet-clutch/Never ask stupid question/Make jokes, interesting/Wear more clothes and let their eyes do the undressing." Grae, above, makes frequent appearances in New York City clubs, and tonight she is to headline a South East Asia Relief Benefit in Brooklyn with E.O.W. and DJ Snooze. title: The Listings; DAN STEVENS
description: Love hurts -- a lot -- in the thorn-filled forest in Peter Hall's thrilling new production of "As You Like It." For this emotionally rich interpretation of Shakespeare's comedy of cross-dressed courtship, Sir Peter movingly emphasizes how scary it is to be young, romantic and thin-skinned in a treacherous world. Rebecca Hall (Sir Peter's daughter) has received plenty of well-deserved acclaim for presenting a Rosalind as notable for her insecurity as for her cleverness. But spare a few plaudits for a recent graduate of Cambridge University named Dan Stevens, who plays Rosalind's gawky, moony suitor, Orlando. Mr. Stevens, above, tempers his teen-idol good looks with a vibrant, appropriately Shakespearean sense of how love makes fools of even the heartiest young men. His tongue-tied wonder upon Orlando's first encounter with Rosalind provokes guaranteed laughter, even as it makes many of those watching him feel a bit like the old rou played by Maurice Chevalier in "Gigi," who sang, "I'm glad I'm not young anymore." title: In Quebec City
description: QUEBEC can give provincialism a good name. Orphaned by mother France, dominated by Britain (after what Qubcois still call the Conquest) then for years by majority-Anglophone Canada, the people of Quebec have followed Voltaire's advice to tend to their own garden. This is especially true of Quebec City, the provincial capital. Proudly dated, lovingly maintained, Quebec City has charm to spare, particularly within the walls of the Old Town and in the Lower Town tucked between those walls and the St. Lawrence River. Winter brings comically low temperatures that linger well into March, but in a somewhat manic variation on "If God gives you lemons, make lemonade," Quebec puts on a raucous carnival, which this year starts today and runs through Feb. 13. Travelers with a retro lifestyle will find the city especially welcoming: at pretty much any hour you can find a drink, smoke indoors, wear fur and eat wild game. This backwoods vigor coexists with serious refinement that can be seen in the quality of the restaurants and hotels and the profusion of art galleries. To a Yankee it all seems European. But there is no place like this in Europe; there is nothing else like it in North America, either. And that's reason enough to celebrate. SCOTT L. MALCOMSON

The militants, two of them women, were suspected of being pro-Chechen members of an extremist group called Yarmuk, believed responsible for a raid on the republic's anti-narcotics agency last month in which a large cache of weapons was looted. title: The Listings; JANIE TAYLOR
description: Ms. Taylor is one of those dancers you keep rediscovering, season after season, seeing her expressive mix of slyness, aplomb and technical pizazz as if for the first time. Where has she been all this time, you wonder, sometimes because Ms. Taylor, above, seems to disappear or dance eccentrically. But then you remember feeling the same surprised delight the last time you saw her dance. This weekend New York City Ballet will present a sort of Taylor mini-feast, with performances in Jerome Robbins's glowing, formalistic "Goldberg Variations" tonight; in George Balanchine's ebullient "Who Cares?" tomorrow afternoon; and in Peter Martins's "Eros Piano" tomorrow night. They've given the girl the day off on Sunday. From Houston, Ms. Taylor finished her training at the City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet, graduating in 1998 to become a company apprentice for a month before moving into the corps. Lead roles came to her the next year. Only 18 then, she also brought a distinctive perfume and abandon to the doomed young heroine of "La Valse." Last week she was named a principal. There is something of Suzanne Farrell's suspect innocence in Ms. Taylor's performing. But mostly, there is the caviar pleasure of her smooth reconciliation of opposites: recklessness and serenity, bold incisiveness and dreaming amplitude. Steps, gestures and characterizations fall away before the immediacy of her dancing. And for hardcore or distant Taylor connoisseurs, there is always the 2003 video "Barbie in 'Swan Lake,"' for which she served as the model for Carlita the Skunk. (Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, Manhattan, (212)870-5570. Tickets: $30 to $83.) JENNIFER DUNNING

description: The Honda Motor Company reported net earnings of 150.8 billion yen ($1.5 billion) for the quarter ended in December, nearly unchanged from a year earlier, but raised its forecast for the full year on strong sales in China and the benefits of cost-cutting. World Briefing | Europe: France: Mad Cow Disease Found In Goat
description: Mad cow disease has been found in a French goat slaughtered in 2002, the European Commission and the French Agriculture Ministry said. It is the first time that the disease, clinically known as bovine spongiform encephalopathy, has been found in a goat under natural conditions. It was widespread in cattle in Europe in the 1990's and has more recently appeared in Canada. Experts originally believed that the goat, from a farm in Als, in southern France, was afflicted with scrapie, a disease common to sheep that is similar to mad cow. The goat and its herd of about 300 animals were destroyed, and officials said there was no danger that their meat had entered the human food chain. French farmers raise about 1.2 million goats, most of them to provide milk for dairy products like cheese. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; NBC Edges Past CBS
description: On Thursday, a night of repeats left CBS tied with NBC in the number of households, but NBC was No. 1 in total viewers and in the 18-to-49 audience it seeks. As of this week, CBS moved "Wickedly Perfect" from its Thursday slot to television's equivalent of purgatory, Saturday night. In its place was a repeat of "Without a Trace," followed by "CSI" and then another "Without a Trace." Against that lineup, NBC was able to win at 8 and 10 p.m., but an original "Apprentice" came in second to a "CSI" repeat for the second week in a row. On Fox, "The O.C." continued to benefit from the absence of CBS's "Survivor." The soap opera drew 8.07 million viewers, its best numbers since early November. There could be another factor in the "O.C.'s" bounce: the show has heavily promoted a same-sex courtship between Marissa (Mischa Barton) and Alex (Olivia Wilde), above. KATE AURTHUR

Arts, Briefly; Arrest at the British Museum
description: An arrest at the British Museum may represent a breakthrough in the effort to solve thefts that have plagued it and the Victoria and Albert Museum in London in recent months. A spokeswoman for the British Museum would say only that on Wednesday afternoon a security guard in the Greek and Roman gallery noticed a man carrying pliers and a piece of wire and acting suspiciously. A tussle followed, and a call for help was radioed. The police said that when they arrived about 5 p.m., museum workers had detained a 48-year-old man. The man was arrested and released on bail; he is to return to the Holborn police station on March 14, pending further investigation. In the last few months, 15 pieces of medieval Chinese jewelry have been stolen from a cabinet in the British Museum's Oriental and Antiquities gallery, and the Victoria and Albert has reported three thefts of small objects from cabinets while the museum was open to the public. Arts, Briefly; A Faint Chant to 'Free' Fiona Apple
description: About 15 freezing Fiona Apple fans, watched by almost as many reporters, gathered outside the offices of Sony BMG on Madison Avenue yesterday to demand the release of Ms. Apple's long-delayed new album. Led by Dave Muscato, a 21-year-old musician from Columbia, Mo., the group chanted, "We want Fiona!" and asked passersby to sign a petition begun online that had more than 23,000 signatures. Mr. Muscato said that Ms. Apple, right, who has not released a new album in more than five years, had delivered an album to Sony's Epic Records that was rejected by the label because it lacked a clear hit song. On Mr. Muscato's Web site, www.freefiona.com, he urged fans to e-mail Sony executives and said he had sent the corporation 1,500 foam apples decorated with the names of 4,000 signers of the petition. Epic Records said it was still waiting for Ms. Apple to turn in a finished product. "It's our understanding that Fiona is still in the midst of recording her next album," Steve Barnett, the president of the label, said, "and we at Epic Records join music lovers everywhere in eagerly anticipating her next release." BEN SISARIO

title: Arts, Briefly; Prize for Dutilleux
description: The French composer Henri Dutilleux, 89, below, was named the winner of the annual Ernst von Siemens Music Prize yesterday, an honor valued at $195,000. In bestowing the award, given to outstanding musicians in contemporary music, the jury said Mr. Dutilleux's "organic, filigree" music unfolds with "poetic clarity." According to the district attorney, Lucille Miller intended to make it look as if the car had rolled over an embankment and burst into flames. title: EARNINGS CLIMB 3% AT HONEYWELL INTERNATIONAL

The company reported net income of $419 million, or 49 cents a share. That matched the consensus forecast of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. A year earlier, the company posted a profit of $407 million, or 47 cents a share. Revenue totaled $6.64 billion, up 7.3 percent from $6.19 billion a year earlier. Sales at Honeywell's aerospace division, the company's largest, increased 7 percent, to $2.52 billion, for the quarter. As almost anyone but Mr. Reuter could have predicted, that set off panic in the neighborhoods where hundreds of thousands of people use the lines to get to work. He has since clarified his estimate to a matter of months and, we hope, learned a lesson in the importance of accurate communication with his customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEINFELD, THOMAS A.
description: STEINFELD--Thomas A., 87, died on January 13 2005, after a brief illness. A man who loved life, his family and his friends, Tom is survived by his loving wife Viviane, his daughter Jill and her husband Saul, his son Geoffrey and stepsons Edmond and Robert as well as his granddaughter Jocelyn, grandson Jonathan and his wife Meredith. His first wife Joan died in 1973. A patrician gentleman, who exuded grace, charm and warmth and the highest moral principles, Tom exemplified commitment, professionalism, kindness and generosity from an age long gone by. Tommy to his friends and "Mr. Playbill" to the many people who knew him through out his storied 65 year career with the magazine that symbolizes Broadway as much as he did. Blinded by macular degeneration, he continued to be the consummate salesman. A Walk down Madison Avenue with Tom would not be without interruption by mutual greetings with leaders in advertising and publishing. He was as comfortable under the white lights of Broadway as he was down the halls of "Corporate America". He was a true giant in his industry and as a human being. He will be greatly missed by those whose lives he touched.

Retired professor of Aeronautical, Electrical and Mechanical Engineering at the University of Detroit and WWII veteran (USN). He was known as a passionate teacher who expected his students to be able to think creatively when solving problems. During his life, he consulted with many companies and governmental agencies on a wide range of contracts from engine design to metal stress analysis. He was the beloved husband of the late Irene. Loving father of Adrienne, Gerard, Diane and Sheila; devoted grandfather of Christopher, Samuel, Marissa, Claire, Stacey, Christine, Tallulah and Lukas. A professor with a curious mind, a mathetician, a historian, a loving gentle man who from a young age journeyed to foreign places and time through the pages of books. He lived with dignity and touched many lives with his wisdom, knowledge and compassion. You left us too soon. We know you missed Mom. We love you very much. You were the best Dad and Grandpa a child could ever have. It was a wonderful life with you and Mom!

title: Reggae Riddims and the Sound of London Grit

She learned English about the time she discovered another language: hip-hop, the perfect vernacular for describing life as a refugee in a squalid housing estate in South London. Now 28, she performs as M.I.A., for "Missing in Acton," a nod both to her London borough, Acton, and to the guerrilla spirit of her lyrics. After releasing two singles, the dancehall-inflected "Galang" and "Sunshowers," last year, XL Records will release M.I.A.'s much-anticipated first album, "Arular," in February. This week, she will play benefit shows at the Knitting Factory's Los Angeles (Feb. 3) and New York (Feb. 5) locations to raise money for tsunami relief in Sri Lanka. Joel Topcik recently spoke to Ms. Arulpragasam about what she's listening to right now and why.

Occupying a refurbished 150-year-old mansion once owned by a textile baron, the museum has for decades served as a kind of public attic for local curiosities. Along with a few paintings of the Cos Cob school, its eclectic wares have included, at various times, a giant clam, a foulmouthed parrot, stuffed bears and a shrunken human head.

In Gary Winick's 13 GOING ON 30 (2004), Jennifer Garner's awkward adolescent Jenna Rink wakes up in the future, where she's a successful magazine editor with a chic lower Fifth Avenue apartment, a sports-star boyfriend, a car service and, wonder of wonders, breasts. This is just a piece of comedy fluff, but the adorable Ms. Garner makes it worth watching. Mark Ruffalo plays her formerly chubby best friend from childhood who has grown up to look awfully sexy. Naturally, Jenna learns valuable lessons about superficiality, disloyalty and dishonesty. Most important, though, she learns how much the grown-up work world is like middle school -- Saturday at 9 p.m. on Starz.

title: Forget Armor. All You Need Is Love
description: JAN. 30 is here at last, and the light is at the end of the tunnel, again. By my estimate, Iraq's election day is the fifth time that American troops have been almost on their way home from an about-to-be pacified Iraq. The four other incipient V-I days were the liberation of Baghdad (April 9, 2003), President Bush's declaration that "major combat operations have ended" (May 1, 2003), the arrest of Saddam Hussein (Dec. 14, 2003) and the handover of sovereignty to our puppet of choice, Ayad Allawi (June 28, 2004). And this isn't even counting the two "decisive" battles for our nouveau Tet, Falluja. Iraq is Vietnam on speed -- the false endings of that tragic decade re-enacted and compressed in jump cuts, a quagmire retooled for the MTV attention span.

title: Racing With Sam
description: At first, Sam Berns looked as odd as all the kids whose pictures I had been studying: big bald head, beaky nose, strangely undersize chin and mouth, blue veins twisting beneath a translucent scalp. He was very short and very skinny, and he had a stiff-hipped waddle when he walked. But after I spent a few minutes with him, the oddness melted away, and I was in the vivid vortex of Sam's personality -- noisy, jokey, smart, imaginative and just a little bit full of himself. The articles I'd read about Sam's disease didn't quite jibe with the bossy little kid who barked, "No shoes in the playroom!" the minute I walked in the door of his home in Foxboro, Mass., southwest of Boston. Sam has progeria, which is usually described as a grossly accelerated form of aging that turns children into wizened old men and women before their teens. But this child was no wizened old man.

title: A Question of Numbers
description: Roger Lowenstein makes a convincing case that the long-term projections of the Social Security actuaries are both unreliable and pessimistic. He points out that if only some of the pessimistic assumptions were revised upward, the predicted shortfall would virtually disappear. Yet his conclusion that "prudence dictates taking steps now" does not follow. When a problem may be nonexistent, and certainly distant, it is actually imprudent to act simply to placate those who hyperventilate over a manufactured crisis.

At the end of the 20th century, we woke up again and found out that we had become a powerful information-age economy. These monumental transformations took place in a virtual public policy vacuum. In fact, stimulating or shaping economic growth has always been a state public policy backwater. Sure -- we talked the policy talk -- but rarely did we seriously walk the policy walk.

title: Middle Age? Bring It On
description: The Red Hat Society A great deal of attention and study have been devoted to individuals who, as a result of feeling marginalized by mainstream culture, adopt a recognizable visual look and form a new social group. Take the 1979 book "Subculture: The Meaning of Style," in which Dick Hebdige deconstructed punks, mods, teddy boys and others. Hebdige called them "spectacular subcultures," and his observations apply to any number of groups, from goths to skateboarders to b-boys. Communicating "significant difference," as well as group identity, Hebdige wrote, "is the 'point' behind the style of all spectacular subcultures." It almost goes without saying that nearly all of these groups were and are made up of young people, and that these days much of the studying is done by marketers, professional trend-spotters and a huge chunk of the entertainment industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LENCEK, RADO L.
description: LENCEK--Rado L. Professor Emeritus of Slavic Languages and Civilizations at Columbia University and the Institute on East and Central Europe, School of International and Public Affairs died on January 27th in Riverdale, NY. Born in Slovenia in 1921, Lencek was a prolific scholar of linguistics, philology and ethnography. He was a member of seven central and east European Academies of Sciences and Arts and of ACLS and founded the Society for Slovene Studies. title: A Sponsor's Obligations at a Co-op
description: Q. I own a co-op in an eight-unit building in Park Slope. Three units are rentals, owned by the original sponsor. The building is self-managed, with the five of us who own and live here doing all the work. We are very resentful about doing work that maintains the sponsor's investment. She pays maintenance, as we all do, but can we legally require her to pay an additional monthly fee in lieu of her contributing to the work of managing the building? Can we fine her for failing to attend meetings for the last seven years? . . . Beth Harpaz, Brooklyn.

From allowing minors to help run bingo games and raffles, to prohibiting unsolicited faxes, none of them could thaw what felt like a deep freeze. title: Jia in Hong Kong
description: THE BASICS Slick but intimate, the Jia opened last March as the first Philippe Starck-designed hotel in Asia, and as such has banished almost all Asian influence beyond the Shanghai Tang attire worn by the hotel's uniformly helpful staff. The lobby dcor, in typical Starck style, mixes formal lines with modern whimsy: a winged armchair wears a repeating pattern of electric fans, a long settee with gilted, rococo trim is covered in a sleek silvery polyester. Good-looking but uninviting, the furniture hardly inspires lounging. That said, the lobby is both pleasing and restorative, with dim lighting and lighted candles soothing a late-night arrival, and a tucked-away snack bar offering free beverages, fruit or candy at all hours. Information: (852) 3196-9000; www.jiahongkong.com.

In the fall of 2003, before the Scissor Sisters even had a full album, the D.J. Javier Peral mixed them into Luca Luca's show. Calls poured in afterward from spectators eager to learn the band's name, and the word of mouth began to spread.

Predeceased by her husband, William Hunt (Chappy) Diederich, she is survived by her half-sister, Hannah Harris, three children, Susan, Lynn and Michael, and his wife Elizabeth, and two granddaughters, Alana and Mikayla. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANDREWS, SARA SONSOL
description: ANDREWS -- Sara Sonsol. Friends and relatives mourn the passing of Sara Sonsol Andrews on January 23, 2005, after a long illness. Sara was a longtime activist in the National Organization for Women, where she served on the Board of Directors for many years; in the anti-war movement, and in the Downtown Independent Democrats. She also served as Treasurer of the Board of Directors of Southbridge Towers, where she lived for more than 30 years. As a child, she emigrated from Italy with her family who were fleeing Nazi persecution of Jews. She was raised in the Bronx, and as an adult worked as a Controller for many companies. Her community of friends will miss her strong convictions and her dedication to women's issues. She will be missed by her reading group friends and many others whose lives she touched. She will be buried on Tuesday, January 25. A memorial is being planned for March, with date, time and location to be announced.

title: Up Front
description: After her first book, "A Return to Modesty," appeared in 1999, it seemed Wendy Shalit was everywhere. Only two years out of Williams College, where she earned a degree in philosophy, she was suddenly the media's favorite -- or at least its most frequently cited -- defender of what she called "the lost virtue" of modesty and a proponent of the view that the sexual revolution has done American men and women more harm than good. Then, just as suddenly, Shalit dropped out of the culture wars. What happened? As Shalit mentions in her essay, "The Observant Reader," which begins on Page 16, she spent about three years in Israel, at first satisfying her curiosity about her religious heritage and then committing herself to it. Her Torah studies didn't lead her to become a rabbi -- much to the disappointment of her grandmother -- but they did lead to marriage and family and the traditions of Orthodox Judaism. Shalit and her husband and infant son now live in Toronto, where she's at work on a second book, based on the letters she exchanged with young readers after the publication of "A Return to Modesty." Does her essay for us on Orthodox Jews in contemporary American fiction signal her return to the culture wars? "Some may treat it as a war," Shalit responds, "but to me it's just about challenging the norm, offering ideas and approaches that help people find their own authentic voices." The Editors

title: Travels With Omar

I found a local pinassier, Omar, at the water's edge. He was a lean Songhai in his early 30's and had a scraggly beard. With his turban rakishly tufted, his black sirwal trousers rolled up, his belt-loop silver dagger, he called to mind a pirate, if a kindhearted one. He moved with a pirate's swagger, which made sense: a pinassier here was a Big Man.

By bedtime, after the virus had clobbered Neve, 7; Veda, 3; and Luka, 18 months, Dad was logging on to type his own send-up of the insanity in his blog, the Zero Boss. And Grandma Bunny weighed in a few days later with a 1,000-word treatise called "The Flu From Hell" on her site, Bunny Beth's Bargains.

title: QUICK BITE/Bergenfield; We Don't Need No Stinking Taco Bell
description: For many Americans, Mexican food conjures late-night, drive-in, fast-food joints, serving bastardized value-priced carbo-loaded Tex-Mex that barely resembles the true regional flavors of a country that has the most complex food history in the Western hemisphere. At La Batalla in Bergenfield, however, you can get the genuine article. The cooks and owners, Santiago and Juan Huerta, are both seasoned veterans of the venerated el Bandito restaurant in Rockland County. The brothers came to the United States in 1980 from Puebla, Mexico, with dreams of opening their own restaurant. In January 2003, they set up shop in an old, dingy diner. Despite the restaurant's gruff exterior, the company is warm and friendly, and the food is hearty and spicy.

The lobby dcor, in typical Starck style, mixes formal lines with modern whimsy: a winged armchair wears a repeating pattern of electric fans, a long settee with gilted, rococo trim is covered in a sleek silvery polyester. Good-looking but uninviting, the furniture hardly inspires lounging. That said, the lobby is both pleasing and restorative, with dim lighting and lighted candles soothing a late-night arrival, and a tucked-away snack bar offering free beverages, fruit or candy at all hours. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAILEY, WILLIAM O.
description: BAILEY--William O. Former president, chief operating officer, and vice chairman of Aetna Life & Casualty Company and former CEO and chairman of the board of MBIA Inc., died January 28, 2005 of pneumonia at age 78. A leading figure in the insurance and financial guarantee industries for five decades, Mr. Bailey played a key role in launching the financial guarantee industry in the early 1970's, a multi-billion dollar industry today. He was most recently chairman, CEO and president of Terra Nova (Bermuda) Holdings and Terra Nova Reinsurance Ltd., (London). Born on July 1, 1926 in Syracuse, NY, the son of William E. and Kate Olliver Bailey, he grew up in Northampton, MA, served in the United States Navy during World War II, and graduated from Dartmouth College in 1947. He received his MBA in Insurance from the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce at the University of Pennsylvania in 1949. A former resident of West Hartford, CT, Southampton, Bermuda, and Moultonborough, NH, he was predeceased by his parents, his sister Ann Bailey Doane and two sons, John Mason Bailey and Thomas Wood Bailey. He is survived by his wife of 26 years, Carole Parsons Bailey, and three children, son George (wife Marsha) Bailey of Northampton, MA; daughter Janet (husband Wilson) Faude of West Hartford, CT, and daughter Carolyn Bailey of Lexington, MA, as well as six beloved grandchildren, Kai and Aquila Bailey, Sarah and Paul Faude, and Adriana and Dylan Akers. Also surviving are nephews George Woodward Doane of Richmond, WA, and Robert Bailey Doane of Vallejo, CA. He is also survived by his longtime caregiver and friend Sylvia Grant-Reeves. Friends may call Tuesday, February 1 from 5-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, February 2 at 10:30 AM at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51 St. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 5 at 11:00 AM at St. John's Episcopal Church in West Hartford, CT. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the St. Bartholomew's Church Flower Fund, The William O. Bailey Scholarship Fund at Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH, or the Squam Lakes Association Sailing Program, Holderness, NH 03245.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEINGOLD, JOSEPH
description: FEINGOLD--Joseph, born in Fleischman, New York, on December 12, 1912, to Charles Feingold & the former Bessie Feinstein. He was raised in Brooklyn, New York, and died in Phoenix, Arizona, on January 22, 2005. In recent years he resided in Grosse Ile, Michigan. Dr. Feingold attended the University of Michigan, graduating Phi Beta Kappa in 1933 and he graduated from the University of Michigan Medical School in 1937. He served in the U.S. Army Medical Corps' European Theater during World War II. Dr. Feingold practiced general and internal medicine for over forty years in Fort Edward, New York. He was the quintessential small-town doctor carrying a black bag and making house calls. He was predeceased by his wife, the former Ruth Bartlett. He is survived by their four daughters: Estelle (George) Bletsas of Grosse Ile, Michigan; Margaret (Charles) Owens of Grosse Ile, Michigan; Lois (Laurence) Feingold-Taff of Cabin John, Maryland; and Barbara (David) Chardavoyne of San Antonio, Texas. He is also survived by seven grandchildren and ten greatgrandchildren. Dr. Feingold was a strong patient advocate, a voracious reader, a lover of history, and a lifelong reader of the New York Times.

title: The Meter's Running and So Are the Hidden Cameras

After all, her date had just been groping her and trying to persuade her to take him home. But after a moment's hesitation they both sign the release to allow the scene to be broadcast.

title: Minetta Moments
description: WHEN Al Pacino as Frank Serpico moves out of his Brooklyn neighborhood to live his bohemian-cop life, he takes up residence at No. 5-7 Minetta Street. Though not stated as such in the film, the address, with the dark red brick, the curving steps down, set on a small crooked street, was unmistakable, at least for me. For eight years, I've been walking down the same steps Al Pacino took when the movie was shot in 1973. Seeing the film again recently, I was thrilled to be reminded of Sidney Lumet's location-decision and became curious about the street's past.

title: Among the Peculiars
description: I grew up among blood relatives who, while not nearly as cold or as mean as Cornwell's adoptive family, were controlling, neglectful and occasionally abusive enough to cause me to feel quite out of place among my "own" people. While my emotional distance from my so-called real family was not as profound as Cornwell's from the people who raised him, it was strong enough to demystify the prevailing romance of genetic inheritance and enabled me to recognize and appreciate the deep connections that are possible among people who treat one another with affection and respect regardless of their biological relationship to one another.

title: Inside the List
description: THE SEX CHRONICLES: In the genre that's become known as urban erotica, there's no bigger name than Zane, whose 10th novel, "Afterburn," holds the No. 11 spot on the hardcover fiction list this week. Zane's good-natured books are filled with smart, believable and self-deprecating young and middle-aged black characters; they are also filled with sex scenes that will smoke your fingerprints off. (Upon learning that Zane's novels were being issued in Japan, The Guardian of London took pity on the translator who had to render faithfully lines like: "No matter how hoochie I tried to be, she out-hoochied me every single time.") Zane is the pseudonym of a suburban mother of three -- she refuses to divulge her real name -- who is in her late 30's and lives outside Washington. She began writing erotic stories in the late 1990's when, as a single mother, she was looking for something to do after her children went to bed. The stories became popular after she posted them on the Web, and she later self-published her first book, "The Sex Chronicles," which sold more than 100,000 copies. Zane is well on her way to establishing herself as a habanero-hot global brand. She has founded her own publishing house, owns a bookstore, has film deals in the works and hopes to start a line of lingerie. If the titles of two of her forthcoming books -- There's a Pitbull in My Bed" and "Dear G Spot" -- are any indication, Zane is looking to out-hoochie almost every writer alive.

title: Reggae Riddims and the Sound of London Grit
description: !IN 1986, 10-year-old Maya Arulpragasam and her family fled the civil war in Sri Lanka and settled in England. She learned English about the time she discovered another language: hip-hop, the perfect vernacular for describing life as a refugee in a squalid housing estate in South London. Now 28, she performs as M.I.A., for "Missing in Acton," a nod both to her London borough, Acton, and to the guerrilla spirit of her lyrics. After releasing two singles, the dancehall-inflected "Galang" and "Sunshowers," last year, XL Records will release M.I.A.'s much-anticipated first album, "Arular," in February. This week, she will play benefit shows at the Knitting Factory's Los Angeles (Feb. 3) and New York (Feb. 5) locations to raise money for tsunami relief in Sri Lanka. Joel Topcik recently spoke to Ms. Arulpragasam about what she's listening to right now and why.

title: OPEC Ministers Leave Production Unchanged

In Suspended Animation, in Limbo, in Japan
description: THE Japanese director Hirokazu Kore-eda makes movies about people whose circumstances are tenuous, unresolved, perfectly ambiguous -- people who are in the profoundest sense neither here nor there. So it seems fitting, somehow, that I'm meeting Mr. Kore-eda in a small conference room, with no view, in a blandly modern Upper East Side Manhattan hotel. In this nowhere place (which feels a little like the featureless, impersonal anteroom to eternity depicted in Mr. Kore-eda's 1998 "After Life") we talk about his new film, "Nobody Knows," which opens in New York on Friday. The story -- based on an actual case -- is about four children, aged 5 to 12, who have been abandoned by their flighty single mother to fend for themselves in a tiny Tokyo apartment. The siblings live in a kind of suspended animation, awaiting their mother's promised return -- in a state of permanent, agonized irresolution.

Paid Notice: Deaths   WAXMAN, ISIDORE HAROLD
description: WAXMAN -- Isidore Harold, devoted husband, father and grandfather, died just before Shabbat on Friday, January 21, 2005. Born in 1916, Mr. Waxman was a graduate of Townsend Harris High School and the City College of New York. Mr. Waxman was in many ways the embodiment of the Greatest Generation; the record of his life is a testament to the courage and perseverance for which that generation has come to be known. For 22 years he served with honor and bravery in the New York City Fire Department - retiring as a battalion chief in 1961 - purposefully choosing to work in the city's most impoverished neighborhoods. Mr. Waxman went on to a successful and challenging career with Rose Associates, the developers. He retired in 1981 as a senior executive. An avid fisherman and photographer, Mr. Waxman spent his retirement traveling Europe and Asia with his devoted wife of 64 years, Anne. To those whose lives he touched, he will be remembered as a man of deep faith, an unabating love for his family, and, above all, an unceasing intellectual curiosity that lasted into his final hours. He is survived by his wife, his son Mark, daughter Geraldine, daughter - in - law Marilyn, and grandson Samuel.

title: The New Hard-Soft Power
description: In his 2002 book, "The Paradox of American Power," Joseph S. Nye Jr., the scholar and former Pentagon official, famously distinguishes between "hard" and "soft" power. The first is the power to coerce, largely through military might; the second, the power to co-opt through such "intangible" factors as culture, values and institutions (the media, churches, schools and so forth). In an era of globalized information, Nye observes, the power to persuade has become almost as important as the power to compel, and he criticizes American policy makers for their single-minded focus on brute force.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, PHILIP
description: JOHNSON -- Philip. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of our esteemed Trustee Philip Johnson. Philip was present at the opening of the Museum in 1929. He organized the Museum's first architecture and design exhibitions: "The International Style" in 1932 and "Machine Art" in 1934. In 1949 he was appointed the first director of the recently unified Department of Architecture and Design, stepping down in 1954 to become the first Chairman of the Trustee Committee on Architecture and Design, a position in which he served for thirty-seven years. Beginning in 1949, Philip designed numerous structures and spaces that visually enhanced the Museum, including the beloved Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden. The south facade of his 1964 East Wing, now beautifully restored as part of the Museum's recent renovation and expansion, stands as a tribute to his mid-career devotion to the International Style architecture of Mies van der Rohe. Philip bestowed upon the Museum an astounding munificence--in works of art as well as financial support--that will long be remembered in an institution that is known for the generosity of its leaders. Instrumental to the extraordinary breadth of the collection of the Department of Architecture and Design, his giving also touched almost every other curatorial department. The experience of visitors to The Museum of Modern Art would be decidedly diminished without the magnificent paintings Philip gave it, including Oskar Schlemmer's Bauhaus Stairway, Mark Rothko's Number 10, Jasper Johns's Flag, Andy Warhol's Gold Marilyn Monroe, and Roy Lichtenstein's Girl with a Ball. We extend our sympathies to David Whitney, his partner of forty-two years, to Mrs. John B. Dempsey, his sister, and to his entire family. David Rockefeller Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel President Glenn D. Lowry, Director Terence Riley, The Philip Johnson Chief Curator of Architecture and Design The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: Racing With Sam
description: At first, Sam Berns looked as odd as all the kids whose pictures I had been studying: big bald head, beaky nose, strangely undersize chin and mouth, blue veins twisting beneath a translucent scalp. He was very short and very skinny, and he had a stiff-hipped waddle when he walked. But after I spent a few minutes with him, the oddness melted away, and I was in the vivid vortex of Sam's personality -- noisy, jokey, smart, imaginative and just a little bit full of himself. The articles I'd read about Sam's disease didn't quite jibe with the bossy little kid who barked, ''No shoes in the playroom!'' the minute I walked in the door of his home in Foxboro, Mass., southwest of Boston. Sam has progeria, which is usually described as a grossly accelerated form of aging that turns children into wizened old men and women before their teens. But this child was no wizened old man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAILEY, WILLIAM O.
description: BAILEY--William O. Former president, chief operating officer, and vice chairman of Aetna Life & Casualty Company and former CEO and chairman of the board of MBIA Inc., died January 28, 2005 of pneumonia at age 78. A leading figure in the insurance and financial guarantee industries for five decades, Mr. Bailey played a key role in launching the financial guarantee industry in the early 1970's, a multi-billion dollar industry today. He was most recently chairman, CEO and president of Terra Nova (Bermuda) Holdings and Terra Nova Reinsurance Ltd., (London). Born on July 1, 1926 in Syracuse, NY, the son of William E. and Kate Olliver Bailey, he grew up in Northampton, MA, served in the United States Navy during World War II, and graduated from Dartmouth College in 1947. He received his MBA in Insurance from the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce at the University of Pennsylvania in 1949. A former resident of West Hartford, CT, Southampton, Bermuda, and Moultonborough, NH, he was predeceased by his parents, his sister Ann Bailey Doane and two sons, John Mason Bailey and Thomas Wood Bailey. He is survived by his wife of 26 years, Carole Parsons Bailey, and three children, son George (wife Marsha) Bailey of Northampton, MA; daughter Janet (husband Wilson) Faude of West Hartford, CT, and daughter Carolyn Bailey of Lexington, MA, as well as six beloved grandchildren, Kai and Aquila Bailey, Sarah and Paul Faude, and Adriana and Dylan Akers. Also surviving are nephews George Woodward Doane of Richmond, WA, and Robert Bailey Doane of Vallejo, CA. He is also survived by his longtime caregiver and friend Sylvia Grant-Reeves. Friends may call Tuesday, February 1 from 5-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, February 2 at 10:30 AM at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51 St. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 5 at 11:00 AM at St. John's Episcopal Church in West Hartford, CT. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the St. Bartholomew's Church Flower Fund, The William O. Bailey Scholarship Fund at Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH, or the Squam Lakes Association Sailing Program, Holderness, NH 03245.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCORMACK, GEORGE
description: McCORMACK -- George. George and Jerry, brothersin-law, two brilliant stars, one a romantic and a poet, the other a noble pragmatist, both consummate problem solvers. Each had an infinite capacity for love that made us all more generous of spirit. Students and teachers of literature, music, politics and history, ever curious and passionate about life and those they loved, even when enduring great hardship. They were loyal friends, devoted fathers and trusted advisors; intent listeners and riveting storytellers, often of tales that ended in departed laughter. So here's to alsatian muenster and petit liverot, Billy Collins and Jane Kenyon, Tim O'Brien and Alistair MacLeod, Venice, Margueritaville and that very special T.B. sanatarium; to speakeasies with live mermaids, soup with shall we say noodles, fresh "ersters" and chilled lobster; to surefooted donkeys tackling hairpin switchbacks; to Mozart, Beethoven, Tosca and "The Trout." Finally, our eternal thanks to Elizabeth and Mary, strong, independent and compassionate, the women who with grace and good humor so generously shared themselves and their men with us. Stancy DuHamel and Carolyn Handler

She was a member of the YMHA Senior's Group of Wayne, NJ and a Volunteer at the Wayne PTO Thrift Shop in Wayne, NJ, but she will mostly be remembered as a lifelong Ranger fan. Her late husband Kurt predeceased her. She is survived by her loving son Peter and his wife Debra, and their three adored children Andrew, Harrison and Grant of Wayne, NJ. She leaves behind a devoted brother Eric Pollitzer of West Palm Beach, FL. Graveside services 1 pm, Monday, January 31, 2005, at the Sharon Gardens Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. For info: Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Rd, Clifton, NJ. In lieu of shiva baskets or gifts, the family kindly requests that a donation be made to the Jewish Family Services of Northern NJ, or the Chilton Memorial Hospital Foundation in Pompton Plains, NJ.

description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 30 - The Environmental Protection Agency has developed a prototype diesel engine that meets tough new emissions standards to be phased in over the next few years in the United States. On Friday, the Ford Motor Company said the technology was promising enough that it had reached agreement with the agency to try to develop it for use in its cars and trucks.

title: Catskill Casino Politics: Game of Delicate Balance
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 27 - Clint Halftown, a leader of the Cayuga Indian Nation of New York, sent a letter to Gov. George E. Pataki on Dec. 31, saying his tribe was scuttling the planned settlement of a hard-fought land claim only six weeks after it had been signed and ending the tribe's relationship with a casino development company in the Catskill Mountains.

title: Volkswagen Chooses MediaCom Over Havas
description: In another blow to Havas, Volkswagen of America in Auburn Hills, Mich., has named MediaCom in New York, part of the Grey Global Group, to handle the media planning and buying duties on its account, which had been handled for nearly a decade by a Havas unit, the Boston office of MPG USA. Spending was estimated at $500 million.

description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority wants the Jets to pay nearly $300 million, or nearly three times what the team has offered, for the rights to build a 75,000-seat stadium over the railyard on the Far West Side of Manhattan, according to executives who have been briefed on the negotiations.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the Bronx fire of Jan. 23 in which two firefighters were killed after trying to jump to safety misstated the distance that a surviving firefighter was reported to have fallen. Firefighter Joseph DiBernardo's father said his son fell from a rope when he was about 10 feet out a fourth-floor window, not 10 feet from the ground. The Fire Department is still investigating and has not confirmed the account.
